reviews.review: A dazzling display of ornate architecture. The outside of the Spanish synanogue looks deceivingly simple. With a fun Kafka statue in front, it belies the ornamentation that lies inside. Beautiful motives, a fantastic organ, pillars that never end... It took my breath away.

Unexpected Moorish architecture in Prague Synagogue. We purchased a combi entrance ticket to multiple sites in the Jevovof quarter. All have stories to tell about a rich past and about horrible events that transpired during the nazi occupation. The fotographs of confiscated and categorized Jewish property in the Spanish Synagogue was confronting, and showed that the same zeal and dedication to execution (no pun intended) the Germans demonstrated then is still evident today in the VW emission scandal .. sad
The contrasts!!. This is the last of the synagogues in the sequence of the Jewish section. It is in a Moorish style and uniquely different from the others.
Astonishingly beautiful decorations. Marvellous building, justly described as the most beautiful Synagog in Europe. Concerts are held there, which is a magical experience.
Beautiful!. Beautiful internal decorations, Moorish style (the term "spanish" is misleading).Interesting explanations inside.Recommended.
Beautiful place. The decor in this synagogue was truly spectacular. Its seems as if every corner was made to look amazing. And don't miss the Kafka statue in front.

Impressive Spanish Synagogue. We went to a concert at the Spanish Synagogue, which is located in the heart of the Jewish quarter. Entry to the synagogue is part of the fee several attractions in the Jewish Quarter, but if you attend a concert, entry into the synagogue is included in the price of the ticket. The concert was wonderful and the synagogue is beautiful.

Jewish quarter and synagogues of Prague were wonderful to visit. Got the multi-site pass and visited most of the synagogues included. Most had some displays of museum-type artifacts, but it would be great if there were a museum that provided a broader perspective of Jewish life and history in Prague. Particularly moving, and horrifying, was the Jewish cemetery.

Unique Synagogue in Prague's Jewish District. I had an opportunity to attend a classical and Jewish music concert at that synagogue. It was an unforgettable experience in this uniquely designed synagogue.

A grand Concert. A concert featuring both a tenor and a soprano singing excerpts from Opera, whilst accompanied by violin and viola. The acoustics are magnificent. Only one hour long, but an hour of pleasure.

Exceeded Expectations. Came upon this while wandering around. Fascinating. Admission price was 70Crowns, and well worth it. Never having been in a synagogue before, I found it really interesting. The exhibition, also was interesting, chronicling the history of Judaism in Prague. The section on Terrazin was of particular interest, as my wife had recently read an account of it. We spent much more time here than we originally intended.

Quite interesting. Lots of gold leaf adorning the place but very little information to give any real atmosphe. Stained glass style was somewhat different if you are into that sort of thing but otherwise a little bland.
Gorgeous and Reverent. This is the most beautiful synagogue I've ever seen. Great part of the Jewish Ghetto tour with audio guide. Wonderful little museum of what Jews endured. Recommend highly.

Gorgeous and sensitive setting of Jewish culture and history. The interior is stunning in it's color and decoration in gold. There is a beautiful organ. A performance was rehearsing on the main floor when we were there. On the upper level was an in-depth display of Jewish history in good and terrible times.
Beautiful piece of history. An amazing building that outlines a valuable part of history in the Czech republic. Well worth a visit.

a quiet moment in a special place. we visited the Jewish quarter, synagogue and cemetery and you cannot help but go quiet and appreciate how solemn the history of the place is. I would recommend a guide (we caught the tail of another group) or an audio guide to fully unlock the value of the visit
definitely worthwhile. This has a beautiful interior, and extensive history of the Jewish community in Prague. It is in a charming part of Prague

Gorgeous Synagogue, a must see. This Synagogue is quite out of Jewish quarter and although marked on Jewish Quarter ticket map it requires a separate ticket for entry. Nevertheless it's definitely worth the price to support this gorgeous synagogue. There is loads of material and displays inside covering history of synagogue and famous people related to it, as well as interactive screens, so give yourself enough time to explore it.

not your normal synagogue. I was surprised to walk into this Synagogue. Not like anything I had seen. We did a self guided tour, renting a head set to take in all of the Synagogues in the area. Go early as it gets so busy. Another way to enjoy this beautiful building/place of worship is to attend a concert (I didn't attend). I would highly recommend seeing it, but on off time. People tend to forget that they are in a place of worship.
Gorgeous Synagogue. Very beautiful building. We did this as part of the Jewish quarter which is simply gorgeous all around. The architecture is amazing.

I wan't that inspired. I confess I wasn't that inspired but that is probably me. Definitely worth the visit. I confess we didn't take a tour of the Jewish quarter but hired some head phones instead. My wife liked them, I personally left needing more information.

Beautiful backdrop for a concert!. The resplendent Moorish-inspired walls of this beautiful synagogue are best appreciated while listening to the music of your favourite Czech composer. Let your eyes wander to admire the geometric golden patterns while the marvelous acoustics bounce the heavenly sounds from your ears to your soul.
Beautiful Synagogue. We took the Jewish quarter tour and visited a couple of synagogues. This one was absolutely gorgeous, definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful and remarkable in the story. This place also demands a guide who knows the history of the Jewish community in Prague. there is so much to see and MISS if not properly described. Yes it is beautiful but the story is the important point of this tour. It, along with the Jewish museum and graveyard are must do's while in Prague.
An important couple of hours. We visited the Jewish Quarter in Prague and the Spanish Synagogue was a site I would definitely recommend. A beautiful small room. Just lovely.

Synagogue with Moorish Influence. A must see if you are touring Jewish Quarter. The interior has a lot of exhibits about their history and the various events affecting the synagogue and their folks. Just as astonishing is the design of the interior is unique. The Moorish style is very apparent. it is definitely a worthwhile visit.

Existing! . This synagogue is very impressive and how its manage to remain untouched and preserved. The books inside are very old, and well kept. With one ticket you can visit five synagogues around the block.

Worth a visit. As I didn't have enough time to visit the Jewish cemetery, museum and all the synagogues in the Jewish Quarter, I was happy to pay the reasonable admission price of 70 coruna to see just the Spanish Synagogue. This impressive synagogue is the "youngest" in the city, built in the 1800's. The style of the interior is beautiful and ornate, unlike any I have seen. Ideally I would have liked to linger and take in the atmosphere at a quiet time, but I was there in the afternoon and unfortunately there were noisy tour groups going in and out. There was a small shop selling books and artefacts, and I purchased a small inexpensive book on "Jewish Prague" as well as several books by Franz Kafka.This synagogue is definitely worth a visit, and there are staff there to provide information.

Don't miss this synagogue's uniquely decorated interior.. Amazing architect with a good historical review on display. Quiet different from the other preserved synagogues int he Jewish Quarter. Certainly worth the price of admission.

If you interested on the Jewish community this is it!. After tge terrible experience in the old new synagogue we kept our promise and went to the Spanish and the museum. The ticket includes all in one (beside the oldnew and Jerusalem) It was beautiful real and educational.
Jewish Quarter Tour. Definitely a worthy stop on any Jewish Quarter tour. Beautiful interior lined with shadow boxes of jewish artifacts and information. A great stop on any Jewish Quarter tour.

Very interesting and informative display.. Well worth visiting in the Jewish Quarter. Ornate interior with a very good display of documents, ornate silverware and personal effects from members of the Jewish community. I was appalled at the ignorant (in both senses of the word) behaviour of some of the tour groups. Talking and laughing in what is a place of worship and remembrance. Most didn't bother looking at the displays or bother talking to the informative staff who were there. To be frank I was a bit disappointed that staff didn't intervene and ask people who behave badly to leave. It's the type of person who later boasts "Oh yeah we did the Spanish Synagogue". Take some time afterwards to explore the Jewish area and pause in the shady seating areas, a world away from the madness that is Charles Bridge.
Great. Awesome, breathtaking, there is the whole secret city, catacombs and the legend of clay robot - Golem.

Beautiful!. The Spanish synagogue is just one of a number of sites that make up the Jewish museum in Prague, but it is certainly the prettiest. Very ornate, but much more tasteful than the 'Catholic bling' of many local churches it is a must see, in my opinion. The synagogue now houses an exhibition on the Jewish community in Bohemia and Moravia since the late 18th century, so picking up where the exhibition at the Maisel synagogue leaves off really.
Spanish Synagogue. The architecture of the synagogue is amazing and there's a lot of history displayed inside. Incredibly insightful.

Beautiful interior . This forms part of the bundle of attractions that one must pay for to see the highlights of the Jewish Quarter. The site itself is a little away from the other attractions on the ticket but is undoubtedly one of the highlights.The interior decor is stunning. This alone would make the visit worthwhile but the exhibits are also extremely interesting. I know little of Judaism and found it fascinating. The material relating to the period 1939 - 1945 is extremely moving and very educational. The exhibits are well signed in English and Czech allowing one to get a good insight into the items and themes on display. I was glad I visited.

BEAUTIFUL! Most amazing interior I've seen in a Synagogue. We first saw the New-Old Synagogue, which at 700 years old was incredibly interesting and ancient looking. Not the Spanish Synagogue, though - this place is covered in gold and has beautiful windows! The Moorish architecture is beautiful.

only expensives bundles ticket are available. Pass away. The live expense in Praga are twice the western EU parts but for the tourists we have to pay the western prices!Only expensive bundles are available (as for the castle) and you are obliged to buy a combined ticket even if you are only interested by one monument (as for us the cemetery).We hate this type of tourist trap and go away...

Unbelievable, amazing details in the place!. I came here with my mum and brother to this Synagogue and it is absolutely beautiful because theres so much detail within the designs of the walls. It just is incredible, if you are ever visiting Prague, please come to this building!

Ok. We bought the full ticket which included the cemetery. To be honest you don't need to see the cemetery, just imagine lots of headstones all pushed together and you're there. The old/new synagogue was thought provoking with the walls covered in all the names of people who lost their lives during the German occupation. The buildings are all close to each other so there's not too much walking. The folk working in these buildings could do with a happy pill each. Would I recommend it, yes. It's interesting and poignant
Worth the visit. Beautiful Moorish architecture. One of the best tours in Prague city. The Old New Synagogue is close by.

A Very Interesting place when site seeing.. We are really impressed with the entire Jewish quarter but the Spanish Synagogue seems to be the most popular with our guests that we take through Prague. This is a very impressive synagogue and very small price for entry. Recommend you tour the entire Jewish quarter and don't miss the Spanish Synagogue.
Synagogue. Beautiful synagogue, it looks very different from the other Jewish synagogue. Detailed designs and patterns covering the whole place, no detail is too small here.

The tour of the Jewish quater offered an insight to old Prague and some beautiful Synagogues.. We chose the shorter less expensive version which gave admission to 5 locals. each was interesting and worth the time spent. It was crowded buy comfortable I would definitely recommend this stop..

Tour the Jewish sector. One of a number of Synagogues we visited in the Jewish Sector and very impressive. A lot smaller than the ones in Budapest but still very meaningful. These visits tend to make you think a little harder about what life is all about and how much so many gave theirs for us to go forward. Lest we forget...

Jewish quarter visit. A whole day of touring around this quarter, stopping only for occasional drinks and a meal. A very moving and humbling trip, we visited all of the buildings in the quarter, walked the streets and took in the sights. Some small entrance fees did not deter us, needs at least 2-3 hours.

Disorganized and inefficient. I purchased tickets on line to avoid crowds but the web site would not allow you to print tickets. The staff was very friendly but most did not speak English. There are several buildings and synagogues to visit each with its own ticket purchasing line and ticket entrance line. Communication between these different ticketing areas are chaotic, policies different and lines unavoidable. My group was expelled from one synagogue for not having the proper photography permission ticket sold to us at the central ticketing area. Overall a most unpleasant experience dispite some wonderful people working there trying to make things function. This Jewish museum needs new management!

Evening concert. We were at the Kafka statue, which is located right beside the Spanish Synagogue, and decided to purchase tickets to a concert taking place that evening in the Spanish synagogue.What a beautiful building full of much important history and a tremendous place to hold a small intimate concert.
Ornately fitted and interesting museum. Fitted in the Moorish style, it now contains an elaborate museum of Jewish artifacts and historic materials.which are well worth the visit.

Horrible rude woman attendant. I was enjoying visiting the Jewish museum in Prague and found it very interesting. While I was viewing the Spanish synagogue at the end of my visit I took out my iPad to take a wide angle photo and swept it across the room. I understood that there were to be no videos taken and thought I was okay with a wide angle photo as there were many other people using digital cameras and cell phones taking pictures. The older woman attendant came rushing at me yelling and shaking her finger and saying no video. I tried to explain it was only a photo and she kept saying the same thing over and over and wouldn't let me explain, her voice getting louder like I was arguing with her, pointing at the sign saying no video cameras. I said okay, I got it. When I went into the next room she followed me suspiciously. I took out the iPad and went to open it to show it was only a photo and again she yelled at me NO VIDEO!! People in the room all looked to see what the commotion was about and I felt like a criminal. I finally just turned and left the building, her following me. It spoiled the whole experience for me and I deleted the photo as I knew I could never look at it without being reminded how unpleasant this experience was and how I felt. I asked the people with me what they thought and they said she was rude and over the top and no need for that kind of behaviour.

Worlds most beautiful synagogue . If you are in Prague the Spanish synagogue is a MUST!!! Although it functions as a non-classic reform synagogue it is one of the most beautiful in the world. It is called the Spanish synagogue simply because the design of it is Spanish! One can spend a whole day just looking at the architectural and design aspects of the interior. Highly recommended!

Paradise on Earth. Fantastic,breath-taking and super!This is the most beautiful synagogue I have ever seen.It is huge,with tiny,pretty details and you do not realize that you are in Prague,Europe.You just HAVE TO visit these!!!!!!

Go here only for religious reasons. We went there with expectations of a historical and informative site, but it needs background. So wont recommend this to be on the must do things in prague unless details of jewsish persecution interest you a lot. the whole jewish are takes around 2 hours to cover.

Very Interesting. The Spanish Synagogue itself is beautiful but it was the articles on display in the glass cases within it which will stay with me. Some of the materials in particular will stay with me forever and are a stark reminder of what happened during the Holocaust. An important site that everyone should visit in Prague.

A Disappointing Visit to the Jewish Quarter. Having visited Budapest and Berlin I was looking forward to visiting the Jewish Quarter in Prague, but was sadly very disappointed. I thought I would be able to stroll around at my own pace and spend time looking at each of the buildings and learning more about the history of the area. Each of the buildings was packed to full capacity which made it quite uncomfortable in the heat. There is only one venue to buy your tickets from and the queues are very long you can gain access from the street behind but only to walk along the streets. You can't just visit the cemetery you have to buy a multiple tour ticket which makes the tour expensive for what it is. I left with the impression that this is just a money making exercise and the staff at times were quite rude to visitors who didn't understand the ticket concept to gain entry.
Interesting piece of history. Worth a visit for the beautiful interiors and historic displays.Far too many selfie takers for my liking
Stunning!. The Spanish Synangogue is definitely worth a visit due to its beauty and unusual decor. Its exhibits are also very interesting.

Magnificent synagogue. This moorish style synagogue reflects the beginning of the reform movement. You can see the organ pipes, the bimah is at the end wall instead of the center. The walls are absolutely beautiful. Almost no place to sit (3 chairs only) so don't plan on it. Get the audio guide

Such a beautiful, highly ornamentd Synagogue.. It is a highly emotional experience to visit the Jewish quarter of Prague and to enter the Synagogues, now museums. This brings home to you the horror of the holocaust when you consider that this beautiful building was simply a place of worship for Pragues Spanish Jewish community. Now gone.

Part of the Jewsih Museum ticket... Beautiful. What a beautiful work of art, this building and all that is in it. Take a moment to go upstairs and look at the history and stories of the Jewish People of Prague who may have worshiped here or in another temple close by..

Informative and a place of true beauty. The Spanish Synagogue offers an excellent insight into the long of the Jewish community in Prague.it is informative and so artful.We had the opportunity to enjoy one of the many concerts offered at the synagogue and the music, acoustics and performaers were all first class.

Amaxing. You must not miss this. I'd recommend seeing this as part of the Jewish area tour; the ticket price is reasonable. Also, be sure the get the audio guide; it really helps. The beauty of this synagogue is outstanding.

very beautiful. You can barely miss the Spanish Synagogue because it is quite easy to find within the Jewish quarter. The architecture is very interesting and nice to see. On the first floor you can see some exhibits and the main part of the synagogue, on the second floor there are more exhibits to see from the history of the synagogue as well as some pictures from Terezin.

Awesome!. This is worth visiting simply because it is so unlike any synagogue you have ever seen! Ornate gold and an organ! There is some interesting information to read upstairs in the display cabinets.

Another fine example of Pragues treasures. It is called Spanish because its Moorish architecture resembling Alhambra. Apart of serving as a museum it has concerts. This reformed synagogue has organ and the author ot the Czech national anthem who used to play organ in opposite catholic church and in nearby protestant church, was engaged by elders and played here also. On the first floor there is interesting exhibition of artifacts from Terezin, like currency, bank books. post stamps and so on not to be shown in Terezin
Interesting visit.. Visited the Jewish Quarters. Very interesting historical place. Guide was very good. Attended live concert at the Spanish Synagoge.

Located in the old Jewish Ghetto..very historical and moving. This is one of several synagogues in the Ghetto areas..Most are closed and are really historical..one has the names of those killed in the holocaust, one is museum of Jewish art and artifacts. The old cemetery is a sight to see very interesting and historical. I suggest you this with a guide or else you will miss much.

Took my breath away!. After five years living in Prague I finally managed to visit this jewel and I was impressed! It is worth buying the ticket which includes other synagogues and the cemetery but in my opinion this synagogue was absolutely the best! Make sure you reserve enough time to explore the exposition inside and soak in the athosphere of the place.

Well kept and peice of history from the remarkable Jewish life in Prague. This is one of the synagogues inside the area that is called the Jewish Museum in Prague. By buying the Jewish Museum ticket you can wander around and see a few synagogues, exhibits from the old Jewish town, a display of children drawings from the Terezinstadt ghetto and the Jewish old cemetery.

A very interesting but grim reminder of the oppression of Jewish people in Poland.. This whole area is very interesting and provides an actual backdrop to the long term oppression suffered by Jewish people in Prague and Poland at large. The Spanish Synagogue gives an excellent account of the history of Polish Jews with actual artifices from various times. It should be compulsory for everyone to be told this story to remind us of just how easy it is to scapegoat minorities and for ordinary people to become victims or oppressors.
Beautifully decorated!. Highly recommend a visit! It's beautifully decorated on the inside, so detailed, very impressive! Also some interesting photos and stories on display on the upper level.
beautiful. This is a beautiful piece of art, architecture and history! Do take the time to see this amazing synagouge

Stunning synagogue in the heart of Prague. The outside of this synagogue is nothing special; nothing can prepare you for the exceptionally stunning interior - truly beautiful. Every surface - ceilings, walls, pillars - is covered with immaculate, glittering decoration. Geometric patterns stretch out into the distance. It was crowded when we went - a late morning in August - so this wasn't especially appealing; but the splendour of the place eclipsed this. Make sure you go upstairs for a different viewpoint. This synagogue is accessible via the Jewish Museum ticket, which includes entry to all the Josefov synagogues and to the striking, ancient graveyard.

Insanely beautiful. This synagoga is magically beautiful inside! You can go on the main floor and to gallery. Orgel concerts in the evenings. The ceapest ticket option for entrance is 70 czkr if you want just to get inside this one, otherwise it is worthy to buy an extended ticket for Old jewish town.

One of the most beautiful building interiors I've ever seen. This building is stunning. I say this after having recently toured the Sistine Chapel and the cathedral in Orvieto (which, for my money, is better than the Sistine Chapel). I can't think of any other building interior as beautiful, anywhere. We attended an evening concert here, which gave us over an hour to contemplate the space. Just spectacular.

Great architecture, interesting history. This is one of several synagogues on the Jewish quarter circuit in Prague, and possibly the most beautiful one. It is called "Spanish" not because of any Sephardic connection, but because of the architecture, and that is a significant attraction. The exhibit is also very informative.

jewish quarter. A must see while in Prague. A story that all must know about citizens of Prague and all of Europe that were persecuted during WWII as well as all through history. This community contributed greatly to the growth of Prague. Long lines visited by all religions and nationalities of people. Hopefully a lesson learned.

Pleasure for Eyes, Feed for Mind. In a relatively compact place (two flours) you would learn everything about the fundamentals of the Jewish heritage across centuries, and understand by the way some slices of central Europe's history. Museum's arrangement is intuitive and the synagogue (containing the museum) itself depicts scenic exotic beauty.
so moving!. The synagogue holds entries for over 80000 Who lost their lives in Hitlers genocide. .so moving and gave me a feeling of deep responsibility and wishing for social change.

Interesting. The synagogue is quite beautiful on the inside, but more importantly was the information on Jewish History. I would recommend buying a full ticket and visiting the whole of the Jewish Quarter for a couple of days. Tickets valid for 7 days and not expensive.
beautiful. Beutiful structure and interior decoration- don't miss the great little museum upstairs with magnificent silver displays

worth visiting. This neighborhood is fascinating... to contemplate the thriving Jewish community that existed in this city before Worl dWar Two. This is a lovingly restored and maintained synagogue in the "moorish" style.
Jewish History. I took the Jewish tour and it was very interesting. The cost was not too much and the places where interesting. The tour covers several places and one must walk from place to place.

Part of the Jewish Quarter - Take the whole walking tour. Stunning building and part of the Jewish Quarter walking tour. Purchase a ticket and go on your own, or use an individual guide so you are not rushed.

Stunning. A must see.. The artifacts on display here are amazing. Take your time and read all about the different items. You would really benefit from a guide of some sort to understand the history behind this place.

A wonderful synagogue. Learn a lot about the Jewish population of Prague. Magnificent building Spanish Alhambra style. Well worth visiting. Yu can visit this as part of a package of a number of stops.

Not stunning but some interesting history. Not an architectural masterpiece but probably the best looking building in the Jewish quarter, this is worth visiting if you have an interest in Jewish history or the Holocaust but its probably not an essential stop for anyone else.

The best of the synagogues in the area. If you havent got time to see them all this in my opinion is the prettiest, with lovely ceilings and decor and historical references.We bought the kippah at the entrance but actually you dont need to as it was not obligatory to wear it.
Impressive. It was the first time I visited a synagogue. This one is very beautiful. I was particularly surprised by its tinyness

Strikingly different. If you were plucked down in this spot without knowing anything about the building, you would be shocked to learn that it is a synagogue. It looks more like a church in many ways. Very much worth seeing and learning another piece of the puzzle of Jewish history in Prague.

Spanish synagog. The most beautiful synagogue that I have seenVery unique and you can see there also pictures of the place and the Jews before the world war 2 very impressive and you can buy ticket to this synagogue only

Highly unusual design, much history here. Warm interior, reformed synagogue, revocable do several times over. Good historical materials on display in cases regarding history of Jews in Prague, including WWII.
attend a concert!. I've visited the museum before and this time attended a very enjoyable concert one evening. It was a pleasure to see the beautiful place again.

Interesting if you see them all. Buy a combined ticket to see all the synagogues, and the Jewish cemetery. Each synagogue has its own exposition, on Jewish presence in Prague, on deportation, on Jewish daily life, etc. Good information in Czech and in English.

Eye catching building .. Although I never ventured into here as I was rushing to meet friends I couldn't help but see this magnificent looking building. The Spanish Synogogue looks so beautiful with the rich colour scheme of the exterior and is certainly very eye catching. I have been to Spain many many times and this synagogue would not be out of place there and is as beautiful as some I have seen in Spain. The synagogue was erected in the 19th century and is a landmark building in this area.Located in the Josefon district not to far from the beautiful Old Town. You will find Spanish Synogogue on Vezenska not to far from the unique Franz Kafka Monument. A building that is well worth checking out.

Meaningful visit. We visited this synagogue along with 3 others and the Jewish cemetery. The beautiful design of this building also contains historical displays with items from the holocaust showing a timeline of what was happening. Beautiful....

Stunning moorish architecture. The Spanish Synagogue in Josefov is a mosaic wonder and a great venue for music concerts. The synagogue is an easy walk from the old Jewish cemetery, Parizka, and Old Town Square.

Amazing concert. We saw that the Synagogue was offering a Gershwin concert and we immediately booked the tickets, despite them being quite expensive. This was a great performance and an even greater feeling of being in such a spiritual place to listen to Gershwin.
Nice. As part of the visit in the Jewish quarter I would recommend to buy an all inclusive ticket and visit this Synagogue as well.
Full of history. A big reminder og what happend in history and why it is so importent to make surre it never happens again.

Go to a concert here!. We missed the opportunity to go to a concert here on a previous visit to Prague and are so glad we made it a priority on this visit. The atmosphere was lovely as the Synagogue is beautiful. The music was great, with a nice mix of vocals included, and the accoustics were great. Since each concert only seats 200 people, it's good to get there early (and make sure you have your tickets with you!)

Interesting. Visited as part of the Jewish Quarter the Spanish Synagogue had some interesting artefacts and told a comprehensive story of the history of the Jewish citizens of Prague through the ages.

Outstanding building. The Jewish Museum ticket is excellent value, as long as you realise it last for 8 days. There is absolutely no necessity to rush around and risk missing things, or feel you simply haven't time to get everything in: you do. And it's a good thing too, as the Spanish Synagogue is an amazing building, full of interesting history and cultural information.There are plenty more reviews on here to laud it, all I will say is this - take your time going around it. It can be difficult, when a building is as magnificent as this, to take it all in without getting overwhelmed and used to it.
Synagogue with a Moorish Touch. This synagogue has a very unique decor making it a worthy part of the Jewish Quarter. We enjoyed our time walking through this historic edifice.

Look at the roof in wonder.. We went to a concert here - a small group played - 4 violinists, 1 x cello, a couple of brass instruments incl. trumpet and a female vocalist who did not need amplification due to the wonderful acoustics inside the synagogue. They have different concerts, we saw Hallelujah which included music from Leonard Cohen, Queen, and music from West side Story and Fiddler on the Roof. It is on at 7.00pm each night and goes for an hour - go and enjoy!

Beautiful. They say that it is the most beautiful synagogue in Europe, and they are probably rightThe altar is with golden and blue colors, it has 2 floors and a huge organThey often organize classic and other kind of concerts

Do not skip it! Worth visiting!. We have visited all the synogogues in the Jewish Museum, but this was by far our favorite. The interior is just impressive. It left us with the mouth open. It is so richly ornamentated. You won't regret visiting it! I do not know if it is all the time like that, but we found it full of tourists, tour groups and it was a bit tiring, dashing often into people. Apart from that, nothing to complain.
Gorgeous interior. A stunning place. We saw it first on a tour of the Jewish quarter. We then went there for a concert. Well worth the experience. One of the most beautiful synagogues in the worth.

Dull-and I was really looking forward to it !. Oh dear. So much more could of been made of these exhibits. They could of been supplemented by film of the era, or follow a family through all the hardships endured. Better use of interactive media could of made it fascinating. More supplementary languages to explain the exhibits in detail would if been useful as a lot of them were only Czech (with some Hebrew). There was limited English used. I was particularly looking forward the Spanish Synagogue. Architecture was beautiful, but again had little/no idea what the exhibits were!It would if been great to learn more of the history, and the uses of the objects displayed. We learnt more about the history of the Jewish Quarter from our guide from 'The Naked Tour' , the next day. Maybe we should of got the audio tour, but we didn't know in advance how difficult it would be to work it all out!
So beautiful synagogue. It is really a shock to see so beautiful indoor deco and you have also a very interesting small museum inside

Spectacular interior. This is reportedly the most beautiful synagogue in Europe. The walls and ceilings were stunning. The pews were roped off so you couldn't sit down. The geometric shapes around the room were stunning. It's definitely worth a visit.

It is beautiful inside. This was one of many synagogues we visited in the Jewish Quarter here in Prague. It has a beautiful interior. Perhaps I would have been even more impressed if I had not already seen so many synagogues and churches. I definitely recommend having a tour guide when you visit the Jewish Quarter. It is well worth the cost.

Worth Going!. Me and my two daughters really enjoyed the visit and learning about new cultures! To learn about the history of a religion that has survived persecutions and torture, it was more than a pleasure to learn about it in the old synagogue. Really interesting.

What a synagogue!. This really is a stunning structure and well worth the visit. The inside of the church has a real Mediterranean feel with Arabic influence. Up stairs gives a little history on the Jewish loss in the war .

Spanish Synagogue .... Beautiful. I loved seeing this synagogue in person. The ornateness is so splendid. I loved that on the second level is an exhibition on the history of the Spanish Synagogue. In the front of the Spanish Synagogue is the Kafka sculpture.

Beautiful, ornate. I attended a classical concert at the Spanish Synagogue, a beautifully ornate structure located in the Jewish Quarter of Prague. The intricate design of the synagogue added to the beauty of listening to excerpts from Bach, Vivaldi, and even Gershwin. Truly a remarkable evening. Great acoustics and beautiful design.

Stunning architecture. This is a beautiful synagogue and well worth a visit. There are other synagogues right nearby and it is worth seeing as many as you can since all are different. Most are not in use for services now but are just museums but it is important to realize what a vital flourishing society Jewish people were before the Holocaust.
Beautiful interior. The interior of the Spanish Synagogue is opulent and beautiful. The exhibition on recent Jewish history was also really interesting. Allow half an hour or so.

The most unusual of the synagogues in Prague. The interior design and the fact that it was fitted with an organ to accommodate reformed jewish worship make this the most unusual of the synagogues in the jewish quarter of Prague. The displays include an exhibition of the assimilation of gentile culture into the jewish community.
Beautiful. Truly inspired design and finish. An amazing collection of religious artifacts. Statue of Kafka is memorable.

Spectacular and well preserved Sephardic synagogue and museum. This is one of six sites of the Jewish Museum complex which also includes the Old/New synagogue - part of which dates back to the 1200s, the old Jewish cemetery, another Ashkenazi synagogue, and ritul museum.This particular site is no longer in active use as a synagogue due to the absence of sufficient remaining Sephardic Jews to form a viable congregation. It contains a well-organized and documented exhibit of ritual items from all major functions of an active synagogue ( most from other liquidated synagogues) and also several historical documents and commentaries. Because this synagogue was used by the Nazis as a storehouse for all the ritual items looted from other synagogues, this building was not destroyed as many others were. While neglected by the Communists that followed, they, too, also did not raize the building as they did to many others.Of note to those visitors from countries with prominant Jewish populations such as Israel, parts of the USA, Britain, many of the ritual items and their explanations may seem surprisingly basic - especially to Jews themselves (like our family). However, the tour groups we saw appeared to be mostly young people from Germany and Spain, and some middle-aged people from France. It occured to us that many of those people had little exposure to Jews in their daily life, so that this basic information was necessary to give them an idea of what the practice of Judaism even is. I have never, for example, seen a church in Europe that gives basic explanations regarding Catholic or Protestant church services, rituals, or beliefs. That fact is, in itself, quite sobering.

Favourite of the Prague Synagogues. Wanted to visit some of the sites in the Jewish quarter and ended up buying the combination ticket that allows access to all the sites as it was a great deal (especially with the student discount). Spanish synagogue was my favourite of the synagogues. Very beautiful inside. Lots of moorish influence. The exhibits were also very interesting and informative
Surprising. The best Jew synagogue to see.Surprising inside decoration.A place where you may really feel the spirit.

Fascinating. It is the best part of the Jewish museum in Prague.The building is very beautiful, especially inside.There is an exposition with some highlights from history. You have to buy a ticket for the whole Jewish museum comprising several buildings and the cemetery, you can also buy separately an audio guide. It is better to come in the morning, later it becomes crowded.

Concert in a beautiful synagogue . This shul was one of the most beautiful synagogues I have ever been to in my life. We saw a "Gershwin" concert in the synagogue. My kids are not into this type of music but they loved this experience. They were mesmerized by the magnificent environment.Sitting in this beautiful shul (built in the 1800's to celebrate the emancipation of the Jews) while listening to the brilliant music from Gershwin, really makes you think about the horrific tragedy of the holocaust, the people that were murdered, and what contributions might have been made to the world by the victims had the holocaust never happened. Go to this synagogue. Remember.

Breathtaking setting for a memorable concert . Attended the most memorable concert in the spanish synagogue. The fascinating interior captivates the limited audience ( unlike the other more touristic crowded concerts in the different bigger opera houses). The chamber orchestra did wonders in keeping up with the beautiful soprano who gave us chills throughout.

Worth a visit while touring the Jewish Museum Sites. This is worth 15 minutes of your day if you're in the area. The architecture is beautiful. It is interesting that only the style is Spanish - there is no other connection to Spain or Spanish Jews.

what a performance. went here to see a performance of excerpts from carmina burana, bolero, and more. beautiful setting with a rich deep acoustic tone. well worth the visit to see the venue with the performance being about 1 hour - just long enough for the seating but a cushion would have been even better. would go again.
You've got to go in to this one.. Gorgeous interior; must be seen. Went in as part of our Jewish Prague walking tour. Interesting modern sculpture of Kafka outside.

Very thought provoking. This is part of the Jewish quarter your which also includes the me museum other synagogues and the old Jewish. Cemetery. The history of the Prague Jewish. Community and the tragic fate of most of them who were murdered by the Nazis is documented and the sheer scale of the murders is shown in one of the synagogues where the name of Everyone murdered is recorded.

An exquisite building. This is a beautifully restored synagogue. The interior is breathtaking in its beauty. In the upper gallery is an exhibition about the history of the Jews in the Bohemian lands from the eighteenth century to the period after the Second World War. It is an interesting story of how Jews emerged from the ghetto and integrated into Czech society, before the Holocaust. The exhibition of Synagogue Silver from Bohemia and Moravia is very interesting, if you know what the objects purpose was, the labelling could be clearer for non-Jews.To be honest I think the exhibitions are of limited interest to non-Jews, but the beauty of the interior is intoxicating, so just sit back (there are chairs dotted about) and breathe in the wonder.
Beautiful place. This is a very attractive site - with some interesting Jewish artifacts. The visit can be done with the remainder of the Jewish quarter.
Beautiful. gilding, woodwork, sculpture fills the synagogue. it's just amazing.Kether the collections Torah and the yad collections are beautiful.A synagogue to visit imperatively.
Touched!. The 5 synagogues are completely standing. They are all beautiful in each style. They are full of history and tell the history of Jew Prague. Amazing

Striking Interior - Lovely Kabbalat Shabbat Service. I visited this synagogue twice - once as a tourist and once as a congregant. Both visits were enjoyable. The interior is striking. Go outside of service times to take pictures. On Friday nights, they have a Kabbalat Shabbat service beginning at 19:00 in the summer. You need a picture ID. I had my NC driver's license. Once I spoke Hebrew to the guard, it made things much easier. Check for winter service times. It's a "Reform" but really more "Conservative" service. If you're Jewish and in Prague for Shabbat, definitely include this service on your itinerary.

Absolutely stunning. We did not know what to expect when we walked in... we figured it would be just another synagogue. How wrong we were! This place is absolutely stunning - pictures do not do it justice. We would have appreciated some chairs to sit on - the pews were cordoned off - to properly sit back and take it in.
Very NICE. This was a really important place to visit. I learned a lot about the community and the history of the Jewish people in the Czech republic. The synagogue is beautiful.

An Amzing place to visit. The object inside represent Jewish history reaching back many centuries. The architecture is breathtaking and the memorabilia from real Czech Jews was incredibly educational.
A Gem. Incredible architecture reminiscent to Cordoba or the Alhambra. Glorious interior, full of light and color
Gorgeous. Part of our families' desire to visit Prague was to go to the old Jewish ghetto and to visit the Spanish synagogue. What a striking structure!

Highlight of Prague. We spent almost a full day in the various synagogues and cemetery of Prague. Each synagogue has its own flavor and history and our time was well spent exploring each. The Spanish Synagogue is exquisite in its style and detail. The Maisel synagogue is a wealth of information about its and Prague's history. The Pinkas Synagogue is beautiful, but heartbreaking with its wall panels listing Czech Jews murdered by the Nazis. The Burial Society had memorable paintings of funerals in old times and a very interesting exhibit. The old cemetery is beautiful and is the place of interment of notable Jewish leaders. The Old New Shul, still in use as a synagogue, is a must see. We were there for prayers and the acoustics are amazing. All the sites are testimony of what was once an important and vibrant center of Jewish life.

Jewish only. Every body says that you should go here but unless you are Jewish then dont bother as we was told all money went for restoration of the building and the church yard but you cannot see much restoration being done.The exhibition rooms had lots of Jewish memorabilia most was in Jewish so could not be read.

Beautiful fresco-like walls painted in intricate patterns with gold leaf. Stunning.. I highly recommend a visit. In addition to beautiful, intricately painted walls and a lovely altar and organ, there is a fascinating and haunting exhibit upstairs that chronicles the rich Jewish community and its destruction by the Nazis. It is good to take this in as part of a tour of the Jewish quarter so you can see the several synagogues there, as well as the old Jewish cemetery. But if you have to see one, this is it!

Very Unique. This is the most beautiful synagogue in Prague, and I found it very impressive. The design is very detailed and lovely. It's also an excellent venue for concerts, one of which I truly enjoyed one evening.
Poignant. Nice décor and expected it to be bigger. Hosts live concerts but we didn't get the chance to attend. Worth a visit
Very beautiful Synagogue. One of kind, very nice Synagogue, if you'd have a chance to go for a live concert there - don't miss it.

Stunning for a visit or to see a concert.. Its part of the Jewish Museum and architecturally, this synagogue, built in the late 19th century in a Spanish/Moorish style, is the highlight for me. It's richly decorated, light and airy and also has excellent acoustics as we returned for a concert in the evening. Also don't miss the strange statue of Franz Kafka sitting on the shoulders of the Golem next door.

Breathtaking Architecture. The remarkable displays of photographs and documents trace the changes of the Jewish community of several hundred years ago to the pre WWII era--from rags to riches, from religious life to the secular outlook.

Every surface covered in intricate patterns. This has a stunning interior. Every wall, ceiling and pillar is covered in painted intricate patterns. The overwhelming colours are rich maroon red and gold, but there are other deep colours also. You can view the synagogue from the ground floor and from the balcony, where there is also a display of the history of the Jews in Prague.
Impressive. Very grand and detailed. Over the top to impress. Visually amazing. If one is in the Jewish Quarter its a must see but would not make an extra trip as there is so much to see in the city.
Well worth a visit. Great design of a spectacular building. Lots of history in the exhibits. If you staying in the city,within walking distance. A sight not to be missed.

Gold, gold and more gold. It's almost impossible to take a picture here, that does it justice. Although your attention will definititely go to all the beautifull golden walls, if you take a little more time, there are many things to be learned as well.

Remind me of the beautiful temple/mosque in Spsin. I bought the combo ticket of CZK480 which allows me to visit 5 Jewish sites in the Jewish Quarter in Prague. This is the last stop and the most beautiful one. The setup and building interior design reminds me the temple/mosques i have just visited in Seville, Granada in Spain one month ago. It is quite small compared with the big siblings in the Spain. However its beauty and architecture is still impressive and i would still give a thumbs up.

Just beautiful. While I haven't visited many synagogues, I know this one was special, Visited it as part of a tour of the Jewish Section. The other 4 synagogues were interesting, but this was the most beautiful.

Beautiful old temple. We came here on our first night in Prague. Had dinner across the street, plenty of Czech beer, then attended a music concert at the Spanish Synagogue. The antiquity of the place is amazing, along with the delicacy of the design and detailing. We heard a small orchestra perform a variety of musical pieces, from classical to Queen. Accompanied by a wonderful soprano from the Prague symphony, our experience here was such a great way to enjoy our first night in Prague.

Beautiful Synagogue in the heart of the Jewish Quarter. The Jewish quarter is well worth the visit and has a very rich history. The Spanish Synagogue is beautiful and was built in the 1800s. You can We did not take the tour, but bought the ticket that gives you entrance to most of the buildings in the Jewish quarter.

unusual synagogue. we have been here more than once; very interesting place, it looks like a church, has an organ with great pipes, lots of silver and gold items that showcase the traditions, outside the statue of Kafka is great & hard to miss. WELL WORTH A VISIT!
Beautiful Building. Don't try to visit the synagogues on a Saturday - they won't be open and the Rabbi was getting very stressed and irate with the tourists.
Simply beautiful . What a beautiful place. Photographs don't do it justice. We were on a small group tour and found it interesting. It is a functioning reformed synagogue.
Overpriced. I would say that the ticket is overpriced, as part of the wider site ticket, think it is quite exploitive of the religion.
Very informative and well worth a visit. We visited this Synagogue and two others with a multi-ticket and found it a very interesting visit. You'll not be disappointed

Unforgettable Prague experience in the Spanish Synagogue/Museum. We were incredibly moved by this experience. I don't this it matters what one's religious affiliation might be, this experience is not to be missed.
Must see. We took a Jewish walking tour of Prague when we were there and this was one of the highlights. Be sure to go with a guide, we would recommend Prague Walkers.

Interesting Hour. We decided to visit this museum even though we are not Jewish. It was very poinient to see the number of exhibits which came fron WWII. It also made me wonder why this religion has been persecuted for centuries.

An Architectural beauty!. The beautyf and the preservation of this synagogue is so spectacular, you run the risk of forgettting what transpired. While small, the breathtaking interiors and the exhibits there-in, bring to mind both the splendour of Jewish architecture and the extent of their matyrdom. It takes your breath away but you stand solemnly reminded of how cruel humanity can be.
Book a concert. Booked a concert at the Spanish Synagogue. Great acoustics, good music, and a smaller crowd attending.

Dont miss exhibit upstairs. Amazing place, has to be seen to be believed. Like my title says, dont miss upstairs for the historical display on the sad ongoing anti-semitism Prague has endured.It will touch your heart. As someone with a bladder problem, i appreciated the free toilet. Nice staff.

very impresive synagogue. this synagogue is part of the old Jewish quarter in Prague and one of the more impressing one .you can get a combined ticket for some of the interesting historic location in the Jewish quarter /
Beautiful Spiritual Place. Beautiful and informative. Pay attention that a visit here is included when you purchase the Jewish Quarter Visit Ticket.

Religion meets beauty. The area is fabulously located to shopping, park, public transport. The building decor and design was so beautiful and well maintained. The day we were visiting the place it was pack but still feel the spiritual component and how beautiful the place. Highly recommend to visit the synagogue.

Moving back in time. WE spent one day visiting all of the synagogues and the Old Jewish Cemetery. It was like a trip into the past. I grew up in Poland where very little was left from the very rich Jewish pre-war tradition and culture so this was an eye-opening experience even though I do not have Jewish roots myself. I highly recommend it.

A Must See. The architecture inside this place is amazing - especially when viewed from upstairs. Never very crowded and also some wonderful places to eat nearby so a mid-morning followed by a great Czech Lunch is a great way to take in this sight.

Very impressive, decorated in Alhabmbra style. It's really impressive, but somehow, in a strange way, it resembles a mosque, most probably becauseit was decorated in the spanish Alhambra town style. There is an exhibition of the Jewish community which boast rare books and print. Quite interesting. Try going up the stairs to the first floor.
Totally different than the other. Wow, what an amazing space. They also have some tables up stairs with history of what happened to the Jews from there in WW II.

Amazing architecture. Spanish Synagogue was one of our visits and we were speechless. It's architecture is completely brilliant and beautiful, I couldn't help myself of taking lots of pictures, just before to see the synagogue you can spot Franz Kafka monument too.Very worth a visit around the Jewish quarters, the buildings are simply fascinating!
Very nice and beautiful. We went there only a few moments. Very nice and beautiful synagoge. When you visit the jews quarter, definitely visit this one!

Beautiful Building. On the 8th June, our party of 10, visited a classical music concert and the Spanish Synagogue and it was excellent. The building itself is stunning and it added to the ambience of the music we were listening to. Well worth a visit whether to a concert or to view the beauty of the building. A visit thoroughly enjoyed by 10 adults. Angie (Doncaster)

Totally worth the visit. Of all the places visited in the Jewish quarter, this is by far the most beautiful. The architecture is completely different to the others and the details and decoration are amazing.

A Beautiful Place. Stunning interior. Interesting part of the Jewish Museum Tour. There are also concerts given in the evenings which you can attend, however, there are charges for them. Worth a visit!!!

Beautiful. A stunning building and the history is interesting if you take the time to read it. The pricing was a little unclear and you have to pay to take photos. We just bought postcards that show the interior.

Beautiful intricately decorated interior. Spanish Synagogue is included in the price of the Jewish Museum ticket (we got a 300Kc ticket good for 7 days and 6 sites, but did not include the New Old Synagogue - that cost extra). Spanish Synagogue is very intricately decorated and is just a beautiful interior. As we are not Jewish, a lot of the significance of some of the displays were a bit lost on us, but I enjoyed it for the beauty of the space. If you have the Jewish Museums ticket it's worth including a visit here.

Highly decorative Synagogue . This synagogue reminded me very much of the mosques in Istanbul - gorgeous mosaics, arches, domes, gilt etc. it's very lovely and well worth visiting. Take a camera. When you are done, stop across the street at V Kolkovna pub for a drink or lunch on their terrace and enjoy this quiet residential street.

Beautiful part of the Jewish Quarter. We visited all the synagogues in the Jewish Quarter and each were as beautiful as the next. Each synagogue had its own unique design and this one had very beautiful interiors.

Very interesting visit. We decided not to go too heavy on the whole Jewish heritage thing (seeing as the week before we came to Prague was Holocaust Remembrance Day in Israel), but we decided not to miss this uniquely designed quite new synagogue. Besides the beautiful interiors, the exhibition there details the last 250 years of Czech Jewish history, which was quite interesting for us both.
Beautiful Old Synagogue. This is a lovely well preserved synagogue. The Spanish influence is strong. It was not an expensive entrance - but there is an entrance fee. We just walked in - no wait.

Amazing Art. Inside the Spanish Synagogue you will see amazing art. Surprisingly, the influence is Arabic with intricate patterns in fences and wall art. Displays show the history of Jews in Prague from 18-20 centuries. Absolutely worth a visit.
Sophisticated.. Small but elegant. The walls and ceiling are dominated by the glamorous patterns. The balcony provides a wonderful view.

Very interesting. I wasn't aware of different synagogues until then! I found it very interesting and beautiful! The guide was amazing, and the whole experience was great and very worthwhile! It was a beautiful building, with so much history! So worth a visit!

An Incredible Feast for the Eyes and the Mind. The entry, rather nondescript in comparison to Franz Kafka sculpture several meters away, does little to impress. That changes almost immediately upon entering the synagogue. My eyes were drawn first to the high walls ascending to the ornate ceiling and skylight (the heavens as it were), and in any direction, spectacular beauty simultaneously adorns what is a reverent place. Along the walls are cases containing texts, historical documents, scripture and the personal items and stories of past members of Prague's Jewish community, gradually revealing the history of the Jewish experience in Prague over the coarse of many centuries, a tale recited in a subtle and somber, yet factual manner. A trip upstairs reveals artifacts that may be considered the "Treasury" of the synagogue and local Jewish community - a fine, and extensive, collection of mostly silver items relevant to the synagogue, its religious rites & celebrations, its rabbis, and its congregants. The gold and silver evident throughout, however, did not appear to represent decadence or wealth; it related, at least to me, the respect and reverence that the community had for its church, it's leaders, and its place of worship - a symbolic offering. I left impressed, and educated. See how you interpret it !!!

Gorgeous interior and interesting exhibits. We visited this synagogue as part of the combination ticket to the Jewish quarter. The interior of this synagogue was truly beautiful, such intricate geometrical pattern, rich colors and gold leaf. My husband's maternal ancestors were Jews that emigrated from Slovakia, but came through Prague, so we were touched by everything we saw here. Strongly recommend buying the full ticket and seeing all you have time to see, it's worth it.

One of a kind. This is a stunningly beautiful synagogue, with every inch covered in ornate designs unlike anything you would typically see in a synagogue. The style is Moorish and, in some ways, the exterior looks more like a mosque. They have concerts in the synagogue and, if you get a chance, definitely go. The sound quality is amazing and the setting is sublime.

Spectacular. We visited the synagogue after seeing photos online and it was well worth the admission fee. The sheer quality of the decoration was breathtaking. It was darker than shown in photos but perhaps there weren't as many lights on that day

Stunning example of Synagogue!. We did this as part of the Jewish Museum ticket. Highly recommend buying the ticket that gets you into 4-5 synagogues, the cemetery. This particular synagogue is amazing. It's stunning interior and informative displays make it one stop not-to-miss in Prague.
Wow!. If you visit Prague, this is a "must", it is beautiful and full of history. You will be fascinated with this construction

nothing to say about it. I visited here right after st. vitus so it seems average to me in the meaning of magnificence but I am not an expert on the sinagogues and this is the only one I have seen so far.

May be the Most Beautiful Synagogue in Europe. We visited the Jewish Quarter thanks to Philip, the remarkable guide of the Sandeman's Prague Free Tour.He told us a lot about the History of the Jews and the Jewish quarter and strongly recommended us to come back and visit it more thoroughly.And so we did the day after and visited the Jewish Quarter and its Spanish Synagogue.Well the name says it all.The Style is definitely Spanish ... or should I say ... Moorish.When you remember that Spain was conquered by the Omayyad and occupied till the middle ages no wonder the style is so Moorish .. .and it is beautiful.From outside the synagogue is not tempting at all.But when you get inside ... Wow ... just Wow !The walls are completely covered with gold and red ornaments and the scene is remarkable.As usual in my reviews, I have attached pictures so you can build your opinion without relying only on this review (subjective as it always is)This is probably one of the most if not the most beautiful synagogue of Europe and it would be a pity to miss this superb piece of Art and Architecture.
Very impressive !. It was very impressive and beautiful... An amazing architecture full of history and culture.. Highly recommended for everybody.. It is one of the best place to visit in Prague.
Highly recommended. The building is very beautiful and the exhibition is interesting. This is the most impressive building in the Jewish quarter.
Amazing interior!. From the outside, you couldn't imagine how beautiful this synagogue is. While not as large as the cathedral or other churches, it is exquisitely ornate.

Beautiful. This synagogue should not be missed on any visit to Prague.It is a short walk from the other synagogues visited on most tours but it beautiful and provides information panels which were most interesting.
beatiful worth seeing. but if you take a jewish old town trip, take this one as last. otherwise, the remaining temples will not be as interesting as they should be.
Spanish Sinagogue. you will see traces of the Alhambra palace both in the exterior and the interior. also you will have an idea about the culture and the education of the Jews in Praha. gotta visit

Surprisingly beautiful. The Spanish Synagogue is the one I liked the most with his Moorish style: the decoration cover all the walls and reminded me - forgive me the comparison - a mosque.around the balcony there was an exhibition of History of Jews in Moravia and Bohemia: collection of pictures, documents and books belonged to Jews that lived the tragic experience of deportation.

Stunning!!!. I am amazed this survived the Holocaust and Communism. And, so grateful! This is a beautiful building and the displays are well documented and thought out. A must see for ANY history buff, not only if you are Jewish.

Beautiful and best place for evening concerts. We went to a concert here for only 25 euros. The inside is simply amazing with wonderful acoustics. A great way to see history on the inside and enjoy a low cost concert at the same time. Highly recommended.

Stunning - a masterpiece. If you visit one synagogue this should be it. Although small it is beautiful. The decorations echo Spanish art with inlaid decorations, wall frescos and gilded ceilings. We listed to a concert here and the sounds was marvellous providing avery poignant memory - worth the visit

Beautiful place. From all the synagogues in the Jewish neighborhood this was by far the most beautiful. Must visit!It is included in the Jewish Museum ticket.As any synagogue you can't visit on Fridays afternoon or Saturdays due to Shabbat.

Guided tour. My family recently visited Jewish Quarter on a private tour with Anna Kristyna Sion.She was professional, enthusiastic and her knowledges are vast. We visited all synagogues, cemetery and museums in this beautiful area. Anna provided us with many interesting explanations and enough of time to see all exhibitions without rush.Highly recommending her!
Beautiful work and location.. I made a tour of all the synagogue except the Old New Synagogue, and I found this one most attractive. I liked their works and the location of it.

A concert in Moorish Spain???. It was restored and redone in Moorish Revival Style and billed as the most beautiful synagogue in Europe. Wouldn't know but after attending a classical concert by quintet and soprano, I'd be willing to believe it. The evening was a treat for the eyes and the ears! Concerts are held there regularly. Google the schedule for Prague's concert season to see if there'll be one at the synagogue while you are in town. A real treat!
So beautiful!. We had the pleasure of seeing this wonderful synagogue by day and attending a concent at night. The mosaics were truly beautiful and the acoustics were extremely good.

So beautiful - and still a living place of worship. If you are Jewish and in Prague for Shabbat this is the place to be. the historic building brings us to worship in a place that was until not so long ago in a world we could not visit. The building is well-maintained as is the rest of the Jewish Quarter.But take your time and see the Pinkus and Klausen and Maesel Synagogues too though these are all now museums.

A visit worth a thousand words. The Spanish synagogue is one of the best keep secrets in the world. it is meticulously maintained. Visiting the Jewish quarter is a must in Prague and this is all part of the experience.

very interesting. This was the only synagogue we visited so I couldn't say if it's the most important. I found the displays and information very interesting and it would perhaps be a good idea to combine it with one of the concerts they give there.

Amazing art. The Spanish Synagogue is maybe one of the newest synagogues in Prague. The decorations inside are awesome. You can also see in the second floor photos and original text from holocaust victims. Worth a visit
You find yourself in another world. Spanish synagogue is a part of the Prague Jewish museum. Take your time for the visit and learn about the Jewish history of Praha

AND NOW FOR SOMETHING COMPLETELY DIFFERENT. A Spanish/Moorish/Czech/Jewish Synagogue; whatever, it demands to be seen. Loud, garish, out of place, it is an unusual bulding with a spectacularly different interior; highly gilded, ornate and beautiful in an outlandish Art Nouveau-ish way. This houses another museum, also interesting.

If you only every visit one Synagogue in your life, make it this one.. So beautiful and the history is both amazing and full of emotion. The people of Prague have preserved this stunning place and I would recommend a visit to experience the atmosphere and read all about the people who have worshipped there. A real education and I am so glad that I went there. I have never been in a Synagogue before and am glad that this one was my first.

Strangely Beautiful. We visited all of the Synagogues whilst in Prague and whilst it is disturbing to understand what people went through during WW11 it is also an interesting and informative journey.

Amazing decoration. This is the first synagogue we've been in and it was magnificent to see. It was beautifully decorated and very ornate. We visited this with a ticket giving entry to many of the other buildings in the Jewish quarter. A must visit.

Evening music performance was excellent.. The synagogue with its Moorish decorative interior style was actually constructed in the 1800's. The Sephardic Jewish community in Prague worship here. The marvelous interior has been described often in Tripadvisor reviews; however, I want to point out that my wife and I enjoyed the evening music performance here far more than those presented in the Mirror Chapel or St. Clement's. Obviously, this is a matter of taste. The program on any given evening is not limited to 'classical' or 'opera' selections: Bach, Mozart, Rossini, Verdi, etc, but includes works by Bernstein, Gershwin, Cohen, etc. It was a marvelous mix and I must say that the soprano ( a Ms. Srumova, I believe) was fantastic. The venue is about a 10 minute walk from the Old Town Square. We would visit again,

Impressive but rather small. It's an impressive synagogue, which has two levels: the lower and main level and the user part, where women (used to) sit. It has unique architecture which reflects the roots and background of those who build it.In addition, there are small displays of various artifacts.Note that like in many of Prague's monuments this synagogue charges an entry fee.

A great way to explore the Jewish history in Prague. We bought the cheaper tickets for the Jewish museum so we weren't able to go in the Old Synagogue. We spent about 3 hours wandering through all the exhibitions and learning about the Jewish history in Prague. The Spanish synagogue was by far one of the favorites. On the ground and upper level are display cases with personal affects from people who lived during the holocaust. The building itself is breathtaking with the elaborate attention to detail. I highly recommend taking a peak inside!

Gold leaf galore. Easy to find and a stunning building with fabulous detail. No problems with photos inside. It's advisable to purchase a 'Full Pass' to all the Jewish sights because it soon saves you money. Lots of info. around the walls of the building and a calm, cool atmosphere inside.

Beautiful Music -- Important and Informative Exhibits. Excellent sound; beautiful geometry. Important to read through the historical exhibits also. The musical program we attended covered a wide variety of music.
Most gorgeous synagogue. Listened to a lovely Bizet and others concert in this extraordinary setting. They have concerts most days - only time you can also use your camera inside!
Beautiful. This synagogue is amazing! I recommend buying the pass to see all the synagogues in the Jewish Quarter. It is truly worth it!
A unique place. A marvelous place with unique architecture. I think there is no place like this in the whole Europe. Astonishing!

Just too beautiful to describe.. The Nazi's desecrated the synagogue turning it into a stable.Fortunately, the communists allowed the synagogue to be totally restored and it is exquisite.It reminded me of the great cathedrals in both its size and it's splendor. They have guided tours in many languages.
Marvellous architecture. A magical place with breathtaking interior. Amazing, beautiful paintings on the walls and ceiling. You can admire this for hours!
A beautiful synagogue. The sefardim news did build a beautiful place of praying, we where impressed, have not seen many old synagogues as beautiful as this one
Spanish Synagogue - Very ornate & Impressive. The Spanish Synagogue was the most impressive of all of the synagogues as far as ornateness. It's well worth the visit.

Very Beautiful Synagogue . Really nice and very intricate place. The details and the painting as well as the stained glass windows is something else. Really beautiful and worth the cost to enter. Was 70 Czk. The history they exhibit upstairs is also worth seeing as well as the view from the second floor.Definitely recommend it.

good looking synagogue but not worth the price of admissin. a lot of really beautiful and ornate woodwork in here. beautifully done. but admission requires a ticket that costs about $15 (and includes five other sites including the jewish cemetery) and it's just not worth that. I wouldn't recommend it for the cost

The most beautiful synagogue in Europe. This was a breathtaking building. The fact that it survived b/c Hitler was going to use it as part of a museum to an extinct race makes the visit even more poignant. This is a rare gem, considering the vast majority of Synagogues in Europe were destroyed by the Nazis.

Beautiful. We thought this synagogue was beautiful. The history was also interesting. Do the total synagogue visit including all the other ones in the area. They are all very close to each other and worth a visit. You have to buy a ticket to see them all.

Amazing experience. Many incredible things have been written about the beauty and amazing architecture of this synagogue. A must to see and experience. But if you really want an everlasting memory, book tickets to an evening classical concert held in the synagogue.The four of us had the pleasure of attending a Hallelujah concert last month and were blown away by the ambiance, the acoustics and the sheer beauty of the music- the horn player and the female vocalist unbelievable- a must see ( and hear ).

Absolutely Brillinat. One of the most ornately beautiful and architecturally impressive buildings i have ever seen. You should keep time to visit this place. Try to do in the early afternoon so you can peacefully enjoy the beauty. If you book the tour, this is usually one of the last ones to visit when you do not have enough time left. Keep that in mind.
WoW!!!!!!. Simply amazing!!!! You must take a tour of the Jewish Quarter. You will love it!!! So much history!!!

A different and amazing building in Jewish area. Isolated from the other Jewish monuments, this synagogue is really impressive. The interior is built in a special style (Moorish revival) and its not so usual to see this kind of style. Really beautiful, bright and warm colors. To see of course.

Amazing bulding, a must see in Prague!. This fabulous building, built in Moorish Revival Style, is really incredible. What a beautiful building. The builders really outdid themselves. When in Prague, I highly recommend taking the time to see this Synagogue.

A synagogue out of the ordinary . The Spanish Synagogue is something quite different from the other synagogues we visited. The whole main room is covered with beautifull shapes in many different colors. It is a part of the jewish museum, and the ticket also includes three other synagogues so you get your moneys worth.
Spectacular interior. This restored synagogue has displays of Jewish life in the Czech Republic from the late 1880's until about 1950.

very moving. Not being a history buff, I found it interesting that the Spanish synagogue was in the Jewish quarter. That being said, there is a lot of history inside the building and definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful Synagogue . This is definitely the most beautiful synagogue in Prague that Hubby and I saw. It is also the youngest synagogue in the "Jewish section"; built in 1869.. It is not an active synagogue and is administered by the Jewish Museum association. It is breath-taking and a must see. It is located very close to the oldest practicing synagogue in Europe, the Old New synagogue. I recommend visiting this museum.
Our first Synagogue. Except for the architecture this synagogue has no ties to Spain. Very beautiful and worth seeing the exhibitions. An hour visit is more than sufficient.

Startling. Well worth a visit. Didn't expect it to be so richly decorated. We purchased a ticket which covered the cemetery and other sights around the Jewish quarter. It was fascinating and very moving.

Imposing synagogue. In my personal opinion the Spanish Synagogue distinguishes from the rest of Jewish synagogues in Prague; its interior decoration is imposing; this place is also used for concerts as well as other types of exhibitions. A must-see when visiting the Josefov neighborhood in Prague..
A magnificent building. This historical Synagogue is one of the most beautiful rooms anywhere in Europe - the commitment to its renovation and upkeep is wonderful - a visit is highly recommended

A very beauutiful synagogue.. Prague's old Jewish Area, comprised of about 5 buildings and the old cemetery, are very interesting to visit. A huge number of Jews were eliminated by the Nazi's in World War II and approximately 2,000 of the original 180,000 Jews remain.

Absolutely breath-taking. Ornate, detailed and simply amazing hidden gem. Exterior looks very simple but as you as you enter you are hit by its mesmerisingly crafted decorated ceiling, walls and glass windows
Stunning. This is by far one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. It has a great exhibit on the history of Jews in Prague, all under a gorgeous site.

Breathtaking synagogue . This was by far one of the most beautifully designed synagogues I visited in Europe. It is quite different from the common cathedrals, which makes synagogues unique. It is not a very big building, however each little detail is amazingly detailed and well preserved. I highly recommend visiting this amazing synagogue.
Spanish Synagogue. a lot of exhibition on Jewish and holocauststill the names of the prayers on the chairs the famous flagjust the way the Jewish left the place

Sorry But.... This beautiful Spanish Synagogue does an excellent job marketing their concerts and it is easy to buy tickets on-line which is good to do if you want to attend a concert since the seating is very limited . I did just that and then eagerly anticipated the Gershwin concert which I would be attending .I agree with everyone about the beauty of the interior of this sanctuary . It's moorish style is very similar to the Central Synagogue in Manhattan . However the concert itself was disappointing . There were 5 musicians whom seemed to be going through their paces without any enthusiasm . Their renditions of the popular Gershwin songs was nothing special and exactly 60 minutes after they started they were finished . Yes applause brought them back for one more song . Twenty six USD seems expensive to me for such a short concert in Prague . Although I was quite happy to contribute to the financial well bring of this Synagogue I feel that in a city like Prague where wonderful music seems to ooze out of every corner of the city , this concert should have had some passion .
Opulent. After visiting the older synagogues, the Spanish synagogue seems very over the top. It is very ornate and has a small museum within. The views from the balcony are excellent.

Nice but not something special!. The most beautiful from the rest of the synagogues I have been in Prague but nothing special. Additional, there was no free entry in any of the synagogues contrary to all other churches.

Stunning Interior. It's well worth the visit to see the stunning interior of the Spanish Synagogue. Every surface seems to be highly (and symbolically) decorated--the ceilings, walls, pillars...in addition to the beautiful stained glass windows.
