Along the walls both upstairs and downstairs are a variety of glassed in displays. There is also an impressive silver exhibit upstairs.

Beautiful Synagogue!!. It's an intimate Synagogue with a gorgeous interior. Of all the buildings on the Jewish Museum tour this was my first and favorite. Be sure and climb the stairs to the balcony and get a view of the organ and the windows.
Easter in Prague. Fantastic and fascinating. Well worth a visit. Historical and a reminder of what was and what could have been had the Nazis not intervened so brutally
The nicest synagogue in town. This is the nicest synagogue in town, at least from the inside. It is not very expensive to get in. Make sure you get up to the second floor for exhibit.
Spine tingling. We attended a concert in the Spanish Synagogue. It was simply beautiful an intimate venue so the acoustics were brilliant. The synagogue itself is breath taking.

Very nice synagogue. It is a smal but very beautiful synagogue. The details on the walls and the chandelier are stunning. It was not crowded, we could admire it as long as we wanted and also we could take photos. It is a nice visit! The only downside was that you cannot pay with a credit card the entrance fee.
Beautiful. This is an amazing place to go through although it is not as amazing as other synagogues in the city. Make the time to take a guided or self guided tour.
Totally stunning . The synagogue looks amazing, all golden, the most beautiful I have ever seen. Upstairs there is a museum for Jewish history.

Beautiful. Best attraction of the Jewish Museum. We bought the combined tickets to see all Jewish museum attractions and this was the best one. You can take photos but without flash or tripod. One of the most beautiful walls I've ever seen. The entrance is beside Franz Kafka's sculpture. Buy tickets online to skip lines.
Stunnibg. The Spanish Synagogue is a stunning moorish revival style synagogue in the Jewish town of Prague. It is well worth a visit for anyone interested in architecture, history and/or Judaism.

Stunning Synagogue. We bought tickets at the Jewish Centre which covered a number of sites in the area, this was one of the sites covered. The interior is spectacular and there are cabinets explaining history of Jews, very interesting. We visited around noon and it was very busy especially with school groups

Beautiful Example. Of all the sights within the Jewish Museum, this is definitely the most lavish. I appreciated this one more than the others (with one exception) solely because of the decor. Not being of a religious persuasion, I have always found the interior of religious buildings to be either outstandingly dull OR stunningly opulent.

Beautiful synagogue, where also non-Jews can go for service . I really liked the architecture. Also the fact that this synagogue is not orthodox, men and women can sit together. Also people of non Jewish religion can see the service.

Special history tour. If you're interested in the history of the central-eastern Europe, you'll find here not only a beautiful building but - thanks to the exhibition - a great opportunity of a special time travel.

Gorgeous Synagogue with lots of history. There is museum exhibit upstairs. Buy your tickets at the tourist center in the jewish quarter They are good for the whole quarter and for five or seven days . Definitely worth a visit.

A beautiful Synagogue. This is immaculate and beautifully decorated. Try and get there when there are few tourists - early is probably best. There's so much information to read inside it is all fascinating and very moving too. The story of the Jews could be any of us at any time. Well worth visiting.

Exceptional!. Said to be the most beautiful synagogue in Europe, this 19th century church building in the Jewish Quarter of Prague has a fairly nondescript facade which does not do justice to its exquisite interior. While not a huge structure, the synagogue has a large dome above its nave and there are overhanging galleries on the sides. The walls are all covered with shiny gold motifs which give the place an incredibly opulent look . For an entrance fee of 70CZK, it is well worth the money to appreciate the architecture and the exceptional interior decor.
Stunning !. Def worth making this top of your sight-seeing list. The Synagogue is so incredibly beautiful, we were completely awestruck.

Simply spectacular!. The intricate work on the walls, the dome, the ceiling of this synagogue in Prague is simply spectacular. Take your time inside the synagogue to admire its beauty, as well as to understand the history of Jews in Prague (and more broadly, in the Czech Republic).

Breathtaking. From the outside you wouldn't believe whats inside..it's so beautiful, everything is golden and just magical. They are also some exhibits to show the jewish history in and around Prague. The Synagogue is close to the old town square and for me it's one of the must-see's in Prague. Highly recommend it
Beautiful synagogue. Very pretty synagogue, the nicest I have seen so far. Plus the place has a very interesting history.
Beautiful. Nothing less!. We went there for a concert. The synagogue is a marvel. Beautiful architecture, great acoustics. Really a must visit place while in Prague.

Beutiful, Ornate, and Historic. The Spanish Synagogue is simply beautiful inside and well worth a visit. A self guided visit will allow you to take it all in, and there are many display cases along the sides of the synagogue (on both floors) that tell the history of the people who worshipped here over the centuries, but a guided tour is really better. Every surface is exquisitely painted, lending a sense of awe and vastness. Don't miss the large silver collection on the second floor, off to the left as you go up the stairs.You can also visit by attending one of the regularly held evening concerts, though you would have less opportunity to wander about. The surrounding area, the Josefov, is the high end shopping district, and it is all just a short walk north of the Old Town Square. The history of the area is fascinating, and if you are fortunate enough to take a guided tour in this section of town, there is much to hear.
stunning. went to a short concert in the Spanish Synagogue , could have sat there all night listening ,such acoustics in such a poignant building
Concert in the synagogue. The music was delightful and the setting gorgeous! We grabbed a bite to eat next door. I had a beet Gorgonzola pear salad. Delicious!

I thought it was bigger.... Very impressive architecture and hand-painted decorations inside. Consists in 2 floors; 1st being where most of the people would sit to hear the mass (open space with few historical documents in display), the 2nd featuring a small exhibition about Prague's jewish ghetto, saved objects from the 2WW confiscation, the reform of the community and mention of few famous artists active during the same era. There is 2 small bathrooms on the 2nd floor and a small shop near the entrance.
Churches. All that we seen have got beautiful architecture.paintings grand you could sit for as long as and still not seen all
Golden. of all of the Synagogues, it is the most ornate. Get a good tour guide or do some research before you go. It's not self explanatory as to its importance.
Amazing architecture. Really great architecture which gives great photo opportunities. Very beautiful inside and was not very busy when we there.
Outstanding Synagougue. The Synagogue is extremely beautiful and not to be missed on your visit. I will recommend the whole Jewish Quarter where this Spanish Synagogue is also included in the visit.
Kfka and the Golem. Full of history and human drama. You have to go there if you want to understand Kafka and... the golem !
Impressive!. This is quite a place to visit. Wonderful architecture and atmosphere and an impressive collection of artefacts. Beautiful place.

Almost unbelievably gorgeous and best exhibits. Not only is this the prettiest of the 5 synagogues available on the same ticket, it also includes the most poignant description of what happened as Prague Jews were relocated to ghettos, and then of course concentration camps. The audio guides are worth getting if you do the tour of multiple synagogues. If you only go to one synagogue this is the one to see, although the Old New is a close second due to its history.
Really intersesting and beutiful. The whole Jewish quarter is worth a visit. The history is fascinating and also very sad. This synagogue is very ornate and has exhibits inside.
A dream. The Jerusalem Synagogue is an example of an Art Nouveau stylisation of a Moorish design, and an example of synagogual architecture of the Austrian-Hungarian Empire.

Czech Collegium ensemble. We went here for a concert of classical and contemporary music. It was fantastic. The Czech Collegium ensemble played for an hour and the music was wonderful. It appealed to everyone and was very entertaining. The synagogue is a magnificent building and a great venue for this type of concert. The acoustics were brilliant, the whole thing was a unique experience.

Stunningly beautiful. Not a particularly large synagogue but an absolutely beautiful building. Currently not active as a synagogue but is instead part of the Jewish Museum tour. Also hosts a one-hour classical music performance a couple of times a week, which also showcases the excellent acoustics of the building. A must-see.
Classical Music evening. Went to hear a fabulous 1 hour concert of classical music at this venue, you can buy tickets outside the synogogue during the day. You can negotiate the price!

Stunning Building. We visited this building after visiting of the rest of the synagogues and the Jewish cemetery. It is a stunning building which is full of intricacies of artwork and pattern. Information about the writers and others who were persecuted during WW11 was sobering but fascinating.
Very Moving. A beautiful place. the lists of names of those that died during the holocaust painted on the walls really brings home the tragedy and counterpoised by a beautiful historic building.
Stunning. Definitely the most beautiful synagogue in the Jewish quarter, and a highlight of the Jewish Museum tour. Come for the architecture, stay for the exhibits.

WOW!!. Since the renovation, this is no doubt one of the highlights of our old Jewish heritage tour.Great atmosphere and feeling of history. We also attended a concert in the synagogue which proved a great thing to do with the amazing acoustics.
Just wonderful. Loads of artefacts around Orthodox Jewish culture, most interesting and informative. We also went to a concert here in the evening, fantastic!

Beautiful place. In my opinion that is the most beautiful Synagogue in Prague. Also lot of displays describing the history of the Jews in Czech Republic. The ticket cost 70 czech korunabut it is worth without any doubt.

Go early. Beautiful synagogue on the inside. It's smaller than the photographs you see in guide book, but definitely worth a visit. Go early in the morning so you can enjoy it without crowds. We arrived at 9:00 AM in February and there was only one other family there. We bought the tickets and began our tour of the Jewish Quarter here, which is a great choice as by the time we got to the other synagogues the lines for tickets were quite long despite it being an off-season.

Very Impressive. The Spanish Synagogue was the most impressive Synagogue in Prague in my opinion. So ornate inside, it really was breathtaking. Very well laid out information points, detailing the history of the Synagogue and the Jewish commiunity. Would definitely recommend as part of the Synagogue tour ticket.

Incredible atmosphere for early evening concert. Spent two evenings out of our 4 night stay at the one hour concerts that start at 17:30. Incredible musicians, amazing atmosphere. Before and after the music looked at the exhibits in the synagogue which related the history of the Czech Jewish community. Such a different way to spend an early evening, thoroughly recommend.

CONCERT IN SPANISH SYNAGOGUE. This amazing venue in the Jewish Quarter of Prague was easy to find. The concert was over subscribed and extra seats had to be found. The building is beautifully decorated and maintained with a very historic vibe.The Hallelujah concert was a wonderful mix of classical music and modern music with a classical theme, expertly performed by a string quintet accompanied by a classical trumpeter and soprano all drawn from Prague city's outstanding orchestras.We fully intend to revisit in 2017 when next in Prague.

Stunning!. Wife and I attended a string concerto recently at this glorious Temple. We were moved by the Holocaust exhibit upstairs which is simple but well conceived. The Temple itself justifies it's tag as the most beautiful in Europe. Well worth a visit.

The most beautiful synagogue in Prague. Spanish Synagogue is the youngest one of all the other ones situated in t former Jewish District, but the most beautiful one. Built in 1868 as the synagogue of reform judaism, it looks different from the traditional synagogues. There is even organ and almost every night there are concerts. The place has awesome acoustics, so for music lovers good to visit.Synagogue hosts permanent exhibition of the history of Czech Jews since late 18th century until post WWII. But built in Spanish -Maurish style, it is a jewel of architecture by itself. Although the exterior is not so stunning, when you enter it you can 't help yourself to say: WOW!
Beautiful. The Spanish Synagogue is the most impressive of Prague's synagogues visually. A must visit when in Prague.

Amazing!. Amazing cathedral with a museum over the jew's history. Really worth seeing. Just be aware that women should cover their shoulders (the staff at the cathedral offer a piece of cloth to cover them if you don't come prepared) and men must wear the kippah (offered by the staff).
beautiful and with nice concerts. maybe one of the most beautiful and rich synagogues. nice from outside and inside. it offers great concerts in this unique environement.

Historic context. One can hardly visit Prague and ignore it's Jewish heritage, best is to buy a ticket that allows entry into a number of Synagogue as well as the Jewish Museum and graveyard and allow at least 3 hours, I particularly enjoyed visiting this very atmospheric building.

Superb Building. The exterior of this building does not prepare you for the magnificent interior. The Synagogue is Moorish in design and its golden design is opulent. We stared in awe at the beauty of this Synagogue. We were privileged to attend a concert in this wonderful building. We were treated to works by Mozart, Vivaldi and Rossini among others and songs from Leonard Bernstein and George Gershwin. The acoustics in the Synagogue were brilliant. After the concert which lasted a little over an hour we looked in the glass cases to admire some of the treasures. What a wonderful evening. This was my favourite concert and venue of those I attended in Prague.

Lovely Music Concert in Spanish Synagogue.. Really enjoyed the Gershwin/Musical variety show with a six piece chamber orchestra in the Synagogue. The venue is really atmospheric and the ornate decoration is well worth a look. You might need a cushion as the wooden pews are a little hard to sit on for an hour.

Beautiful and emotional. I've been to the synagoge for a concert, which was unbelievebly moving, the beautiful music and the synagoge itself. As an israely, it was very emotional for me to visit there and the whole jewish quartor. totally a "must" site.
Worth the visit. My favorite synagogue in Prague, if there would be only one, this should be your visit, system of ticket is not very Easy though but that the game in tourist places

Exquisite architecture, interesting artifacts.. Very glamorous synagogue with Granada style of architecture. Absolutely worth a visit. Please pay the respect as visitor and avoid flash photography. Some youngsters think that everything is allowed...
Beautiful. Worth the visit if you do nothing other than go in to see the incredibly beautiful interior of the synagogue. Pictures don't quite do it justice.

Highlight of the Jewish Quarter - A must see!. This is a beautiful and ornate synagogue, easily the most beautiful in the Jewish Quarter. They are all worth seeing, but this one stands out. The decorations are beautiful, and it is easy to spend an hour or two in there, especially for photographers!. A must see when in Prague

Good end to the Jewish Quarter tour. We bought the tickets for the combined Jewish Quarter self guided tour. It was 300 Kc for an adult and 200 for a student. The Spanish Synagogue is a definite highlight of the tour as it's really beautiful. It is relatively new as it was built only in 1868. The name Spanish comes from the fact that it was inspired by the Spanish Alhambra.

Must Visit when in Prague. One of many sinagogues in Prague, in the Jewish and Ghetto Quarter. A Must do activity, principally for the stile and work in wood, the ornaments and wonderful work made one of the nicest ever seen by me in my 52 years jew life ! Recommended ! In the second floor you have an exhibition of jewish life and ornaments from czech community in the long years before the

Breathtaking. One of the half-dozen synagogues in the Jewish Quarter of Prague. it's by far the most impressive in terms of the decor. Very much worth an hour or two of your time, with very well displayed history of the Jewish history of the city.A guide will give you an orientation to the area and then it's well worth paying the entrance to the Jewish Museum which will give you entry to the main centres of the Quarter, Allow a few hours if this is in anyway of interest to you, and allow time to reflect and absorb on the tragic but fascinating history of Jewish people, not just in Prague but in all of central Europe.
Incredible visit. This was a beautiful synagogue and we enjoyed learning the history of this landmark. We actually even went back for services on Friday. Incredible experience.

Architectural and historic delight. The building has nothing to do with the Sephardic Jews of Spain but should be taken as a 19th century homage to what is now perceived as a golden age of Judaism in Spain during the Moorish occupation of Iberia. The interior is a delight to behold, combining moorish elements with traditional Jewish sacral architecture whilst showcasing a short history of Judaism in Prague, much of it is naturally talking about the holocaust and the deportation of jewish citizens under the Nazi occupation of the city.Should not be missed on any Prague itinerary.

Absolutely stunning!. This synagogue was absolutely stunning! I'm so glad that I was able to see this lovely building. The synagogue itself has been turned into a museum detailing the life of Pragues Jewish citizens within the last few centuries. The museum is absolutely fascinating and I highly recommend this exhibit and building for anyone who either wants to see a beautiful building OR a wonderful exhibit.
Interesting Visit. Very nice synagogue. Richly decorated but is more a museum than a place of worship. It served as a warehouse during the Second World War for all confiscated property.

Incredible interior, wonderful exhibits. First off all, keep in mind that the ticket for the Jewish Quarter is good for SEVEN DAYS. You have an entire week to see all the sites included in the price of the ticket. As for the synagogue, it's spectacular. By far the coolest interior of any the religious sites we visited. The walls and ceiling are something to behold, the organ is incredible to see, and to top it all off, there are very well done exhibits on folks like Kafka on the second floor. Well worth the visit, and as part of the entire Jewish Quarter, well worth the price of admission.

A museum cannot be missed. The Spanish Synagogue is the most worthing visiting one among several synagogues around. Besides it is very nice golden decorated, the content part is the most important and interesting. It is a museum of the Jewish community in Bohemia region, from around 18th century to current. Very educational and informative.
Beautiful interior. In sharp contrast to the Old-New Synagogue, Moorish-style interior of the Spanish Synagogue is not be missed. It makes a fitting end to a self-guided tour of the Jewish Quarter.

Don't miss the Jewish Quarter. We purchased a ticket to see the entire Jewish Quarter, with the museum, the old cemetery and the Synagogues. This Synagogue is by far the most beautiful I have ever seen. The decorations are wonderful and you can stare at them for ages. The exhibition was also really good, although we enjoyed the architecture more. Quite an impressive building, in and out.
Fabulous interior. If you have a chance to visit, do. There are regular concerts playing, not bad, but maybe visitors can access some other way.

A small, modest and beautiful building, I would recommend a visit.. Prague has so many phenomenal churches as it is, but you're going to feel a bit worn out from seeing them all.I would really recommend adding this to your itinerary.. It is geometrically beautiful and gives a strong insight into Jewish life in Prague and the Czech Republic.
A moving experience. Well worth a visit, inside is stunning. I'm not Jewish or even religious, but I found the information available very informative.

Fabuous ceiling in this synogogue. Part of the Jewish information centre list of 8 Jewish places to visit. This Paradise Hampstead49 South End RoadHampsteadLondon NW3as the only mpressi e building our of 4 synogogues. Orhers were more informative.

Beautiful and historic. No trip to Prague would be complete without delving into the Jewish history of the city. The Spanish synagogue forms part of the Jewish Museum which is actually a collection of synagogues and the Jewish cemetery as well. The Spanish Synagogue is a dazzler and worth a visit.

Very beautiful intricate building inside. My family and I got our tickets for entry as part of the Jewish Tour. This was the highlight of the attractions offered. We were greeted by a very friendly door lady who spoke multiple languages competently.

The most beautiful Synagoge in Europe. It quite unbelievable that this unspectaculare house from outside have this enormous treasure inside.I dont want to tell too much about my impressions but it needs some time to recognise the fine art what you can find their too.The whole arcitecture ensemble is grandious.And you can find a lot of information about the jewish community in Prague over the centuries.

Perfect pitch. You would never guess from the external view that this was such a beautiful building. Not that I have visited many synagogues but the modern austerity of the facade belies the gem within.The occasion was to listen to a concert during which the pitch of the flugelhorn and soprano achieved a wonderful resonance.

Great Concert. My wife, 2 kids, and 2 relatives listened to a concert here in December 2015. It included Carmina Burana, Bolero, Evita Don't Cry For Me Argentina, Hava Nagila, Carmen, and many others. I returned the next day as part of my tour of the Jewish section of Prague. The synagogue like the other synagogues in Jewish Prague was a very interesting place to visit.

One of the most beautiful buildings in Prague. If you like amazing architecture you have to go there. It's so amazing, full of details and there is an exhibition with Jewish details.In the outside you can't predict what's inside... Definitely recommend it.

Breathtaking. I wasn't sure what to expect before I arrived, especially as the outside is pretty but not amazing. However the inside is absolutely breathtaking. The work and effort that has gone into this can be seen on every wall and ornament. It also has the very interesting history of the enlightenment of Judaism and the transition from orthodox to reform too. Definitely visit!
Stunning Moorish design!. You can visit this synagogue as part of the tour of the old Jewish quarter. It is now one of the Jewish museums.

Prague Highlight. The Spanish Synagogue along with the other sites in the Jewish Museum (which is a collection of sites in the Jewish Quarter) is a must see in Prague. In fact, it's one of the most frequented sites in Prague.All of the sites are beautiful and it's very moving to see the well preserved vestiges of a once vibrant Jewish community.
Concert. The concert was fine, not exactly a "wow" factor but the building is probably one of the beautiful synagogues in Europe.

Beautiful moorish style synagogue . This was our last stop on the Jewish museum tour, I think we saved the best 'til last! Decorated in the moorish style, the Spanish synagogue is simply stunning. A good display of Jewish history in WW2.
A very beautifull place. In terms of art and beauty this is one of the better houses of God around. Definitely worth a peek when in Prague
Nice Architecture & Interesting history. Nice Architecture & Interesting history. It really a grand synagogue. Vey special. 1/2 hour is needed at most.
Very imprassive. The inside of the synagogue is beutifully decorated. It is a tripartite facade with a tall central section flanked by lower wings on each side. Worth visiting.

Beautiful. The Spanish Synagogue is worth the visit. It´s unique golden colours will blow your mind! However the Jewish pack is quite expense: 300Kc for the Spanish synagogue, the Klausen synagogue, the old jewish cemetery and the ceremonial hall and on the first was worth it

Stunning architecture. For me one of the highlights of our trip was the visit to the Spanish synagogue. The beauty of the interior waa awe inspiring. There are glass cases displayed around the inside of the church telling the story of the Jewish people in that area.
Small, elegant place. It is a nice small synagogue - not sure why is there a ticket to visit this religious place. Okay if you have time, but you won't be missing much if you cannot visit.

An impressive place to visit, a sobering walk through the cemetary. Give yourself some time to absorb the history that surrounded the second World War. I really felt that history here as I did with several other Jewish sites that I visited.
Historic. There is lots of information on site to educate the visitor. It is a small synagogue, but plenty to see. Very beautiful interior, and a permanent silver collection upstairs.
Lovely. Small, dark, but beautiful. Luxurious colors. Worth to visit. I really like it. Little shop also worth to check.
A must see in Prague. This was a wonderful place to visit. We went to an evening concert there and the acoustics were fantastic

Beautiful construction!. Sometime you need to get completed tour for several synagogues, but If not have the time you can get tickets for thes specific one in the entrance approx 30 min, beautiful architecture and lovely Windows.Also some historic photos and text regarding world war.

Concert at the Spanish Synagogue . What and unexpected delight, the musicians and the fantastic singer with the varied choice of classical music made an excellent first day in Prague.Well worth listening to this concert.
History visit. Visited this as a one off. Poor value for what was on display. If visiting the Jewish quarter consider visiting all three sites in package and not this as a single visit

Beautiful. The Spanish Synagogue is a beautiful building. The synagogue is Ashkenszi but the architecture is in a Spanish style. There are 2 levels that you can visit. There are many donated pieces that you can see on the second level as well as display cases showing the history of the Jewish population.
Amazing. When you are outside the building you barely notice it, but once inside...Take your time to see all the details, totaly worth it

The synagogue you cannot miss. Loved it. It is beautiful on the inside. But most of all, there was an exposition related to the history of the jews in the Czech Republic, so interesting. You have to go there when you have enough time to spent at least one hour exploring the exhibition.
Go see a concert. Went to see the Gershwin Concert - very talented musicians in an opulent setting. Go see a concert while taking in the beauty of the Synagogue.

A Place of beauty and humanity. We've there twice - first at an evening classic music concert and 2nd we went the see the beauty and uniwueness of this place. It looks like it sums the Check people spirit - a jewish synagoge which looks and decorate as a mosque and got an Organ

Just Gorgeous!. This might have been the most visually stunning interior in all of Prague. It's absolutely gorgeous! Every surface is covered in beautiful geometric gilded paintings. We visited this synagogue at the end of our walk around the Jewish Quarter and it was the perfect cap to the morning (I would recommend ending with this one, since all the others pale in comparison). One other fun thing upstairs here is a display of shiny gold and silver religious artifacts such as menorahs and Torah ornaments.
Beautiful!. Well worth the visit. Very interesting to see the Moorish/Islamic architectural influence in a synagogue. Same architecture can be seen throughout southern Spain in most all churches.

Make sure you see this one! . This synagogue was well worth a visit it was very informative, covering Jewish History etc., The Synagogue is very impressive/ornate, the best synagogue in the Old Jewish Town, so if you don't want to view all of them then choose this one. We paid at the ticket office next door 3€ ticket included a museum as well which we didn't go to... History overload. You can get tickets that include all of the synagogues, graveyard & memorial Hall plus others with a tour guide which are very informative. It is we worth going to the Jewish quarter plenty to see & if you like religious artefacts/Jewish history you will be in your element!
Great architecture. Only got chacne to see from the outside as there was a xmas concert in full swing and the place was packed, really nice church , good location easy to find
Beautiful. Blown away by this beautiful space. We went to a concert there which was fantastic and very enjoyable but expensive. I highly recommend.

Powerful reminder of man's inhumanity to man.... The artefacts and their associated stories (up in the balcony area) were very moving. This stuff happened within living memory and is a powerful reminder of God's purpose with the Jewish people. Scattered. persecuted, regathered (Deut 28:64-68; Ezek 36:16-28)
Wow. Historical and the most ornate synagogue in Prague. If you are in the Jewish quarter, you must see this

Beautiful. Beautiful synagogue one of several on the Jewish Museum trail.The presentation of history & artefacts in each of the different synagoue's was a wonderful way of understanding the history of the Jewish community in Prague

Absolutely stunning!. This is so beautiful and totally worth seeing. 'Make sure to bring cash to pay your entrance fee with as they do not accept paying by card. You can also buy the ticket online before you go.
beautiful building. A must on the list of Jewish sites. Magnificent building with superb decorations - a true feast for the eyes. Try and attend a concert inside too.
Ok. It was ok not a lot to see and not a lot of information on the synagogue didn't do it for me. wroth it if you get a all in one ticket for the other synagogue
Very cool. It was our first time visiting a Synagogue and it was very interesting, the tours are worth to take as they have many interesting and historical things.

Breathtaking. The synagague is very beautiful. The walls are beautifully designed in gold. There is a classic concert at night which it was the reason we went there. The singer is marvelous so it's the small orchestra. A modest show that will leave you wishing for more. You will be surprised by the quality of music we will enjoy in there.

As part of the Jewish Quarter visit.. Having visited the other attractions, as part of your ticket price, visit this Synagogue, only as it is likely you will leave this building until last, do it before 4-30 pm as an unsmiling security person will usher you out - they close early. The building seems a bit over 'rich ' for a Synagogue, but we'll worth a visit.
Synagogue with a difference. The synagogue has a Moorish style exterior indicating Arab influence in its construction. As it was closed we could not see it from the inside.

Amazing. Lol.. Inside the building is very .. gold. But then you have a lot of history about the Jews from before, during and after war, pictures, letters, documents so its very fascinating. You have notes about poets and other famous people. The best synagogue in Prague for me.
Hidden, but very nice. This sinagogue is an artifact of most refined craftmanship. Its ornaments, combined with gold and cuppolas, have a very special effect. Definitively worh a visit!
Beautiful. This synagogue is beautiful, and incorporates moorish elements of design. It is part of rhte Jewish Museum.
Synagogue you should visit. I am not very fond of Synagogues etc but this one is impressive. Visit it in combination with a concert. Twice as nice !

Very beautiful.. The prettiest synagogue of them all. Part of the Jewish tour. If you only see one synagogue, it has to be this one. There is an interesting sculpture of Franz Kafka, meters from the entrance.
Jewish Ghetto Tour. We stopped by the Spanish Synagogue as part of the Jewish Ghetto Tour. Buy a ticket and see all the sights in the area. It is very well worth seeing.

The most interesting synagogue in theJewish quarter. If you are planning to visit synagogues in the Jewish quarter this is the most beautiful from the architecture point of view. It is unique in its kind with variety of colours and very atmospheric.
Pretty awesome. Well worth a visit on it's own but add the other Jewish attractions and worthwhile. The aritfacts were interesting and the architecture amazing. Such wealth.

Gorgeous Synagogue !!!. This is a Moorish style synagogue, built in 1868. The ark shows an Islamic influence. The Torah ark and central dome are Spanish inspired architecture. The entire interior is simply magical to see! There is a permanent exhibition of Jewish history from the 18th century Enlightment Period to present housed in this building. The synagogue is used strictly as a museum and a concert hall. Be sure to bring your camera!

Nice building many colors. We have been 2 times in Prague and still could not see the interior of this sinagogue. Bare in mind- it is closed in winter until 31 of March and during Easter as well,have no idea if there is something with religion to do. I hope we manage to see it open some day.

stunning. We took a tour of the Jewish Quarter and saw several synagogues. The Spanish Synagogue is gorgeous and golden and has a huge organ. It was my favorite of all. It is a tour not to be missed. Very moving.

Most Beautiful Synagogue in Prague. Aesthetically, this was the nicest synagogue in the Old Jewish Quarter in Prague. There was not much to see in this synagogue besides the bimah and alter which is the main picture here. I enjoyed this one.

Beautiful Synogogue. We hired a guide for a private tour, which included the old Jewish ghetto. In the ghetto stood some synogogues, one of which was still in use, and the others, including this one, are sort of museums.The whole ghetto thing is kind of depressing actually, but so interesting. The reason all these buildings still exist whereas the Nazis destroyed all the other European Jewish reminders is because after they killed all of the European Jews they planned to make the Prague ghetto a museum about a race that no longer existed. Well, I told you it was depressing. The Spanish Synogogue is absolutely beautiful. Even if you aren't particularly interested in Jewish European history, as a building it is absolutely worth seeing.

beautiful place. We didn't have the time for one of the full tours of Jewish Prague, so we took a chance and just visited the Spanish Synagogue. The rich colors of the patterns on the interior walls and ceiling are just beautiful. Many educational artifacts are on display. I do wish we would have had a tour guide to learn more.

Most interesting place. This Synagogue is different than all the others ever seen . Inside you can see a very big exhibition of documents concerning famous Check jews that contributed to humanity and genuine documents related to Second World War , Nazisim ,Antisemitism and Jewdaism .

Magnificent architecture - don't miss. We ended up here after a walking tour of the Jewish Quarter. The interior is stunning and you should not miss any opportunity to visit. If you enjoy classical music, check out performances, it may be you can combine your visit with a concert.

Must-see if you want to understand part of Prague's history. The ticket to the Spanish Synagogue grants you access to other monuments in the jewish quarter (other synagogues, jewish cemetery etc). There is not much left from the original buildings because of several fatal events (fires, destructions, pogroms etc) but they have been renovated and well documented with the history and evolutions of Prague's jews.
Lovely Temple. We visited this lovely Temple while taking a tour of "Jewish Prague" and I really enjoyed this Sephardic Temple although much of it was missing. The Moorish designs were delightful
the Jewish Quarter Tour. We took the Whittman Tour of the Jewish Quarter. They were excellent in their presentation and information. highly recommended..
Great Jewish History Place. A very beautiful interior with lots of displays of the history of Judism in Prague.The interior of the building is amazing.
Prague is more than the famous clock.. Going into the Spanish synagogue was quite an experience. It was like entering another era. It was worth the money we paid for the tickets.

Magnficent building with important history. This beautiful building is a jewel and still in use albeit in a limited way. Attended a concert there one evening and went on a tour on my second visit, really a must see.

The congregation is gone, the beautiful Synagogue remains.. It was so beautiful, that it was difficult to absorb, and even more difficult to finally take my eyes off of it, and remove myself from the surroundings. Could be my strong attraction to the style of architecture. It was part of a ticket that included 6 or 7 sites in the Old Jewish Quarter, remarkably including the 13th century Old-New Synagogue, which is a working synagogue, the old cemetery, and several other synagogues. The other synagogues are museums and concert halls now; not a lot of people to use them after WWII. I didn't know what I was walking into when I entered the Pinkas Synagogue, until I focused my eyes on the pattern on the white walls and felt my breath leave me. In calligraphy the names, birthdates, transport dates, for 78,000 Jews of Bohemia and Moravia. The walls of the entire synagogue were covered in this manner, so to give a different perspective, how many walls, in how large a building, would it take for 6 million names? In summary, the Spanish Synagogue is an architectural gem, but it is just a small part, and a much later part of the story of the Old Jewish Quarter. The visit isn't free, and why should it be? For those who travel to actually see, learn, and appreciate, a visit to the Jewish museums will be an enjoyable and valuable experience. They are museums, they require time and thought. For those who hold up a cell phone, take a photo, and think you've seen something, then go to the next site, and want it all for free, probably you wouldn't enjoy these spaces.
Wonderful architecture and art works to behold. Worth the time to stop in while strolling through old town Prague. Near the Jewish Quarter as well as the Astronomical clock.

Unusual looking synagogue(for Prague). Of course the design is based upon the Moorish buildings of southern Spain and North Africa, apparently I was told by the tour guide that this is a really popular building for Muslim tourists, because of it's incredible similarity to a mosque. It certainly looks that way, and really stands differently amongst the Czech grandeur that surrounds it here in the Jewish quarter, definitely worth a visit.

Gorgeous, Ornate Interior!. Prague's Spanish Synagogue was built in the 1860's and is obviously influenced by Moorish design on the interior. If you've traveled to Granada or Cordoba in southern Spain, you'll recognize the Moorish influence that is also found there. Oddly, however, this synagogue has no particular connection to Spain or Spanish Jews. There is some debate about how this site acquired its name, though the design aspect of it is a likely link. It was interesting to learn that during WWII the Nazis used the building as a warehouse to store property they had confiscated from the Jewish population of Prague. In any case, the interior of the synagogue is fabulous! Intricate designs dazzle the eye! There are interesting case displays relating to the history of Jews in Prague, but it's really the ornateness of the interior that is why this is a "must-see". If you have purchased a ticket for the New Jewish Synagogue and Jewish Cemetery, your admission to the Spanish Synagogue and a couple of other sites is included. Take advantage of it -- you won't be disappointed!Highly Recommended!
Saw a concert there. While we were "underwhelmed" by the concert we saw there, the synagogue itself is beautiful and worth a visit.
Amazing. This place is breathtaking. The exterior does not prepare you for inside. This is a "must" for any Prague visit.
Beautiful. Just beautiful, we visited while on a walking tour of the Jewish Quarter, This was one of three Synagogues we visited,so glad we went.

Quiet beauty and reflection. The 'Spanish Synagogue' is one of the currently-working synagogues in the old Jewish town (at least 2 are now just museums). It's a new building: After WWII what had been the ghetto became slums, and the synagogue was rebuilt when the Czech government had much of the area razed and reconstructed to make the neighborhood appealing again, or so I've been told. It is gorgeous, and the gallery holds a small but very touching memorial to the Jews of Prague, both before the war and during. This synagogue is accessible with the 300 crown combined ticket. It's a place I would love to see again, and definitely where I'd go for services if I lived in Prague.
Just another splendid old synagogue. Just a quick visit as we were passing, much too quick to form a view. Interesting if that is your thing.
Stunning. We went to all parts of the Jewish quarter. This was one of the highlights. Quite wonderfully beautiful.

Fascinating . Wanted to see the cemetry but had to pay all in ticket including entry for few synagoges. This Spanish one has all the names of Jewish people who died at the war written on the walls. The cemetry is eery and spooky. I have been told there are 12 layers of bodies burried underneat the graves. This site would have been awesome to do a ghost tour.

Interesting but a bit expensive. A fascinating glimpse into the story of the Jews in Prague but the access is pretty steep - crowds were high and it was often hard to move around. The synagogue is an attractive building inside and there were some interesting displays.

Beautiful. A lovely little gem. Reminded me of trips to Istanbul and Morocco. Take a wide angle lense for the best pics and go upstairs and look down. Added some nice variety to the already rich architectural range of Prague.

this is my third visit to the spanish synagogue. There's a reason for that. man. man. man...this is a stunning building. now, KevinP says this is overpriced and not that interesting. Not unique? Horribly overpriced? Seriously? This place is gorgeous. How many surviving synagogues are there in Europe this beautiful? Or is Kevin P just disappointed that the final solution failed? A breathtaking beautiful building filled with fascinating and sombre artifacts.

Concert magic. During the Second World War, the Germans used the building as a repository for property taken from the Jews. The building underwent a restoration in the late 1990s.The building is owned by the Jewish Museum of Prague, and is used as a museum and concert hall.We went for a concert here and it was just magical. There are many halls that have these concerts on in Prague but this is lovely and is worth attending one here.

Beautiful and tragic. The decoration of the synagouge is amazing and well photographed. The stands upstairs are telling the history of Prague Jewish community have old documents with English translation. The are showing the usual story of European Jews: periods of persecution and enlightments, Hitler's final solution and post war antisemitism.

Overpriced not that interesting. This site can be skipped. This is part of the Jewish Museum "package" which is not that unique and horribly overpriced to other European sites of greater interest. The Synagogue is pretty inside, but the museum portion on the second level is really weak. The cemetary is the only interesting part of the JM tour, catch a look from the outside and spend your money elsewhere.

Chock full of Jewish Religious Objects. We loved the open space and the architecture of this synagogue. There was a room filled with religious objects -- rather than a single example there were many ! I believe the Jewish Museum ticket included this location.
Amazing. we visited many synagogues in Central Europe and this was by far the most interesting and different. It is a must see when in Prague

Must see in Prague. The synagogue is a part of the Jewish Museum, laying in the heart of the Prague city center. It has special atmosphere and definitely worth the visit. Till today, there are many weddings having in this synagogue - so it is not just a museum, but living installation.
A must-see on any tour of the Jewish Quarter. The first reform synagogue in Prague. Very interesting decorations and lots of interesting Judaica. You don't have to be Jewish to learn a lot here!!
Memorable. This is by far the most memorable of all Prague synagogues. Not the oldest, but definitely the most ornate of them all. A wonderful example of early 20th century synagogue architecture.

Beautiful interior . This synagogue has a beautiful interior and an organ as well , which is unusual for a synagogue . This synagogue also has several display cabinets reflections Jewish history . We visited this as part of a package of tickets we bought to explore the Jewish area of Praha . This was one of the better places to visit.
Not to be missed. I enjoyed the tour, it is actually "Moorish" I had a wonderful morning in the Jewish Area of Prague. Worth your time
Jewish heritage. Toured this museum which was very informative. Just beautiful. Was part of the tour with Valentine on tour through Jewish section during WWII.
Beautiful moorish style synagogue. We attended a classical music concert at the Spanish Synagogue. Beautifully decorated interiors with good acoustics.

Inspiring- great concert venue and of historical value. The building appears to be very moorish in design. Historically significant for the lost Jewish population of Prague. Upstairs holds a gallery noting the history of WWII and a time line of events with relevent artifacts. In addition to visiting the musseum earlier int he day, that evening we attended a classical concert. The acoustics without any supplemental devices(microphones or speakers)was incredible. I highly recommend a visit to include a concert.

Go with No Expectations. That's the only way to do it. Go with no expectations because if you think it is as pretty as those beautiful pictures you see online, then you'll be disappointed. But if you really want to see a one of a kind Spanish synagogue, then you will be blown away. You wouldn't mind paying the cranky Jewish ticket lady, wouldn't mind that the place is smaller than the pictures suggest and that there are more people than things to see in the building. You wouldn't mind because the details are exquisite.
Spanish Synagogue. "Beautiful" doesn't really do it justice. Still used for services and concerts are regularly scheduled. An important stop on a tour of the Jewish Quarter of Prague.
Gorgeous. Beautiful and historic synagogue. Very ornate. In sharp contrast to the Alt-Neu Synagogue which has been continuously active for prayers.

Dazzling Spanish Synagogue. We had the good fortune to attend an evening concert in this beautiful synagogue. We heard music by Leonard Bernstein, Leonard Cohen as well as operatic arias. The synagogue has Moorish style decor that covers every inch of its interior that we had never seen in any other synagogue. We went back on a tour of the synagogue and again admired its beauty while learning about its history.

Absolutely beautiful. We the number 2 option to visit the Jewish neighborhood, cemetary and various buildings. This is the only building I really wanted to visit and I wasn't disappointed. The synagogue is gorgeous!

The most beautiful synagogue in Prague. As everybody says it is stunning. It’s such a beautiful building. The colours are a mixture of red, blue and loads of golden. The Moorish influence in the building is evident in the arches and some of the decorations. The place can get a bit crowded so I recommend visiting this synagogue early in the morning (they open at 9 I think). In the upper floor there’s a very interesting display on the history of the Jewish Bohemia and Moravia. There’s also an exhibition about Synagogue Silver from Bohemia and Moravia.

A Treat for the Eyes. This is an absolutely beautiful synagogue. It was a treat for my eyes to drink in all the color and design. This was my favorite synagogue for beauty and the Pinkas was my favorite for the history and memorial to the holocaust victims.

Pretty amazing. This synagogue is one of the most beautiful buildings in Prague and is one of a kind. The inside of the synagogue is beautifully decorated, merging Moorish styles with the Jewish culture.

Interesting synagogue with intriguing exhibits on Jewish life in Prague. The Spanish Synagogue in the only reasonably-priced exhibit in the old Jewish quarter of Prague. The synagogue itself is very interesting and the exhibits are extensive and provide a very interesting and informative glimpse of the rich history of Jewish life in Prague.
Surprising decor. The synagogue is a visual delight with such a rich decor and craftsmanship. Additionally, the artifacts on display were interesting and beautiful.

Gershwin Concert. Went to listen to a concert of music by George Gershwin. Had to line up for 15 minutes to get in, which seemed a bit odd. Once in, had to junk a tea we had bought - just like US planes. Seats just OK for comfort. Concert itself was great and enjoyable.

Fabulous!. We attended a concert "Best of Gershwin" in the synagogue. The musicians comprised 3 violins, a bass, cello and horn. These 6 men were great! So enthusiastic, in sync and obviously enjoying themselves. It was a "feel good concert". Loved it!
absolutely beautiful. we toured all the old synagogues of Prague and this one is stunning. HIghly recommend seeing them all. They range in age from the 1400s-1800s/
Beautiful synagogue. It is always fascinating to see magnificent works of art in these buildings/ It is now a mueum, but really worth to look at the grandeur
exiting. the Jewish quarter is full of rich history:old synagogues,beautiful ancient architecture.,information about the huge Jews contribution to the Czech culture and science

Amazing witness of Prague Jews . I was wondering why this building survived Second World War, until I acknowledged all Prague Jews were exterminated in German Death Camps. Amazing building with terrible story with behind. Must see to memorize tragedy of War.

Important Reminder of Jewish Community. A view of the once-proud Czech Jewish community. The lavish synagogue is a reminder of the pre-WWII days in which the city had a Jewish community proud of its heritage and religion. If going to see all the Jeiwhs museum sites, I would leave this for last.

Don't miss Bolero or Gershwin concert!!! Best value in city. When we booked, questioned the quality of a five piece performance...they simply blew us away. Intimate venue, 7 PM start time, plus a few surprises added up to a memorable evening. Only two blocks from Old Town Square. All performers are part of the Czech Symphony and solist/soprano sang with such feeling.Open seating and doors open at 6:45 but no a bad seat in the house.
stunning. This is beautiful building. They say the 'most beautiful synagogue'! I would agree with that I also attended a classical music concert in the evening which was lovely.

You Should See This. This is one of the stops on the Jewish Quarter Museum walk. The Moorish architecture is unlike any other synagogue that I have seen. This is well worth the price of admission. It is a must see if you are interested in Prague's Jewish history.

So interesting. This should be taken in tandem with the Jewish quarter to appreciate the whole story. Interesting to note that the Nazi's kept this quater intact in order to preserve it a s "a museum for a Vanished race" This makes it a wonderful place in celebration and defiance of the Nazi regime and the dastardly plans.

Beautiful monument. Beautiful place to visit, highly recommended. It is quite modern but anyway, lovely. it is Moresque in style but does not really like the old Jewish monuments of Cordoba. Very special.
Beautiful synagogue. This is a very beautiful synagogue with stunning ceilings and windows. The displays were informative. It does not have poignancy of the Pinkus synagogue but is worth a visit.

Beautiful interiors. This was our first visit to a synagogue and we were quite enthralled. The Spanish synagogue gets its name because of its moorish architecture (we learned that jews are divided into two depending on the geography i.e. either Spanish or German). The architecture of the Spanish synagogue was very different from the other synagogues we saw within the Jewish quarter - it certainly was more elaborate and intricate. The interiors too were very pretty though different from the churches one comes across in this part of the world. The walls weren't overtly decorated and they had a few relics and artifacts on display. If you don't have time to visit the whole Jewish Museum (its the spread across the Josefov) then at least visit the Spanish synagogue.

Jewish Quarter is unlike anything I've seen elsewhere. We spent a day walking around the Jewish quarter. Unlike elsewhere in Europe where World War II and the Holocaust have destroyed most vestiges of the Jewish community, Prague's Jewish quarter is still mostly intact - numerous synagogues and a cemetery have amazing stories to tell. The synagogues reflect the different influences of different congregations - in terms of architecture and religious practices.

Don't miss this beautiful, historic site.. Whereas the Pinkas Synagogue with its walls of names of people killed in the Holocaust was very emotional for me, the Jerusalem and Spanish Synagogues are both beautiful and well worth seeing by every visitor to Prague.

Jewish Prague. This is one of several synagogues in Prague's ancient Jewish quarter and well worth the price of admission. Travelers can buy a ticket for all the attractions. Must see if you are interested in Prague's Jewish history.
You want to see this.. Stunning! Very informative exhibits. If you have a better camera (than your phone) you will want to have it here.
Site for weary eyes. Excellent ,iformative and beautiful into the bargain. This was a great stop on our tour well worth the effort while one of the many visits available in the Jewis district

A real treat!. We visited the Spanish Synagogue for both the Jewish Walking Tour and a concert. Just wonderful! Music was a wonderfully eclectic mix of Queen's Bohemian Rhapsody, Fiddler on the Roof, Johnny Mercer, classics and more. So glad we took the time to visit this remarkable building.

Beautiful. We were lucky enough to see an intimate classical concert here, along with 40 other patrons. Hearing this concert while viewing the stunning architecture and design was pure delight. There are documents displayed that are hundreds of years old for you to view, scrolls and photos within reach.
Beautiful interior. The Jewish Quarter offers many special places, but this is definitely the most spectacular synagogue. Interesting exhibits are displayed in the upper gallery.

Must See. Any tourist trip to the Jewish Quarter of Prague isn't complete without stopping at the Spanish Synagogue. As beautiful and stunning as the architecture and decoration is the story told of the Jewish people in Prague from 1790 to 1945. The exhibits are well done and easy to read and follow. It was a sobering and enriching visit.

Worth it. This is a most interesting synagogue. It's in the Spanish style which means it is decorated in warm earth tones and has symmetrical designs that are Moorish in nature. It looks like a church until you really examine it. It's an important part of the Jewish Quarter.
Must see. We learnt so much about the Jewish community at this well preserved building. It was a reminder of what they went through over the centuries.

Mesmerising. I listened to an amazing concert at the Spanish Synagogue, the venue was sensational and sitting there staring at the ceiling and surrounds just made the visit more magical. An amazing building that should be on everyone's list. Just make sure you don't plan on visiting on a Saturday as that is the Sabbath and it is closed to the public.

Real history. I cannot add much more than has been said in previous reviews other than to reiterate that this is a must see place. The display cabinets lead you through time and contain items that will break your heart. The décor is stunning in its simplicity and one of the few places that make you stop and think about human history.

Of all the Synagogues, go here.. We went on a Jewish Heritage tour and this was the last stop - had wished it was the first as it is an amazing site but was tired at the end of the tour to really appreciate it.

if you choose just one Jewish museum site choose this. As everyone has said this is stunning. You see fhe main sanctuary and the women's section upstairs. There are also some great pictures and objects demonstrating the intellectual and social depth of the community before the holocaust and some heartbreaking items too. Allow about an hour. Ticket office closes for lunch but reopens at one at the spanish synagogue so good time to arrive. We paid 70 koruna each as seniors and thought that was a great bargain.if you want the whole Jewish museum site package that's a different review.

A beautiful and peaceful place. We included this visit as part of a tour of the Jweish quarter and an inclusive ticket to a number of locations, including the cemetery, pinkas synagogue and the old new synagogue. We highly recommend this as part of any visit to Prague. Very humbling and moving. The Spanish synagogue is a very beautiful and tranquil place.

a must see for those interested in history and architecture. This moorish style synagogue is quite beautiful and reflects a style of architecture unusual for a synagogue. Worth visiting for sure. You must see all of the sites in this quarter and this is particularly unique.
A perfect stopping point for a tour of the Jewish Quarter of Prague. Beautiful synagogue with informative and interesting exhibits of the rich Jewish history of Prague and the Czech Republic.

Informative Visit. You cannot walk in the Jewish quarter of Prague and not visit this Synagogue.. The interior is so detailed you have to stare for some time to see it all... The staff at the entrance was a little cold.. The displays with the little artefacts were very informative...
Concert in a Synagogue. Amazing interior and an even more amazing concert: Hallelujah Concert in the Spanish Synagogue. Very special event.
Beautiful place. This was a stop on our Jewish Ghetto tour and was well work the stop. The interior was stunning. Really a beautiful place.

Beautiful, distinctive, well worth visiting. This is a beautiful, distinctive synagogue. Regardless of your religion, this is worth visiting. Strongly recommended as part of a visit to the former Jewish ghetto. Interesting displays along with the distinctive architecture.
Beautiful historic site. This is a beautiful synagogue, but the exhibits were a bit old fashioned and could use some updated organization.

A Holy Place. If you are an open minded believer in whatever you personally believe in then you will appreciate the history and the sacrifices that this place holds. It is somewhere that you need to go to experience the way history unfolds for a certain people. I can say no more.
Beautiful. We spent time in the Jewish Quarter and went into the Spanish Synagogue while there. IMO, the mose beautiful synagogue in this area.
One of the the most beautiful churches/ synagogues I gave seen. This was the high let of the Jewish quarter. The interior was magnificent, artfully painted and beautifully displayed. Worth a visit

Excellent Tour of Jewish Quarter of Prague with Anna Krystyna Sion. My husband and I took a private tour of Prague's Jewish Quarter with Anna Krystyna Sion in August. She is an excellent guide. We visited the synagogues and Jewish Cemetary with Anna and were impressed with the breadth of her knowledge about the history of the Jewish Community in Prague and European history in general. We spent at least three hours with Anna and she answered so many questions and shared so much information with us. Our tour with Anna was a definite highlight of the our trip. Strongly recommend Anna to anyone seeking to tour the Jewish Quarter. We have taken private tours elsewhere in Europe and in South America and Anna is a truly exceptional guide.

Amazing interior. Absolutely cannot miss when visiting Prague. Interior is decorated beautifully in a moorish/Spanish style. You would think you are in southern Spain. There are some interesting exhibits on the history as well. If you only have time for one of the many synagogues in the old Jewish quarter make it this one!

Get there early. This is a beautiful synagogue with a detailed explanation about the persecution of the Jewish community in Prague. If you are interested in going around the Jewish quarter (Josefov) you should go here first to understand the history behind the area.
Look up. the best thing about this synagogue is the beautiful ceiling. It is quite dark inside and no flash photography is allowed.
beautifuly beautiful. very creative architucture. not like al the gothic churches. a synagogue from the modern era. also has a kafka statue next to it

An Emotional day in the Jewish Quarter. We decided to tour around the Jewish quarter whilst in Prague this year and it was a decision I was pleased to have made. Learning more about this faith in the synagogue was enlightening.

A beautiful synagogue. The synagogue is very beautifuly decorated and has interesting history and written information about the jews living in prague over many hundreds of years. We also visited the cemetary which is also very interesting and much larger than we had expected. Its a little surreal walking in them cemetery in the middle of the city.
Musical evening in a wonderful setting.. We attende a superb concert here of both classical and contemporary music. A memorable experience which we would repeat.

Truly magnificent!. We were blown away by the Spanish Synagogue. So richly decorated without the gaudiness of the catholic churches. I love how symmetric the decorations look from a distance and then when you get up close it is so obvious that everything is lovingly done by hand. 'The exhibit also has a lot of information about the jewish community in the area and the hardships they suffered even long after WWII.

Must see synagogue. This is worth every penny you pay, the most incredible decoration of any building I have ever seen, it is covered in gold and geometrical patterns. You can buy a single ticket but it is also worth buying one for the circuit of synagogues, as then you get to see the others as well as the famous Jewish cemetery.

A Must Visit. The most special synagogue in the Jewish old square. The construction is amazing, the place is highly maintained and preserved beautifully. The second floor has exhibits that tell the story of the Jewish community in Prague at old times. Highly recommended!מדהים, אסור לפספס! כדאי לרכוש את הכרטיס המשולב שמאפשר גישה לכל בתי הכנסת ברובע, המוזיאון היהודי ובית הקברות העתיק. לא תתחרטו
Best of the synagogues we visited. Beautiful workmanship and design. Glorious colours. Displays and information well set out and easy to follow.

Beautiful interior. This synagogue was the most beautiful of the three we visited in Prague. The interior is very colourful and unique in its ornamentation. The organ I found to be particularly attractive.

Gorgeous place, worthy a visit. Even though this place is far from a traditional synagogue, it's worthy to see the influence of a culture on another. Nice mix of catholic influence (organ) and muslin influence (architecture very much seen in Andalucia)

Beautiful Synagogue with historical museum showcasing 19th and 20th century of Jewish community. Really beautiful synagogue , which we visited first time.  We also liked the way historical documents preserved neatly which explains the Jewish society in Prague during 19th and 20th Century

Pretty, but was overwhelmed by visiting the Pinkas synagogue first.. Part of the collection of buildings collectively known as the Jewish Museum, it is a pretty building but as we had visited the Pinkas synagogue first I was probably too affected by that to fully appreciate here. The Pinkas synagogue is a memorial to over 77,000 jews who were killed by the Nazis, and is a thought-provoking experience to visit.
Spanish Moorish architecture Synagogue. Really beautiful! Worth a visit especially if you're interested in Jewish history. The musical performance at the synagogue was ok, nice setting.

Jewish sector is a must. Was not expecting a richly decorated Moorish synagogue! Amazing. Many good displays too. The man in charge of audio guides didn't know how to set them up or distribute them so he refused to do so and made us go to another part of the Jewish sector to get them

Excellent Jewish history tour with Anna!. First of all it is incredible the amount of preserved monuments and artefacts. I have visited few places before in Vienna and in Germany and it was just a small fragment, of what we saw in Prague Jewish Museum. Prague was always very important in Jewish history, so it was natural for us - family with Jewish roots - not to miss this part. We wanted to get more from our visit, so we decided for Anna Kristyna Sion to be our guide. Eventually we recognised it was the best decision we made, because without her, we will never feel that we really understood the story of Jews in Czech lands. She does her own research and studies going deeper to the core of Judaism and also making and filming interviews with holocaust survivors with her colleague and mentor Pavel Batel (whom we hired to take as to Terezin). Her personal interest and connection to this subject is admirable. She pointed us so many details and personal stories we wouldn't be able to know or find just wandering around the streets, that made our tour with Anna Kristyna Sion very unique, personal and moving. We can simply say, don't go there without Anna!

History brought to life!. Moving accounts, photos,artifacts and memorabilia from the Czech Jewish community during the Nazi Occupation.This is such a part of Czech history that should never be forgotten.I was so glad I included this in my itinerary of things to see.Its worth paying the three hundred Czeck Crowns to visit the other Jewish Museums that are linked to this part of history.All are near to each other.
A great place to hear classical music.. Went to a concert here. The acoustics were amazing, and the location is beautiful. I would certainly go to another concert here. Lovely.
Beautiful inside of the synagogue. Beautiful synagogue is now a museum and place where concerts take place. I loved the ornaments inside, worth of visiting.

A museum and a synoagogue. A must for every one who want to know about the flourishing Prague Jewish community before wwII. The place is impresive, there are many historical articles on display so in fact it serves a a museum of Jewish life in Prague for centuries
A must see in prag. One of the most beautiful Synagoges that I have seen. You can see the great work that has been invested in keeping this jewel in good condition.
Gorgeous synagogue of Moorish Revival style. The interior of this beautiful synagogue is very elaborate style with great designs and patterns of Moorish Revival style. Really worth visiting.
Book a concert here it's amazing. Just amazing by all accounts we booked one of the concerts, cheap, and heard Bolero and a number of other number sung in wonderful acoustic conditions, sensational
Nice concert. Went there for an evening classical concert. the concert was beautiful and acoustics were amazing. Highly recommended if you are a fan of classical music.

Absolutely beautiful.. In the top five of all the most beautiful churches we have ever seen, it ranks with Cologne cathedral, Rosslyn chapel, the abbey at Iona as a true testament to man giving his best to honor his God. The interior design was intended to remind the faithful of the cities of Spain that they left. It is an inactive synagogue but still inspires.

Historical displays could be better organised. The interior of this synagogue is quite beautiful but the displays aren't in any real sensible chronological order. I am sure this is a fascinating place for those of the Jewish faith, but for us it was only average. We purchased a 2a ticket for 300 Kroner which gained us entry to 6 different sites - a fair price if you visit all of the sites (which are all in very easy walking distance).

Classical Concert in the Spanish Synagogue. Touted as the most beautiful synagogue in all of Europe! What better way to enjoy this place than to watch a classical concert for a complete experience. So glad to have had the chance to catch the famous Czech Symphony Orchestra performing inside this iconic building of Prague.
It is really worth a visit!. It is really worth a visit! It's gorgeous (a wonderfully rich decoration inside) and the exhibition is very interesting.
wow. Wow I have never ever in my life seen so beautifull synagogue.Lots of colours shining.Entrance is expensive but in this case it is worth it.
Absolutely stunning!. This was one of my favourite places in the whole of Prague. The inside of this building is very grand and stunning! Make sure you go and look!

A beautiful and functioning traditional Synagogue. We were here twice, once for a tour of the Synagogue and once for a concert performance.The synagogue is beautiful and traditional in style and shape. The acoustics are exceptionally good meaning no amplification ois needed for either services or performances. A must see.

Impressive building. This is a beautiful Synagogue which looks like palaces I have seen in Andalucia. As in the other Synagogues there is a lot of information. They also have concerts there in the evening.

Most Beautiful Synagogue in Central Europe. I made an effort to visit as many synagogues as possible on my trip through central Europe. The best of these synagogues is the Spanish Synagogue of Prague. The architecture is marvelous, it is truly one of the most beautiful synagogues I have visited. The gold walls and stained glass windows are truly stunning. The synagogue was not used by Sephardic Jews from Spain, but it was built in a very vibrant Spanish style. Truly a must see while in Prague.

Unique. Very beautiful inside, which is totally unexpected as you walk into an ordinary looking contemporary style building. Inside is a feast for the eyes and nothing like any other Synagogue I have been too. Seeing an organ in Synagogue is something unique.
A MUST See. Absolutely stunning interior. Truly gorgeous architectural elements. It should be on everyone's tour of the Jewish Quarter.

Breathtaking first view. The minute you enter the main hall you just have to stop and gasp. The space is bedazzling in its decoration, and the way the space and light play with each other will leave you gaping for a few moments. Along the entire two floors are displays indicating Jewish history in the Czech Republic, which were all very informative, but honestly for me it the space itself that made it worth the money.
Gorgeous architecture housing important history. Worth a stop on your travels through Prague. Beautiful history preserved. Modest but poignant collection inside.

Beautiful Building. The Spanish Synagogue is architecturally beautiful. It has a very special feeling to it. There are also reasonable concerts there some evenings which are worth going to. This is definitely worth a visit.

ABSOLUTELY STUNNING! . Beautiful building and architecture! As well as rich history displayed inside it.Highly recommended when visiting Prague. Interesting Note: Nothing Spanish about the Synagogue except for its architecture and design. The Jews who built it and prayed in it weren't from Spain at all. They just wanted to build a building that's different and incredible

An important stop in Prague.. It was the first time I had ever been in a synagogue. And this was a good one to start with. Absolutely beautiful. And with a lot of historical souvenirs and explanations. Helpful to get a point of reference.
A must see in Prague. Only built in the 19th century, this synagogue is spectacular. Architecturally similar to a mosque, this house of worship is ornate and breathtaking. Very special.

A feast for the eyes.. The greatest problem with visiting the Spanish Synagogue is knowing where to look first. Every centimetre is richly decorated. Its claim to be the most beautiful synagogue in Europe is hard to dispute. We were fortunate enough to return the following day for an amazing concert by a phenomenal string quartet, joined by a superb soprano and trumpeter. Don't miss this architectural masterpiece.
To be visited. A very nice place to visit with the other synagogues located in the same area. For the enire sites forecast half day minimum.

Jewish Quarter with private guide Anna Kristyna Sion. We knew we wanted to do the Jewish Quarter, but it is one of the most expensive things you can do in Prague and with our knowledge of Jewish history and culture only being so so, we wanted to make the most of it.So having looked through various reviews on here, we kept noticing the same name crop-up time and again. We did a quick Google of Anna Kristyna Sion and found the site and email to contact her with to book a private tour.Booking was effortless and she sorted everything for us.Kristyna is an incredibly friendly, happy, informative guide with a love and knowledge for her people which is refreshing. She helped turn what otherwise would have been just another thing to see in Prague into the highlight of the trip.Thank you!I would highly recommend her services.
Spanish synagoge. Very interesting, very touching, a lot of details but very hot and crowded during the summer months.

Beautiful concert space with amazing interiors. We went for a concert here, and the beautiful interiors enhanced our experience of the performance. The concert played to the crowd, but the trumpet player was really good. Worth a visit.

Beautiful. Get the full pass for the synagogues and cemetery. It'll help you understand how 10% of Prague's population went from middle class professionals to outcasts and eventually ended up in the gas chambers. This synagogue is beautiful and should not be missed.

Impressive synagogue. I had the opportunity to visit the synagogue during a music concert. There was a fantastic environment (just completed by the beautiful drawings and architectural details of this wonder), and the musicians that I had the opportunity to watch were good. It is also very interesting to see a jewish constructions with a moorish style. It worth the time of any traveler.

Beautiful . This was such a nice place to visit. The architecture in the Synagogue was fantastic and the items they had on display were amazing! In my opinion it was the nicest one out of the whole Jewish town.

Beautiful Synagogue with Moorish Style. We visited this synagogue after our tour of the Old Jewish Cemetery. Our guide said it is known as the most beautiful synagogue in Europe and is located in the heart of the Jewish Quarter. The synagogue was founded by a group of Jewish people who were expelled from Spain in the 15th century. The Spanish influence can be seen in the interior of the building. Be sure to visit this synagogue when your travels take you to the Jewish Quarter in Prague.
Stunning interior, a must see.. The Spanish Synagogue is absolutely beautiful. We went to an event there that made it that more interesting.

beutifull inside. although a walk away from the main Jewish area of Prague this is well worth the walk as part of the ticket ,on the outside it looks like a normal building but oh boy the inside is fabulous ,such a majestic décor is a sight to be seen
beautiful. Beautiful building, the most ornate of all the synagogues. Definitely worth the time. If you like buildings you will love this.

You don`t have to be Jewish to visit this place. The Spanish Synagogue in Prague is a most wonderful building with a Moorish concept, it was built in 1868, not for Spanish or Sephardic Jewish congregation but was a Temple for early reform worship. The elaborate interior with it`s magnificent Dome, Organ and Ark, is breath-taking, there a lots of Jewish artefacts and History recorded in this amazing place.

Kafka and the Synagogue. I went to the Spanish Synagogue because I was on the trail of a sculpture of Franz Kafka which is just outside the Synagogue. the Synagogue itself is well worth a visit whether you are of the Jewish faith or not. There are many exhibits which are informative and give much insight into Jewish life and practice throughout the centuries. The large bronze sculpture of Kafka, himself Jewish and a famous son of modern day Prague, lived up to expectation. Whilst you're in the area pop into one of the Jewish Restaurants and enjoy a traditional meal.

Wonderful building in Moorish style : very special for a synagoge.. Not only a wonderful building but on the 1st floor there is also an exhibition about the Jews during WWII in Prague. At the same time it is a place of beauty and of a horrible past.

Loveliest synagogue in Prage.. This was part of our self tour of the Jewish section of Prague.A very beautiful building with lots of history.Ornately done it is a peaceful place. You can photograph the outside by going to the side street off to the left.
Interesting exhibits. Very pretty building! Took an hour to go round all the displays and read about recent Czech Jewish life.

Gorgeous and interesting!. Entrance fee: 300CZKThis is the first ever synagogue I have been to and I was impressed. It's very beautiful inside and the history of that place is presented very well.
