We spent an hour inside. The artefacts and pictures with commentary about the Jews during the Holocaust is interesting. Shouldn't miss this gem if you're visitng the Jewish quarter!
Beautiful . This was my first visit to a synagogue and I came away impressed. This one is very pretty and very well maintained. Shouldn't miss it.

really impressive. I felt like this was the most interesting site in the Jewish district. The exhibitions and artefacts about the Jewish community in Prague were interesting and presented in an effective way. A place to keep remembering History. Absolutely necessary

One of the nicest Synagogue I've seen in Europe. The Spanish Synagogue in Prague is one the most beautiful synagogue and fortunately photography is allowed.The most remarkable part is the style of the interior, lots of gold color as you notice in the pictures.I would suggest to allocate at least half a day to visit and walk the Jewish cartier since the whole area is nice.Basically you can get a ticket to cover few places in Josefov area such as Old Jewish Cemetery, the old-new synagogue and so on ...

Very ornate. This was one of 3 Synagogues we visited in Prague and the most ornate. It is sad to see they all have a guard at the front entrance as a sign of continuing anti semitism. Admission fee required.
Colorful and beautiful. The detailed pattern inside the synagogue is just impressive. This is my favorite synagogue with one of the best pilsner restaurants just in front.

I received a wonderful tour from Terezin Private Tours. Before coming to Prague, I asked Anna from Terezin Private Tours to guide me through the Jewish quarter. She gave me a wonderful tour through all of the buildings of the area, sharing the history of each building and explaining the history in detail. Anna is passionate about this subject and a delightful person to spend a few hours with. If you would like to not just see the buildings but really understand what you are seeing, you can also book the tour here: www.terezin-private-tours.com

Beautiful synagogue. After the decimation of the Jewish people in Europe during World War 2, this synagogue remains a towering icon of how impressive Jewish culture in Europe used to be for centuries.This place also offers GREAT 1-hour concerts!

Inspiring. magnificent interior - nave and gallery. There is a display of silver items associated with the Jewish faith - in a side room off the gallery. In the gallery itself, there are display cabinets, some of which contain photographs and other memorabilia from the Concentration Camps - very moving.There is a tiny gift stall at the entrance/exit; a most delightful and chatty lady served me. She was lovely and an excellent ambassador for her faith and for the synagogue itself.

Disappointing compared to the Portuguese synagogue of Amsterdam. The potentiel Of this synagoga is underused though the place is beautiful and very unique in Praha.One month ago, I went to the Portuguese one in Amsterdam and the staff of Praha should REALLY inspire themselves from the one of Amsterdam.-> here, the specifity Of the Spanish Jews in Praha is not explained at all.No history (why was the synagogue built in the 19th whereas the immigration began in the 16th..???), no focus on famous people from the Spanish Jews, nothing about the choice Of immigration to Praha, about the intégration with the Czech Askenaze community. Nothing except global facts that you can find everywhere else in the other Jewish attractions. -> As in Amsterdam, you could use some tactil screens with interviews, old pictures and movies. Really disappointed and that's a shame to underuse such a place !
Amazing concert experience. Wow the acoustics here are unbelievable get to a concert here if you have time. Excellent mix of classical and classical hits played by the quintet. Wonderful evening.
Great building. Beautiful building but due to tight schedule didn't get to look inside. Statues outside thought provoking.Makes some good photos.

An experience to be told. It´s said is perhaps the most beautiful synagogue,, my experiences there make me think it´s true. I went twice one for visit and the second one to be part of the religious service friday night. For me and my wife it was an EXPERIENCE, visitors from Seattle, service shared with them , Touchfull.

Looks so out of place. It is unlike any other building in Prague, all the architecture here is done in Gothic style and this place just looks so different in comparison to everywhere else but that's not a bad thing.

Thrilling. Heard the most perfect evening of music. (I saw some of the performers at the Prague Symphony the night before). Overwhelmingly beautiful Synagogue - the acoustics were perfection. The musicians (especially the vocalist) were spectacular. A night to remember.(get there early to get the best seats)

Inside truly amazing. The decorate inside this building in amazing. The details and painting are unbelievable. This together with the cases of items relating to the war and the stories they tell are not to be missed

Unusual Synagogue in Moorish Style. Unusual decor and stunningly beautiful. So much to see you need to take your time looking at the beautiful Moorish design. Check out the stained glass windows and the ceilings. Some of the most beautiful paintings and shapes are on the ceiling. The history included in the cases around the Synagogue is informative and heartbreaking. Do not miss going upstairs to see the organ and get a view from above.

Beautiful!. Decorated in the Moorish style, this synagogue is a jewel in Prague's Jewish Quarter. It is not as big as I would have expected, but the colors and design make it very special. We were lucky enough to attend one of the weekly summer concerts the synagogue sponsors two nights a week going through July.We heard a classical concert--mostly strings--that was absolutely breathtaking! The acoustics made it even more astonishing. I think they do these concerts throughout the year, so check with your hotel concierge.

Spectacular Details. This Synagogue is overwhelmingly beautiful. There are so many delicate details throughout the space. Don't forget to look up. Some of the most beautiful paintings and shapes are on the ceiling. The history included in the cases around the Synagogue is informative and heartbreaking. Do not miss going upstairs to see the organ and get a view from above. The entrance fee is included in the Prague Card.

Impressive. This is a very impressive building., mainly the interior decoration. There is an interesting display around. We also enjoyed the great acousitcs of the place by attending a concert there one evening and it was a amazing/
Anna Kristyna Sion Was A Great Guide. This was one of our best tours. Anna did a great job and went out of her way to assist us. The price was also reasonable.

very interesting and beautiful. Don't miss the Spanish synagougue. The interior is amazingly beautiful and rich. Very special to see the Moorish influences. Try to go there on a sunny day; the light through the windows and dome is wonderful. On the first flor you can see the organ up close. There is also an exhibition of beautiful old silver Jewish objects used in a synagogue.

Private tour of Jewish Quarter. Book a private tour with Anna Krystina at www.terezin-private-tours.comshe is a wealth of knowledge and can really make the Jewish Quarter meaningful for you. So interesting to hear about Jewish life past and present. You won't be disappointed. You will have entry into the synagogues as well.
Beautiful!. We didn't pay for the photo ticket and no one stopped us taking pics. Amazing inside, lots of gold. Staff were friendly and helpful.

Beautiful. The inside is just sublime. We visited during the classic concert as we believe we could mix both the tour and the concert all in one. It was a very relaxing and serene moment. We highly recommend it. Arrive early as no sitting assigned and first arrived first seated.

Very impressive and interesting from a history perspective. The synagogue is very beautiful but also has historical exhibitions which are great. They are particularly moving if you are familiar with german

An absolute must. Having wanted to go to the UPM (closed until 2017), I decided to go an see the Jewish Museum - a great find. Entry into the Spanish Synagogue comes as part of the ticket price (300 č). I would have spent that for this attraction alone. It is truly beautiful, ornate and full of fascinating information about Jewish tradition, history and how the synagogue and Czech Jews were treated during the Nazi occupation. A must see...

Important part of the Jewish Quarter. First off I fail to understand why people are complaining about the price. Buy the package deal and you get to visit several (think the total was 7 can't remember for sure) As for the surcharge for photography it is annoying yes but it is not much and seems to be a common in Prague. (I would however have preferred they inform you at the ticket booth which locations do and don't allow photography) Now back to the Spanish Synagogue it is a unique and golden place. Ironically you will learn that the Synagogues were used by the Nazis to store their ill gotten gains. A true marvel that sticks out in time and location. The warm glow of this synagogue fills you with the history of a lost people. Don't skip if you are in this section of town. I do recommend the entire Jewish tour.

Concert. The place is beautiful. We went there for a Concert and I must say the benches are terrible to sit in. Luckily we were able to "catch" 2 of the chairs they had put out because of the Concert. (Not good either, but better). So be hereby warned, people were not supposed to sit comfortably in those days, either in synagogues or churches. But visit the place, it is said to be the most beautiful synagogue in Europe.
Fantastic. Very beautiful place. We bought complex ticket for all jewish museums the price was about 15$. I strongly recommend to visit all jewish museums in Prague.

Fascinating. Very ornate and well worth a visit. Only criticism is that the overall cost of a ticket for all the synagogues is way too expensive in our opinion. Plus paying extra to take photos is rather excessive and we would have thought that this should have been included in the entrance ticket cost. Never come across a photo fee before, anywhere!

Worth a look. The Spanish Synagogue is a complete contrast to the simplicity of the Old/ New Synagogue. Very ornate interior and rich coloring. Though in close proximity it seems the two congregations were very distinct and separate and the buildings reflect this. Included on the combined ticket when visiting the other Jewish sites in the district.
Nice but small. It takes 15 min to see the whole thing. Nice but too small!It is certainly a beautiful synagogue but looks like a mini church with mosque design. It doesn't feel jewish.

Beautiful and historic place of worship. Old Prague has a number of historic synagogues, and this one is, perhaps, the most beautiful. Visit several so you can see how different congregations (and different periods) celebrated their faith in this historic city.
Beautiful Interior. We did not complete the Jewish Trail in Prague but this was something we were not willing to miss. The history inside is mesmerizing and the architecture just magical. A must see.
Fascinating. We stumbled across this little gem on our way to the Old Town square and what a find! beautiful religious artifacts and a fascinating history of the jews in Prague
Nice surprise. I had never seen a synagogue so I didn’t know what expected. The synagogue is very beautiful and it’s worth staying in line to buy the ticket.

I don't understand why the Jewish Quarter Tour of Prague isn't #1!. The Spanish Synagogue alongside the other memorials in Prague are extremely well done. The drowning of 600 years of Jewish history during the holocaust and its resurrection after provides a critically-needed light of hope in our world. The entire tour of the Jewish quarter, including the Jewish museum, is a must-see while here.
Such A Lovely Place To See. This must be on your top ten places to visit whilst in Prague.Small fee to enter but worth a look around to see and read about the history
Hype?. Beautiful synagogue, although I think some are nicer?? Esp Budapest! No flash, or the hidden little ladies will step out from the dark and scold you.

Gorgeous Interior, Sad History. The interior is quite gorgeous and is comparable (if smaller), to the top tier of churches and mosques. The style is Spanish (or moorish?) which makes it really unique to see. Definitely worthwhile visiting. The prominent Jewish history of Prague is presented in an interesting way through artifacts along with commentary. There's also a history of how the Holocaust wiped out the vast majority of the Jewish community.The silver collection is interesting, but also sad when one thinks of how the collection came to be.

Beautiful building full of history. So much history in Josefov. It was initially a bit confusing, trying to understand where things were located, how it was situated, and where we needed to go, but once we spoke with a ticket agent, it all made sense.Josefov was crowded the day we went - all the synagogues, all the museums, even the cemetery were full of tourists. It was great for them, because I'm sure the funds will go a long way in helping to preserve the landmarks, but it made navigating through spaces a bit of a challenge.There were so many great displays within the Spanish Synagogue. They line every wall, and every one of them has a story to tell. Most of the displays had placards with English translations on them, but there were a fair number that did not. You can get a sense of what they're trying to tell you based on the artifact and the surrounding plaques, but there were a lot of gaps in information because of that. I'm not one of those travelers who expects the rest of the world to speak English, but it's confusing that some are translated and some aren't.The architecture and decor within this synagogue were beautiful. There's quite a bit to see - two levels worth, as a matter of fact - and though it can get crowded, it won't feel nearly as pinched as some of the other locations in the area. Definitely worth the time and money, for the history alone, if for nothing else.

Simply stunning!. When I saw pictures of the Spanish synagogue, I immediately knew that I had to see it. I was right: it was simply stunning! Such beautiful patterns and decorations! I simply loved it. It was the most beautiful sight in all of Prague for me. If you want to take pictures, purchase a photo license. It costs 70 CZK and it is absolutely worth it. The only thing I didn't quite understand was that you are not allowed to take photos with a tripod. I guess it's because there are sooo many people and when you use a tripod you block the "flow". Which brings me to my next point: It's very crowded. I guess it would be best not to go there on a Sunday. It is closed on Saturday (obviously) and then all weekend travellers go there on Sunday, just as we did. I would assume that it is less crowded during the week but I can't really tell because I was there only during the weekend.

Jewish quarter private tour with Anna Kristyna Sion. My husband and I visited Prague in April. We were recommended to book a private tour of the Jewish quarter with Anna Kristyna Sion. Anna met us at our hotel promptly and 9am and escorted us the short walk to the Jewish quarter. Anna is an excellent and very knowledgeable tguide and student of the Jewish history of Prague. We were shown around all of the synagogues, the old Jewish cemetery and told all about the history of the Jews of Prague. Our private tour lasted about 3 hours but Anna is a patient guide and we did not feel at all rushed but given time to explore all of the sights we visited. We also arranged a tour to Terezin with Anna's colleague Pavel Batel who is also a first class guide and an expert in the history of Terezin. We would highly recommend both Anna and Pavel to anyone wishing to visit Prague's Jewish quarter and to learn about Terezin.
Stunning Place. Bought a ticket for all the Jewish Quarter sites and this was my favorite. Its quite quick to go around but just absolutely beautiful. Great just to sit and take it all in.

Jewish quarter and cemetery tour with Anna. We were lucky enough to sign up for a tour of the Jewish quarter with Anna Kristyna Sion. The tour included the temple and cemetery. Anna was so knowledgable and patient, as one of the members of our family was in a wheelchair. Anna was able to accommodate all of us, with different levels of interest and knowledge. She is very insightful and made a connection in different ways with each member of our group. Most tour guides don't bother to do this, but Anna did. She made sure she kept it interesting. We were all very moved by her knowledge and passion regarding Jewish history in Prague. Thank you Anna for a fabulous experience!

tour with Anna Kristyna Sion. Our family have just returned from a fabulous tour of Jewish Quarter with Anna Kristyna Sion. We learnt so much and were completely looked after for the day. It is necessary to have a good guide who will tell you about synagogues before you walk in. I can not recommend Anna enough.

So beautiful. I dare to say this is one of the most amazing and beautiful religious buildings I've seen and i have visited quite a few around Europe! Definitely worth visiting and you also get to see some of the historic events summarised of what the Jews in Czech Republic went through during the WW time. Half hour would be enough to enjoy this venue, make sure you make some time for it!
Incredible . A lovely synagogue with beautiful architecture and detailed deisgn. The museum upstairs provided a sombering look at Czech Jew life.

moving visit. This was a most educational and interesting visit, and the restoring of the interior of the synagogue was magnificent. The monument with inscription to the victims of the Nazis was impressive in its simplicity.

The Jewish quarter. The Jewish quarter and the Spanish Synagogue are worth visiting. Buy the combined ticket so you can get the full pictour.of the Jewish quarter. Do not take the audio guide. Not enough information, expensive and too dramatic. The cemetry and the Spanish synagogue are the best parts of the tour.

Just marvolous. It is not only beautiful to see and visit but like most old buildings it is filled with stories of horror and other legends.In the old days a Jewish girl fell in love with a monk from the Catholic monastery in front of the Synagogue. The romance went on for a while until by accident the abbot of the monastery found out. He banished the monk to a monastery outside of Prague and waited for the Jewish girl in the crypt below the monastery where they used to meet. After this meeting between the abbot and the girl the girl was never seen again and it is said that her ghost is still around the monastery waiting for lost love.
Beautiful synagogue, worth a visit. Stunning interior to this synagogue, so ornate and beautiful. The exhibition was OK but the main draw is the synagogue itself. Worth a visit
Beautiful outside, beautiful inside. This is a fantastic building to see, filled with interesting displays. You might need more time to really look at the displays than you might think.

Beautiful Building and Part of the Overpriced Jewish Quarter Combo Ticket. The interior of the synagogue is beautiful! In particular, the geometry of the deign can take your breath away. On the second floor is one of the more interesting exhibits of life in the Jewish Quarter (each of the places you visit with the combo ticket has exhibits of some sort). While interesting, my judgment was experience by the fact that you have to purchase an overpriced ticket. I judge the latter by the price of tickets to major sights elsewhere in Prague (this lis far more expensive) and also by European standards generally. When you consider that a ticket to the Vatican Museum, for example, is 16 euros (less than $20 currently) and the cost of this ticket is about $25, it seems unreasonable.

Smaller than expected. The Spanish Synagogue has a well preserved interior; very easy to find once you are in the Jewish Quarter. Glad I saw the synagogue but I would not recommend this as a separate trip.

Great Tour of Prague Jewish Quarter. Any visit to Prague should include a few hours in the Jewish Quarter, just a small area of a few blocks that is full of history, architectural beauty, a sense of spirituality and sadness, and a bit of the mystical. Although my family and I are fairly well-versed in the history of European Jews we hired a guide, Anna Krystina Sion, to take us through the Jewish Quarter and found her to be excellent. She quickly assessed our level of knowledge and our areas of interests and was able to fine-tune her discussion of the various sites to that level. I was very impressed with that because many tour guides don't bother to alter their presentations based on the knowledge of their audience. She has a wealth of knowledge, a great deal of detail at her fingertips and an engaging personality. The four synagogues in the Jewish Quarter are each different, lovely in their own way and have singular histories. A Jewish cemetery is poignant and quietly beautiful. This was a morning well-spent and on our next trip we would not hesitate to hire Anna Krystina to accompany us to Terezin--time did not permit us to do that on this trip.
very beautiful inside. It is worth visiting. It is a little separated from the other Jewish monuments. It is beautiful and doesn't take very long to visit.

Really nice!. I really enjoyed my visit to the Spanish Synagogue and from the whole Jewish Museum tour this was the best part! Nice building and lots of information concerning the history of Jews in Prague.

Beautiful. Absolutely beautiful inside, worth a visit and combining with some of the other attractions in the Jewish quarter. No photos though which was sad, and strangly none available as postcards in the shop either.
Great place ...... Very beautiful place yet every corner with the "sign" stated no camera !! What the point paying a fee yet you just see and can't photo ! Should be no flash indication

Beautifull building, sad history. The building is beautifull. It has naturally a sad and bloody history like all synagogues do in central/eastern europe.Has a collection of jewish artifacts, that may be interrsting if you are in to those. You may pirchase a ticket to see the cemerary and the memorial by it, and i suggest you do, even if the price is a bit steep.
Spectacular interior. The gilded and brightly coloured interior is based on Spanish Moorish architecture. Classical music performances at 5:30 p.m. cost about £21.
Gershwin Concert. Very atmospheric, great acoustics this concert on Christmas Day actually moved my wife to tears.The architecture and the museum are worth a visit in their own right.

Bolero was awesome. I think it was $25 usd. A couple violins, a viola, and a couple bass plus an opera kind of singer. The singer was amazing. The first violinist did a splendid job as well. And the synagogue is worth visiting in itself. Killed two birds with one stone

The Spanish Synagogue Is a Beautiful Sephardic Synagogue. The Spanish Synagogue is one of the more beautiful houses of worship in Prague. Considering the stiff competition that is saying something. Built in the 19th century, this synagogue was a place of worship for Prague's Sephardic community. The Moorish decoration on the interior and exterior is beautiful. It fits right in with the Art Nouveau architecture in the neighborhood. The exhibits include silver menorahs, Torah ornaments, and Kiddish cups that the Nazis stole and intended for their "museum of the exterminated race." Do not miss the photographs of the Jewish quarter from the Habsburg era.

Beautiful.. Absolutely beautiful and certainly deserves its title as 'most beautiful in Europe'. Please visit - no trip to Prague would be complete without it. Prices did seem expensive though so it's worth buying your ticket with a Prague Card. Your ticket is then valid for a few days regardless of how long your Card is valid for. With the ticket, you can visit a few venues of the Jewish Museum in Prague. All worth taking advantage of.
Beautiful. It's now a museum. Beautiful synagogue! The art work on the walls is amazing. Kind of expensive but worth it. Kind of difficult to find it from the Old square.

Synagogue with Moorish Design. Moderately priced haunt with much to offer: engaging design, opulent treasury, and careful didactics tracing the plight of Jews in a Prague and surrounding areas. I left knowing more than when I arrived.

Splendid and historic Moorish architecture in Prague. The Spanish Synagogue in Prague is a must-see for anyone with a shred of interest in the history of Prague and/or central Europe. Hitler wanted to make Prague a museum for an extinct people, so Jewish sites in Prague were spared. Thank goodness, because they are so important. This synagogue also happens to be spectacularly beautiful.

Gershwin concert in Nov/Dec '14. Bought tickets for a Gershwin (Jazz) concert that day outside the site for adults-700ck, students (21-26) -600ck. Concert started at 5.30pm. First thing I noticed was that the synagogue was a lot smaller than pictured on the brochure, but that probably allowed the architects to make the interior as detailed as it is. The symmetrical patterns spread across every inch of the synagogue (except the floor) was visually satisfying to my inner-OCD. There were only about 10 pews and they had to set up several extra chairs to accomodate for the audience. The ensemble were 6 members from the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra - violin quintet and a trumpeteer. The concert was technically excellent - great dynamic range and clarity. The acoustics of the synagogue allowed the music to resonate richly, leading me to wonder what it might be like during a worship service. What pleased me the most was the small shared smiles among the experienced ensemble; they really enjoyed making music together.After the short (1hr) concert, we quickly took as many photos of the synagogue interior as the security insisted "No photos" and shooed us out. If you can catch the Gershwin concert I recommend it. I'm sure the other classical concerts offered on alternate nights are excellent as well.

Stunning interior. The interior of the synagogue is stunning and designed in a Moorish style. It is one of the most beautiful interiors that I have ever seen in a synagogue. It is well work the $2.50 to see it. We found an evening orchestra performance that was going to be played in the synagogue just so we could sit there and soak up all of the architectural details in this building. Don't miss this site.
Most interesting synagogue. What an interesting synagogue! It is very ornate and beautiful and my favorite of the various ones we saw in Eastern Europe. The small fee is worth it.

Really beautiful and interesting!. This cynagogue was definitely most beautiful one from all of the other ones. The differest stories that are told in the cynagogue and some of the stories of these cynagogue are really interesting and quite amazing.
Beautiful Historic Synagogue. A must see on your visit to Prague. Breathtaking renovated interior. Our visit gave an incredible historic perspective to the pre WWII Jewish community of Prague.
Very impresive synagogue. One of the most beautiful synagogues I have ever seem.The wall are covers with gold decorations.It is pity they don't let to take pictures there.

Ornate Interior and Memorable Exhibits. If I had not visited the Spanish Synagogue, I would never have known that one of my favorite 19th century composers, Gustav Mahler, was Czech! There he is, in a display case along with other notable Czech composers in the synagogue's balcony. Other display cases feature Jewish Czech writers, artists and so forth. The gorgeous ornate interior of the building is the perfect setting for this celebration of Czech Jewish culture.

Beautiful. As unique as this synagogue is in style, and as drenched in history as it is, you really don't want to miss it. Not nearly the crowds of the Jewish Cemetery and plenty of history. A small fee will get you in, but it's so worth it. There's also the Franz Kafka statue out front for a photo op!

Gorgeous, gorgeous building with a great exhibit. This is one of the most beautiful interiors we saw in Prague. The marrying of Moorish design with the synagogue layout was wonderful. The intricate decorations from the walls and ceiling to the lighting were all spectacular. In particular the folding of the Jewish motifs (Star of David) into the designs was subtle and clever. The exhibits were also quite good on the 2nd floor. Come back for a concert in the evening for the wonderful acoustics.

EXPENCIVE!!!. The price for this Jewish tour was so expensive and it is a waste of money..I visited St. Paul Cathedral in center of London and the entrance is free, and here you must pay a lot of money to see nothing!!

Beautiful. This is a stunning synagogue to visit. It does have a small fee to enter (50 Crowns or $2.50) but it is worth it in my opinion. It is a Synagogue that is made in an Islamic style so it has a lot of very geometric features with no icons other than the star of David.There are also displays in both Czech and English.No Photos Allowed.

Stunning. In my opinion this is Prague's most beautiful synagogue. It is an architectural beauty and should not be missed. There are a lot of items on display inside but the one that fascinated me the most was a Star of David that Jews were forced to wear during WWII. Unfortunately, photography is not allowed inside but that doesn't stop a lot of people from trying. As a side note, an interesting statue of Franz Kafka is located outside right by the Synagogue.
amazing... not to be missed. Certainly not the oldest synagogue ....but an astounding piece of architecture.Not to be missed. A must for your Prague visit.

Must see it. Definatelly the best synaogue in Prague. Go czech it out after the jewish cemetery. It's one of a kind, completely different from the others. It wont take you much time and the inside part is just gorgeous! It reminded me of a mosque, what a weird mix between religious buildings!

Upbeat concert. A string quintet with a vocalist delivered a well-paced performance of well-known music in the richly decorated synagogue. A great way to see the synagogue and enjoy one of Prague's many musical treats.
Concert with a view. A beautiful synagogue with a Moorish influenced interior that is well restored. Had the delight of attending a concert in this space. A great time!
MUST VISIT. The old Jewish life in Prague and what happened to it as a result of WWII is a must for any traveller. It bears witness to the history of the Jewish people.

Went to a Concert at the Spanish synagogue. On our last overseas trip we book a cruise and an independent tour. Unfortunately the timing was such that all the famous symphony orchestras were on their summer break. We look on the net and found concerts were available in the evening at the Spanish synagogue. The site indicate that there were three concerts held each week. We attended the Best of Gershwin concert. The music was performed by member of the Prague symphony orchestra. Great venue and music. Worth the visit and the music was performed well.

Nothing too exceptional. I read about this place and I went searching for it when I was in Prague. I passed next to it a few times without actually seeing it because only one part of thys building looks spectacular and you have to enter a park in order to see it. One can also buy tickits to go inside, but I decided not to do this, because it was pretty expensive and I was already a little bit disapointed by this building.

Just Go!. Regardless of your faith, the Spanish Synagogue is simply spectacular. We were fortunate to enjoy an evening concert in this exquisite performing space. Any visit to Prague should included a trip to this house of worship conveniently located near a famous modernist statue of Franz Kafka.

Beautifully Painted. It was expensive but for those that appreciate Jewish History, it's worth paying for. Not only is it beautifully painted inside but it has a history of the Jews in Prague which I didn't know a lot of.
Didn't go in but. From the outside it doesn't look like a typical synagogue, which makes it interesting. Very colorful and nice looking
Wow!. I loved the interior design and also the interesting historical display of Jewish history and culture in the area.

Buy an overall Jewish Museum ticket. This Synagogue is indeed beautiful and unique. It is best appreciated by buying the full Jewish Museum ticket, so that you can also see the Pinkasova Synagogue, the Old New Synagogue, and the Jewish Cemetery. Even though you are not supposed to take pictures in these buildings, everyone is and no one is stopping them, which is quite annoying!
Gorgeous. Just breathtaking! Don't miss this beautiful synagogue. The exhibition inside is also well organized. Lots of information in English.

Beautiful both by day and night. Go during the day to really see the spectacular interior and the moving exhibit about the Jews in Prague. We went back in the evening and heard a one-hour concert of classical 'hits.' The intimate and beautiful setting made the music extra special - my (teenage) son and I found this a very relaxing and enjoyable evening.Note tickets are cash only.

Beautiful. The synagogue is beautiful both from the inside and outside. All the decoations and organs are very nice and interesting. On the first floor you can fint several exhibits with an interesting history. The building itself is nice decorated and the style is very interesting. Since this is a religious place, I think that people who visit it should have more respect and visit it in quiet even if they are not religious and/or Jewish. Noisiness doesn't belog to such places.With the Prague card, this synagoge is free of charge.

A piece of art. This is really worth a visit. Built in the 18th century in Morrish art-modejar- this synagogue is beautiful. It ressembles a lot of the islamic art we can see in Morocco. There is a museum, but we skipped it!

Painted walls beautiful. Display powerful. From the outside, the Spanish Synagogue has no religious markings at all. It looks more like a banal blocky communist ministry than a house of worship. The interiors of the synagogue, relies on luxurious earth tone Moorish arabesque designs on every inch of the sanctuary, much like the Jubilee Synagogue, only smaller. There are no carved statues or frescoes in these synagogues. As in all Jewish houses of worship nothing representational is allowed except depictions of plants and animals: Images of God or the prophets are forbidden. Nonetheless, the Moorish carvings and painted covering the walls are a lavish feast for the eyes and for the spirit.There is an exhibit of Jewish life and death from medieval central Europe to the present. What struck out the most in the Spanish Synagogue was a picture (taken by the Nazis) of a woman unwittingly leading a group of children to the gas chamber. There are many other powerful images on display as well.

Go for a concert. One of the highlights of our trip was going to an evening concert here. There was basically a chamber orchestra plus a trumpet and a soprano. The synagogue is extremely ornate, but very intimate, with fantastic accoustics. For 700 CKR, you are treated to an hour of music from Mozart to Gershwin. The concerts are not nightly, and they do change, so check the website before you go.

As a jewish and Israeli - something was missing.. I mean, the synagogue is beautiful, from the outside and the inside.But, I think that were not enough jewish signs, even not hebrew inside. I am not talking about the outside, even in the museum itself.

Worth a visit. We went to see just the Spanish Synagogue, at a cost of 70 CZK, rather than the full Jewish Museum ticket which includes a number of Synagogues. The synagogue itself is beautiful, both inside and out, with incredibly ornate Moorish-style decoration, apparently influenced by the Alhambra in Granada, Spain. It houses exhibitions on the experience of the Jews in Prague, with the upstairs women's gallery featuring a powerful exhibit on the ghetto during WWII. The smaller Winter Synagogue upstairs houses a collection of religious silverware, including Torah scrolls and pointers. The only downside is that it is not permitted to take any photographs in this beautiful building. You'll just have to remember it!
Not to be missed. Lovely synagogue in the Spanish style. Dark woods with inlays. Very pretty. The whole family enjoyed the synagogue.
Magnificent Architecture. This Moorish appearing synagogue is very stately on the outside and quite ornate in the interior. The synagogue is still in jse today.

very interesting history. We enjoyed the effort to establish a historical context for the Jewish community in Prague (and the whole of CZ). Well worth the entrance fee. We only visited this site of the multiple sites in the Jewish Quarter and hope to get back later in our visit to see some others.

Don't miss the exhibition. The synagogue was big and very well-preserved. It's a pity we are not allowed to take pictures since the interior is really beautiful. Don't miss the exhibition inside the synagogue. It's really informative about the history of the Jewish district, the Spanish synagogue, as well as life in the camp. You will get a great insight of how they struggled during the war and how they survived. Very nice exhibition, very recommended to visit.Ticket was combined with old cemetery and other synagogues (200 czk for student).

Gershwin concert at Spanish Synagogue. If you love Gershwin / Bernstein/ Lerner and Loewe , you'd be hard pushed to find a more beautiful location to hear a group of 6 professional classical musicians playing their hits. But if you don't love the above, I'd say come to see the synagogue during its opening hours and ponder it for its beauty and history. If you come just to the concert, not only are you paying 700 CZK, but you are only there for the concert, the exhibits are in darkness and you don't get a chance to really see the Synagogue. To know if the concert is for you, you can find extracts on Youtube. We felt that the musicians were professional but there was no warmth or rapport with the very enthusiastic and appreciative audience. It felt like they were doing once again, what they do for exactly one hour a few times a week. TIP: If you opt to come to the performance, note that the wooden benches are very hard and uncomfortable - bring a pillow or go for the chairs they put out in front of and alongside the benches!

The nicest. Spanish synagogue is supposed to be the nicest in Europe. I agree with it, jewish city in Prague is unique in its originality, as it survived holocaust.The exterier of the synagogue doesn't prepare you what you will see inside. According to its name the synagogue was built in moorish style (alhambra) and interier is decorated on every piece of wall. The gold and red combination is wonderful.At the balcony there are pictures and objects from the life of jewish community in Prague during and after WW2. Books written by Czech famouse great jewish authors are there on display.The tickets are purchased for the whole jewish museum.Twice a week there is a concert, popular pieces - Gershwin, Ravel, ...

The only one worth seeing. We got the number 2 ticket including the new old synagogue, maisel (which is closed for construction), pinkas with cemetary, klausen and ceremonial hall. This was 10% of our total 3day budget and sincerely not worth it at all. Only the cemetary and the spanish synagogue are worthwhile. Its interior is absolutely magnificent. Very detailed painted ceilings and walls; very impressive. Don't bother with the rest. Besides their unfriendliness it's way too expensive for what it is. And none checks if you take pictures at the old cemetary or not.

Spanish Synagogue Splender. A place of outstanding beauty, entrance fee included in Jewish Quarter entrance fee, £10 approx, well worth it for this alone. Amazing walls, clings, alters. Lots of very interesting facts, artefacts on display.

Beautiful synagogue and interesting exhibits. This is a very ornate synagogue; just incredible. There were also many displays and exhibits of articles used in Jewish ceremonies that were very interesting.

Gorgeous synagogue - go for a concert. We visited the synagogue during the day - saw the exhibits, which were ok. The real attraction is the beautiful interior - this synagogue escaped damage during WWII and was wonderfully restored. Later we went to a Gershwin concert which was very enjoyable. If you can only see one synagogue in the Jewish quarter - this is it.

Best of The Jewish Sites. This was the best of the Jewish sites. In general the sites were overpriced for what is included, but this was definitely the highlight. The interior is nice, and is interestingly designed after the Alhambra in Granada (a Moorish palace).
Gershwin greatest hits. Beautiful concert, great building and acoustic. The musicians seemed to enjoy their play and were lively.Exquisite solist.

Moorish. Unbelievable beauty and craftsmanship. Also carries with it the sad history of Jews in the Czech lands over the last few centuries. Nominal entrance fee allows a different look at a synagogue in the moorish theme.

Startlingly Beautiful. If you are interested in history, art or architecture add this gem to your list. It is unbelievably beautiful inside, the walls remind me of Damascene or Toledo Ware Jewelry on a huge scale. Such beautiful gold on the dark background. Also an important memorial/museum. A must see!

Very different but worth a visit. We attended a concert in this Synagogue. The decor is just fantastic. The concert was ok, the sound excellent and the two combined did make it a worthwile visit. The concert was well attended so come early to get tickets and it is free seating.
Superb decor. This is part of the museum. But the best in terms of decor as it has the feel of something special that has endured throughout the nazi rule and more besides.

Small, beautifully decorated but too expensive. To visit this synagogue you have to buy a tour ticket which has a cost of at least 300K (this includes four other Jewish sacral places) and was the best place to visit in the whole tour.The synagogue is beautifully decorated but quite small worth maybe a 50K ticket not a 300K one.
Go to the nightly concert. A nightly concert is held with incredibly talented performers including an opera singer. Wonderful setting for such a first rate performance. A must do!

Spectacular. You don't have to be Jewish to understand that when you enter this synagogue you are standing in one of the most beautiful synagogues in the world. Its decoration is spectacular and detailed. COME DURING THE DAY WHEN DAYLIGHT FILTERS THROUGH THE WINDOWS. I came in early afternoon and then again the following evening and the details and colors were far more subdued. This is a not to be missed stop, during daylight.
Beautiful Synagogue. This synagogue is very beautiful on the inside. We went to a Gershwin concert there which was a great way to experience the interior.

Beautiful. The interior of the Spanish Synagogue is beautiful - well worth seeing. Inside are also display cases of various Jewish articles, books, letters and photographs of significance that are informative and interesting. Some of the displays were quite moving. Children are of course permitted inside however I wouldn't recommend keeping them there for too long as it would be difficult to keep them engaged.

Oriental Fantasy. The Spanish Synagogue, close to the Jewish Cemetery compound, is, compared to the other synagogues there, a rather late contribution to Prague's rich Jewish past, built in the 19th century in Spanish-Moorish style. If the front is rather unconspicuous, the side facade reveals the "Spanish" character, and the interior is marvellous and absolutely worth while seeing - the synagogue is not a place of worship anymore, but a concert hall (Classics and avant garde) and, on the upper floor, displays ritual objects and traditional Jewish silverware. The building is part of the Jewish Museum and can be visited with the ticket one gets when visiting the Jewish Cemetery compound.
the inside blew my mind. Like alot of the Spanish churches this Synagoge is painted in dark hues. But the natural light that falls through the glass roof panels makes it fantastic. Well worth seeing

Beautiful interior, go here if you want to see A synagogue in Prague. This is by far the most beautiful synagogue in Prague. The other ones included as part of "jewish walk" is not as exciting, except for maybe the old cemetery. If you have to pick one, go to this one and skip the rest.

very beautiful synagogue, excellent tour. i payed 320 crowns (price for students) for the big tour which includes access to 5 synagogues and the jewish cemetery. this is one of the most beautiful synagogues i've seen in europe. not old, build around 1870 with moorish influence it's a place where you can also go to concerts.unfortunatelly you can't take photos. the complete tour takes about 2-3 hours, and although is quite expensive, i think 500 crowns for an adult, you should visit all this places.the tours can start from any point, tickets can be bought from any attraction or from other shops, they are easy to find. prices and tour map in the photos!

Beautiful location for great music. The Spanish Synagogue is absolutely beautiful. Even if you don't get to a concert there do try to see it. We went to an evening of Jewish/American composters - Gerschwin, Bernstein etc. Quintet chamber orchestra plus an opera singer. Music was lovely. Concert was just an hour which was perfect. Ended with Hebrew folk songs. Will remember it for a long time.

Give yourself an hour. This is typically the last stop of the Jewish Quarter Tour. Hopefully you got the combi-ticket with the Old Cemetery and the other Synagogues along the way as this is the best of the buildings. No pictures allowed is a bummer, but there is an excellent series of displays (in English) chronicling the Czech/Jewish experience for the past 3-4 years. It's a bit of reading and crowded on a Sunday, but well worth working through the whole series. The building itself is attractive, but not spectacular.

Interesting and informative. This was very a different style of synagogue, with very ornate interior and stained glass windows. Don't miss the second floor which has a very detailed and poignant exhibition on the history of the Jews in Prague.
is so pretty!. We payed the tour 2 that included this synagogue. It is worth to visit!! it is really beautiful and you can learn a bit more about judaism. Photos are sadly not allowed.
History. Welcome to History, welcome to Prague the ancient and quaint City.The architecture if breathaking, so many places to see and so many things to do.You will not be bored.

Beautiful to see. We visited the Spanish Synagogue after purchasing the all-inclusive ticket for all Jewish sites in Old Town Prague. Unfortunately we were unable to attend a concert here. The interior is splendid. There is a fair size display upstairs relating to history of the area during WW2.

Stunning decor-great concert venue. We visited the synagogue as part of The Jewish Museum tour and it is a very impressive building with a beautiful Moorish decor and it houses part of the exhibition "the history of the Jews in Bohemia" which was very interesting.We later returned for a fantastic concert by the Czech Collegium comprising a brilliant string quintet and soprano and the hundred or so audience were treated to an hour of superb music and the synagogue has fantastic acoustics.

Stunning interior. I found this synagogue a little strange. The painted and gilded walls and ceilings are stunning, but to me it looks more concert hall than synagogue. It certainly does not feel like a place of worship.The exhibits telling the history of the Prague Jews during the Holocaust are very moving.

Gorgeous building; great music. We couldn't get over the beauty of this synagogue. We attended one of their evening concerts which had me smiling ear to ear. Attend a concert. It is so joyful in this unusual setting. Members of the renowned Prague Symphony play.

Beautiful venue, great recital. A beautiful venue for a small almost personal concert. Less than 30 people turned up for the Gershwin concert by the Czech Collegium. This ensemble featured musicians from the Czech Symphony Orchestra and a guest trumpet soloist. What made this concert even more enjoyable was that the musicians so obviously loved what they were doing.It was a very cold night but comfortable in the synagogue (it is heated but not overly so) - we could take hats and coats and gloves off. The seats are a bit hard but they are pews.The building itself is definitely worth a visit – so beautiful.

Bolero Concert. We attended a Bolero concert in the Synagogue tonight 26th JanuaryIt was a magical experience with the magnificent setting of the venue and the amazing acousticsAn experience not to be missed.

Beautiful building; wonderful concert. We saw this gorgeous building in the evening for a concert. Very dark, saturated colors - reds, blues and lots of gold. A 6 piece orchestra played Gershwin pieces, tunes from West Side Story and several other popular songs. The orchestra was excellent and the acoustics fantastic. Definitely worth seeing!

Impressive Building!. The Spanish Synagogue is covered by the ticket for the Jewish Quarter and is probably the most impressive building. Excellent decoration and in line with all the buildings covered by the Jewish Quarter tour is very well maintained.Good information boards describe the exhibits in a few different languages helping to explain them to the uninformed about Judaism such as myself.

Beautiful building and informative exhibits. The painted walls of this synagogue are strikingly beautiful and very different from the other synagogues in the city. The exhibits that make up the museum give a basic history of the Jewish community in Prague.
Informative. This is a must, the information available to visitors is phenominal, this area is so interesting, not only for the Jewish history but the designer shopping.

Floored By The Beauty--And The History!. This Synagogue is jaw-droppingly beautiful. The gold leaf, architecture and mosaic work are just phenomenal. The upstairs exhibit on the history Prague's holocaust victims is very moving and worth visiting for perspective on the city during WWII.

Good museum inside.. Visited the Spanish Synagogue for the museum and wasn't disappointed. It tells the history of the Prague / Czeck Jews very well. Had a lot of background knowledge and an interest in the Holocaust already so this probably helped!
Fabulous. Don't think you'll see anything like it anywhere, least of all in Spain. A beautiful place we got to visit on our guided tour of the Jewish Quarter- a must-do in Prague.

Beautiful decorations. This Synagogue can be visited as a stand alone. It is very ornate , lovely light through the windows and beautiful decoration in , as suggested by its name, in Spanish style. The small museum (only one room) is also a good reason to visit. The displays upstairs includes pictures by children from the Terezin ghetto. A place to reflect on the tribulations and sufferings of the Jewish people in Europe.

Spanish Synagogue. Amongst all other synagogues in Prague, the spanish synagogue is by fat the nicest.Very well laid out exposition describing the life of the jews in those times.One can again realize how the jews where persecuted during those years and then even more wonder how some head of states can deny the holocaust

Nice short visit. The Spanish synagogue is a beautiful place to visit. I recommend visiting only this site (for 70kc), and not the whole Jewish museum which is around 320kc.The interior of this building is beautiful and there are small exhibitions inside from the Jewish era in Prague history.One cons: you cannot take photos inside, UNLESS you pay additional 40kc. Why is that? how come it is allowed to take photos only upon extra payment?... didn't like it at all.

Historical-Cultural must. My wife and I entered the Synagogue and felt the awe the place gives you.We were very moved by the historical artifacts and journals displayed along the walls.What struck us the most is the Jewish history during the Holocaust and the Anti-Semitic acts they suffered.We recommend the visit as it gives you special perspective on life.

Recommend visit/concert and adjacent restaurant. We had a lovely time visiting the Spanish Synagogue followed by dinner at the Kolkovne Czech restaurant across the street. The food, beer and service is very good. And the whole neighborhood has a remarkable mix of ancient and Art Nouveau architecture. Very pleasant to explore. The Spanish Synagogue would be an amazing venue to hear a Gershwin concert but we didn't find out in time.
Unique architecture. I am always very sad visiting the splendid remnants of so successful and special a community exterminated by the Germans. Silent Monument of Jewish Prague.

Excellent venue for a concert. We went to this renovated Synagogue on our day tour. It was beautiful, and had interesting historical information throughout. When we were there we saw a sign that they were having a string quartet concert that evening. We arrived 15 minutes before the concert and purchased the tickets at the stand outside the building. The acoustics were amazing, and hearing wonderful music is such a beautiful setting was a real treat. We then had dinner across there street at an amazing asian-German restaurant.

Very interesting into the Jewish culture on Prague. This was our first stop when visiting various synagogues in the city. Thankfully as it was the first we hadn't become overwhelmed by the amount of information on offer.The interior is fascinating and has a resemblance to the Alhambra. The museum/exhibition on the first floor is very interesting, well laid out and offers you a fairly comprehensive insight into the way of life of Jews in Prague.Recommended.

Fascinating. The Spanish Synagogue is part of the Jewish Quarter tour. One ticket gets you into several old synagogues and the very interesting cemetery. Next to it is the traditional Kolkovna restaurant with its selection of heavy Central European food, but quite good; on the same corner is the even better Nostress Cafe with wonderful light 'nouvelle' cuisine; no smoking, easy music and a photo gallery + beautiful, modern decor.

Beautiful living synagogue - a bridge from the past to the future. The beautiful interior of the sanctuary (still used for services and concerts) takes you by surprise with its rich Moorish decoration. The balcony now houses a Holocaust exhibit. This synagogue is one of those on the tour of the Jewish Community -- it is probably the most beautiful, but not the most intriguing. I recommend going to all of them (and the cemetery) to get an understanding of the history of the Jews in Prague and their contribution to the city (including the tiled/paved sidewalks).

Probably,one of the most beautiful houses of worship I have seen. We saw it at night,at a classical music concert.Enchanting ! It really is an uplifting experience.Don't just tour,find a concert there and while listening,let your eyes tour this fantastic edifice !You won,t regret the time spent.Enjoy !
Great History. The Jewish Community in Prague has done a grea job of preserving the several synagogues in the former Jewish Ghetto. The Spanish synagogue is the most ornate , a true work of art

Beautiful building. The inside of this synagogue is extremely ornate and well worth a visit. Whilst photographs aren't allowed inside any of the buildings on the Jewish Quarter Tours, this one will stick in my memory for some time!

Beautiful synagogue and Gershwin concert. We paid for a single entry ticket earlier in the week just for this synagogue . We were so impressed with how beautiful the inside was. We later booked the classical music concert. This was lovely ,magical. A great end to our holiday . The czech symphony orchestra were very good.

Beautiful synagogue!. Amazing, with an arabesque feeling. Beautiful walls and ceilings! It is part of the awesome "Jewish Museum" in Prague but it by far the most beautiful building! Unfortunately you have to buy the complete ticket to the Jewish Museum (about 8€) in order to visit this synagogue. There aren't individual tickets.
Concert. There was a concert the night we were there. It was great ambiance but only lasted an hour or so, which it would have gone for a bit longer.
Excellent Concert. Beautiful building and concert brought chills. The soprano was angelic and 5 piece musicians were polished. Elvita was a highlight.

Not what I expected from the outside. From the outside it looks like some sort of government building but inside it has to be one of the more elaborate religious buildings in the city. Heavy Spanish influence and just a visual overload. Could have stayed inside and looked around for hours.

had it all to ourselves. Instead of buying the big Jewish Museum combo ticket, we bought a ticket JUST for this synagogue and the associated gallery. We arrived right at opening time and were the only visitors for almost a half-hour. The lady whose job it was to prevent photography was mostly absent.As everyone here says, it's an incredible place, with fascinating exhibits. Not to be missed.

Stunningly beautiful. This synagogue is simply overwhelmingly beautiful-a not to be missed Moorish style masterpiece. The Jewish Museum within has many educational and interesting displays and gorgeous silver ornaments from closed synagogues.
A Treasure restored. Visited it on a tour and then attended a concert there one evening. It is quite beautiful and has been wonderfully restored

The most ornamented. To me the most beautiful of the 5 synagogues in Josefov with all the ornaments inside. The exhibition is descriptive, but nothing exceptional after visiting the other places in Josefov.
Amazing. Amazing and full of history.A museum must for your trip to Prague.And just for art's sake please go to the beautiful Jerusalem Temple...Amazing too!

Beautiful design. This is the most opulent of all the synagogues in the area. The design and beauty surprised me as most synagogues are simple is style. This is included if you buy the pass which includes several of the synagogues in the area, which I would highly recommend. Don't miss going upstairs to see the displays. I wish we would have attended one of the concerts held here, I would be magical.
OMG. gorgeous restored synagogue. The entire jewish museum is remarkable; not sure why the OldNew synagogue is not included with the ticket.
Wonderful day here. Gorgeous structure...nice foil for all the churches we see! Great architecture and warm feeling. Great neighborhood with shopping and some sight-seeing

A place of beauty. Although it is no longer a functioning synagogue it seems to have retained its awe and spirit. The detail of the workmanship is truly beautiful. It is as if the heavens are surrounding those that would be there to worship. There are wonderful displays in this museum and concerts are held in the evenings.

Spiritual, Elaborate Design, Excellent Acoustics. We attended an evening concert here so we could specifically see the synagogue's interior. The elaborate designs blended with the delightful (Gershwin & other Broadway) musical tunes performed by a small "combo": this was an acoustic and visual evening of music and art!

Nice concert in the Synagogue!. We saw best of Gershwin here. Bought tickets right before the 7pm start. It was nice to sit, relax in a beautiful building & listen to music for an hour. Very casual. Well worth it.

1867, synagogue in Spanish-Morish style. An impressive synagogue, built to replace former senior "Yeshiva Synagogue" called Stara škola, already named after 11th century and used by Sephardic Jews (Byzantine rite cult). Its interior houses a part of the Jewish museum. Exhibitions: winter synagogue history "Jews in Bohemia and Moravia" (Part II of josef ism to 20th century), prayer hall: silver synagogue objects, gallery: synagogue textiles.

Spanish Synagogue - reminds one of the Alahambra. With its Spanish tile, architecture and beautiful carvings. Truly amazing and a joy to visit. Be sure to buy the package tour ticket and visit the other Synagogues in the Jewish quarter which are also very interesting.

Intersting Smaller Synagogue. We visited the Spanish Synagogue on a walking tour of the Jewish quarter and Old Town. It is between both. The moorish architecture reminded me of the Palatina Chapel in Palermo. Unfortunately we weren't allowed to take pictures. It is an interesting picture of Jewish life in Prague before the second world war.

Can't miss. The Spanish synagogue is quite stunning from the inside. Decorated in colors of Red and black it has a moorish touch which gives it a lot of character. It's easier to get a pass for multiple attractions rather than individually, although you are not allowed to take pictures inside unless with a permit. Don't forget to walk upstairs for a better view as well as to see a little museum in honor of the Jewish people.

Beautiful synagogue. We visited the spanish synagogue on our guided day tour and we loved it. It's small and stunning from the inside, but unfortunately, it's not allowed to take pictures. It also has an interesting exhibition of the history of Jewish Prague community.
Most beautiful synagouge in Prague. The location is a bit tricky since it is outside the Jewish main sites area. Amizingly decorated synagouge with informative exhibition of jewish history in Prague.
Beautiful. Loved the Spanish Synagogue. Our family toured several Synagogues in one day in the Jewish Historic quarter. We loved the Spanish Synagogue. So much beautiful detail.

Simply Beautiful. I did the whole visit of the Jewish tour in Prague, and found it very interesting, as most of the places were informative and had a different touch. The Spanish Synagogue was stunning from the inside with the golden colors and moorish taste. The choice of colors was just perfect. Both floors are totally worth the visit as was the whole tour package.Easily 8/10

Fascinating building, part of the Jewish museum. During a guided tour the Spanish Synagogue was recommended to visit. We paid 70 kr each for a ticket which includes the Guttman gallery next door. Unsure what to expect the interior is moorish in style and incredibly intricate. The exhibits help to put into perspective the history of the Jewish Czech community. The upstairs gallery has information relating to WWII.Good if you like history not so good if you want somewhere to sit down as there is nowhere inside.They do have a toilet!
Stunning interior.. Our family of four visited the synagogue and were blown away by its beautiful interior. Unfortunately you can not take a picture inside...

Beautiful synagogue in Moorish style. We took a tour of the Jewish quarter, synagogues, museum, and Old Jewish cemetery with Wittmann Tours. The English speaking guide (Susannah) was pleasant and knowledgable. One of our party walks slower and with a cane, and she adapted to his pace. The tour highlighted the vibrant Jewish life and history in pre WWII Prague and Susannah's commentary enhanced our experience. We were a party of four and all of us would recommend seeing the Jewish Quarter and Whittmann tours.

Stunning. Of the 3 or 4 synagogues that is included on the Jewish museum ticket - this one is easily the most stunning to see inside. Too hard to describe. Beyond words. You can see why they say it is the most beautiful in all of eastern europe.

Informative and interesting. This was the only synagogue that my boyfriend and I visited while we were in Prague and I really enjoyed it. It was nice viewing the inside architecture of the building. As you flow through both floors of the building, most of the display boxes have information about the artifacts as well as the history of the synagogue and the related events in the area. It seems like each site in the area has a great map which suggests a route to take through the area - this was helpful when we got to this part of town and were wondering where to start.

Incredible impressive building. The Spanish Synagoge is unbelievable beautiful and not typical Czech or Jewish. You can buy a seperate ticket for this synagoge (70 CKZ) so you don't need to buy the combination ticket for the Jewish Museum which includes the other synagoges and the cementary. In the synagoge is also a exhibition on display with foto's, books and documents, telling the history of Josefov, the Jewich community, the synagoges and the foundation of the first Jewish Museum, and Jewish writers.
Best synagogue in Prague! . By far the most beautiful synagogue in Prague. Great stained glass. And the 'altar' is great. Every wall is very detailed. Must visit!

Beautiful, but.... Very beautiful synagogue, no doubt. However, I think it's very strange that they sell a camera permit for the Jewish Museum and then don't allow pictures in the the most beautiful, important sites—especially after such a high entry fee.We were on the fence about whether to do the Jewish sites given the money. At the end of the day, I'm still 50/50. Beautiful and important, no doubt, but the price seems steep given the milling groups of tourists everywhere, no cameras, and the fact that only three of the attractions are really worthwhile.I give this 3.5 but round down to 3.

The interior is beautiful.. I almost preferred the interior of the Spanish synagogue more than St Vitus' cathedral. It is absolutely stunning and the best part of the Jewish Museum package. The only disappointment was that the museum was a bit pricey for the other sights that are included, even with a student card.
Stunning and moving. Stunning Moorish building with a very moving history. Read up on this one before visiting and you will know what you are looking at. Amazing and I am so happy it is still there.
Gold Ornaments.... The Synagogue has gold everywhere, it is really beautiful to look at. Spend a few minutes and enjoy the indoor beauty.

Racist Ticket Guard.. It's okay for an attraction but when I went out for a minute breather and tried to go in to find my family. The guard didn't allow me to talk and enter whereas a lady just entered by just smiling to him.
beautiful Moorish style. What an impressive building. Its interior is beautifully decorated. The synagogue also displays the second part of the exibition "history of the Jews in Bohemia and Moravia"

Stunning!. The outside was interesting but I was not prepared for how absolutely stunning this building is on the inside. The information inside was also well presented and interesting. It gave a good overview of more recent Jewish history in Bohemia. We purchased the pass for all 6 sites done by the Jewish history society. All of the sites together made a very worthwhile, interesting, and moving experience. Together the sites provided a lot of good opportunity to discuss the long history of anti-Semitism and the holocaust with our older child.

Quite beautiful and interesting. We enjoyed visiting the Spanish Synagogue. It is beautiful inside. Note that you are not supposed to take pictures. We visited as part of the Jewish Museum package. It was a bit pricey, but we enjoyed seeing the various synagogues and learning about their histories.
Worth it simply for the beauty of the Synagogue. This is a particularly stunning Synagogue, and is worth a visit just for that.The exhibits bare some interest too.

Far more than I expected. I didn't think this 19th century synagogue would interest me much in comparison to the other amazing Jewish sites in Prague, but it did. And it's not just the distinctive Moorish style of the synagogue, which is quite beautiful despite being too ornate for my taste (we weren't allowed to take pictures). It's the very informative exhibits on the balcony that grabbed my attention on a wide variety of subjects, including Terezin (the concentration camp north of Prague). The Spanish Synagogue also sponsors regular classic music concerts, which would provide another way to experience it. Also, be sure to enjoy the playful Kafka statue nearby (you can't miss it; it's just to the left of the synagogue). We spent an hour here and could easily have stayed longer.
Beautiful Architecture. Lovely building with wonderful atmosphere even when full of tourists. Exhibits are fascinating and moving.

Nice to see history of Jews during last 2 centuries. First of all it is nice to see the architecture of the synagogue inside. I have never been to any kind of building with this kind of style inside.Secondly it is very interesting to see the exhibit inside. It talks mainly about the last 2 centuries. For me the most interesting to see was the direct impact of World War 2 and how it was exectuted in the getto. Besides this it was very nice to see the famish Jews and their influence.You will anyway buy a ticket for entry when you visit the Jewish cemetery, so don;t miss out on this place

Pretty but expensive. Interesting visit to a very pretty synogogue with plenty of history of the holocaust and the history of jews in czech. Also has a museum of jewish items - quite pretty. A bit commerical adn over priced for what it offers, but if you are interested in history or the jewish religion, a good investment of time and money.

Most Beautiful Synagogue in Europe with Fantastic Acoustics. Wow! I have not been to too many synagogues, but this one was breathtaking inside and out! I had the privilege of attending an orchestral concert with the addition of a soprano and a trumpet player. Sitting near the center of the dome, the quality of sound was fantastic!

Inside is ornate and beautiful. I did this museum along with the other sites of the jewish museum. This synagogue had a lovely interior the gold and very ornate. It was a beauty to look at.. The upstairs has a lovely history of the jewish quarter or Josefov how life was back in the 1900s.

Historic. Go here especially if you get a package deal to see all of the Jewish quarter. It is expensive for the whole thing.This is an impressive place, turned into a museum. No pics allowed inside, but totally covered w designs. Beautiful skylight and history of Jewish treatment and precious sacred items. Well preserved.

Spectacular. This building is so beautiful both inside and outside. I would advise that if you are not part of a tour that you latch on to one so you can hear the significance and history. I had the opportunity to go to the Bolero Concert at the synagogue. The performances and acoustics were great.Although photographing is not permitted on the tour, nobody stopped photographers prior to the concert.

A spectacular synagogue. This synagogue is located in the old Jewish quarter, Josefov. There is a lot of history of Jewish life in Prague, which you can find elsewhere on the internet. This synagogue, which is called the Spanish Synagogue because of it's Spanish-influenced architecture, not because Sephardic (Spanish) Jews founded it, is located in the midst of Josefov.There are display cases telling some of the history of Czech Jewry. Well worth a visit, even if you are not Jewish.

Great look at Jewish Prague. Despite not much of the original Jewish Quarter surviving, the synagogues are a great look back to how this area of Prague was before its reconstruction. Some may feel that the synagogues were lucky to survive Prague's Nazi occupation, but the truth of the matter is much more sinister. It was Hitler's intention to keep the Jewish Museum intact, so that in later years, when the Jews had been eradicated, if anyone ever questioned whether it had all happened, he would have it as a 'museum of an extinct race'. Knowing this gave me a much deeper understanding and more grave feeling as I explored the different buildings of the museum, knowing that it could have been for a completel different reason.

Part of the old Jewish quarter. The whole Jewish quarter is worth it: the cemetery, Klamen synagogue, Pinkas synagogue which is aMemorial for the Holocaust Jews. The Spanish synagogue has beautiful inside decorations. Built in 1898 it has a moorish style.
A glimpse into a vanished world. Check out the entire jewish quarter to get a sense of the vibrant jewish community that once flourished here.

The Spanish Synagogue is a CAN"T MISS visit. My wife and I attended a classical music concert at the synagogue on our first night. The acoustics are wonderful. We also attended Friday night Kabbalat Shabbat services. This synagogue as well as the others in Prague was spared destruction in the war because the Germans intended to use the synagogue as part of their museum of an eradicated race. Things didn't work out the way they thought!

Eh. Not much to see here. The inside has nice Moorish style artistry but I wouldn't go too far out of my way to see it again. Very little information about the synagogue within the walls, so it's about a 15-20 minute visit unless you're an art historian.

Great site to see. We were not that interested in Jewish issues, but this synagogue was right across the street from where we ate lunch, so we peaked in. So beautiful and so rare to see the Moorish style in the center of Europe!

ok, nothing more nothing less. I visited the entire Jewisch museum (all buildings) and they are ok but the price (about 20 euro including the old new sinagoge) is too high. I would recommend to only visit the "real" museum and not bother about the old new sinagoge (saving about 6 euro).

Simply incredible. I don't know if it is so important, but being a Catholic, I was never been in a Synagogue.- Perhaps that was the fact that made me consider so important this sacred place for the Jews.- Incidentally, in the surrounding streets of the Synagogue you will find surprising buildings and good shops.-
Synagogue wonderful...employees, not so much... Beautiful and quite moving to be there....the employees were a little rude and didn't seem very happy to have tourists.

Jewish Prague. We got a ticket for the Jewish sites (old Jewish Cemetary, Maisel Synagogue, Pinkas Synagogue, Klausen Synagogue, Ceremonial hall and the Spanish) 300Kc (about $15). The Spanish was the most visually spectacular. It was an interesting and moving morning visiting the sites, and something I can recomend.

Imagine what didn't survive?. The Spanish Synagogue, just one part of the amazing sites in the old Jewish Quarter, awesomely demonstrates what was once a thriving Jewish community in the heart of Europe. What remains for us to view and contemplate is what the Nazis thought would be a museum and the subsequent communist government was too lazy to completely destroy. The small Prague Jewish community continues to restore this and other important sites so the public can view them. The attached photo of the Spanish Synagogue’s interior is opulent. Not so the Old New Synagogue that is also part of the quarter. Dating from Medieval times, it recalls the ancient architecture and long history. It is still in use and congregants meet for prayers every week. The Old Jewish cemetery, with bodies supposedly buried 12 or more deep, includes the remains of sages and scholars, doctors and lawyers, and those who resided here over the centuries. Just walking through it evokes images of our ancestors. Along with the multiple artifacts that have been preserved that once functioned in European Jewry’s daily home life, possibly the most disturbing exhibit described how the post-WWII Czech government treated (and treats?) Jews. Not a pretty picture. Reasons for seeing this site are many. For Jews and those of Jewish heritage, it recalls our ancestors. For others, it is a view of how those in the community lived when the Prague Castle was even more important than it is today. It also implicitly poses the question: Can you imagine the wondrous synagogues and artifacts that didn’t survive because they were intentionally destroyed?

Beautiful Synagogue, fantastic concert. A beautiful, active synagogue. Did get here for Shabbat, but did catch a concert at night. A string quintet, from the Czech symphony orchestra, with a soprano soloist performed classical, show, and Jewish music for 1 hour. Great acoustics, with sweet music. Catch it if you can.
Concert. We were fortunate to attend a charity musical concert in this synagogue. The acoustics and beautiful decorations enhance the playing and the atmosphere.
Go for services Friday night 7 pm. Even if you are not Jewish, you can go for services. They are very nice and you see inside the synagogue for free
Worth a visit. The synagogue itself is beautiful but the best part are the twice weekly concerts they have. The acoustics are impressive as were the musicians.

Music in the Synagogue. We attended a concert advertised as "Gershwin in the Synagogue. The building itself is beautiful and interesting. The musicians were fine. The programme was only very partly Gershwin.

Beautiful but nothing to do inside. It is very beautiful inside, but for the entrance fee, I thought there would be more to see inside. We literally walked in and walked around in five minutes, so I was a little let down. I'm not sure what I expected, but it seems like there could have been more information inside for us to read about the history of the synagogue.

So many sights, all of them very special. Get the Jewish museum ticket and start by seeing this magnificent synagogue. I've never seen anything quite like it. The exhibits are very interesting and after viewing a few synagogues in the area, it becomes clear that Prague has a rich and unique Jewish heritage.
Go to the Concert. There are concerts twice a week in Classical music!! Beautiful. Worth your time and money. I wish that I had bought their CD.

Symphony at Synagogue. Bolero at Spanish Synagogue was wonderful and the acoustics in the old building were fantastic, with the members of Prague Symphony Orchestra and the opera singer. Her voice was superb. A great evening's entertainment to finish an interesting day in Prague.

So moving. We visited the Cemetery and all the synagogues. I have to say this was one of the most moving experiences of my life and would recommend that everyone visiting Prague should ensure that they visit. Its a symbol of both the best and worst of humanity and how the strength of the human spirit has the capacity to endure and overcome. God Bless all those poor lost souls,

A moving visit. All the distric of Josefov is interesting, with several synagogues from different periods (the oldest in Europe dating from 10 th century). The spanish synagogue has upstairs a fascinating collection of jewish silvery from jewish synagogues in BOHEMIA, don't miss it. Go on the full circuit of synagogues, they are all different.
a must to see. THIS SYNAGOGUE WAS A SIGHT TO SEE. we loved the design and history. the entire Jewish quarter was exciting
