We wept. Helps one understand what happened to Jewish nation who had lived here fora thousand years and then have it all taken away

String quintet with decent singer in interesting Jewish setting. The tout promised a "chamber orchestra". The string quintet (with double bass) hardly qualifies as an orchestra. But they were decent enough, as was the vocalist. The program included a somewhat kitschy Bolero (a perhaps inevitable description of that piece if performed without brass, bassoon, or percussion), Bernstein's Candide, Gershwin's Summertime, an aria from Carmen, "Wouldn't it be Loverly?" (nonvocal), Hava Nagila, and Carmina Burana. All competently executed, and with a smiling stage presence, in a ornately decorated synagogue setting with decent if unspectacular acoustics. There was no Dvorak or Smetana, surprisingly. The synagogue exhibits = glass cases along the wall, old prayer books, illustrations of famed rabbis, Torah covers, head shots of Prague Jewish intellectuals, etc. The accompanying descriptions of pre-Nazi Jewish life were a bit dry but tasteful enough. Given that most Czech Jewish society was snuffed out by the Holocaust and then the Communists, the whole Prague Jewish quarter experience is a bit bitter and commercialized, but what can one do?

Worth the time to visit the whole area. We spent the morning (in the rain) in the Jewish section of Prague including the very somber walk through the old cemetary. It does make you realize how much pain and suffering took place in this City during WWII.

Beautiful interior and good historical exhibit. The exterior of this synagogue is very unimpressive, but upon entering, visitors are greeted with an elaborate interior. Decorated in a Moorish style, every surface of the interior is covered with glass tiles, stucco, or carved wood. The two exhibits, history of the Jews in Bohemia and Moravia, and Synagogue Silver from Bohemia and Moravia, offer rare glimpses of Jewish artifacts that have survived World War II.

absolutely beautiful!!!. we spent half day discovering the jewish old quarter. Get 1st to the museum and see all the synagog before the spanish one, because this is the best part according to me of the trip.The decoring is absolutely georgous, we were very impressed by the architecture and we found very interesting the exposition on objects and stories about the past of the jewish community during WW 2. Once again very pleased to see this place.

A Beautiful Synagogue. We have visited many synagogues, and this one is outstanding. The entire Jewish Quarter, from this elaborate synagogue to the more ancient and simpler "Old-New Shul", is a moving experience. How ironic that this quarter survived because the Nazis used the synagogues to warehouse Jewish ritual objects.

Beautiful Synagogue. Not having visited many synagogues, this was a very special treat for me. It is beautifully decorated. I don't have a picture to show as they were not allowed, but do consider including this stop when visiting the Jewish Quarter in Prague

Beautiful and informative. There are a number of different Synagogues in Prague's Jewish Quarter but we were told by the guide that this was the most beautiful of the lot, they were not wrong. The inside are decorated with designs that are meant to replicate the geometric pattern found in Al-Hambra mosque (hence the name). The exhibition provides a moving, heart-breaking journey through the life of Czech Jewish community from the every day life in Prague to the famous artists and writers. Its just the right length and packs a lot of information into such as small exhibition.

Nice interior but nothing more. The interior of the Synagogue is nice, but the pieces on exhibit were poorly documented and the entry fee was rather high for the amount of time you could spend inside.
Interesting Moorish architecture. Clearly the most interesting architecture of the several synagogues in the Jewish quarter. Also...overwhelmed with tour groups.

Really impressive synagogue. We arranged to take a tour upon our arrival to Prague through the train station tourist office. As part of this walking tour, we visited this synagogue (and others). It is very impressive inside and well worth seeing, but would encourage people to see it on a tour rather than by yourself as you'd learn more in an easy manner about its' artwork and history. Very beautiful place and the history is always interesting, even though it is historically tragic.

leave a full day to take in the jewish quater.. breathtaking,the beauty of the synagogue is awesome,the history of the jews from the gettos to constration camps is so real it hits home how bad the jews were treated.

Didnt go in.. This is by the Jewish cemetery, we didn't go in as it was expensive. Obviously would be more interesting to Jewish people or those with an interest in Jewish religion. Shops around the area are nice but slightly more expensive than the town.

Nice.... Much nicer than the old synagog but would not put it on the top of my list. Although the exterior isn't too outstanding, the interior is very colourful and decorated with lots of details. What I liked the most was the history behind the synagog and the Jewish community in Prague (none of which was explained to me at the synagog- I had a private tour guide)!

very moving. Be prepared to be very moved as this is a tribute the thousands who perised in the ghettos and camps in WW2. Well worth the cost of entry. You can by the tickets from a small book shop just around from the entrance as well as the ticket office. You cannot take photos in the synagogue or the cemetery. Do be prepared to be very moved as part of the exhibit is children's art.
a must see. The most beautiful synagogue i have ever seen. Simple and elegant. Worth the time..Lots of history..
Beautiful synagogue!. Intricate designs on all surfaces of the synagogue. Beautiful beyond imagination. Take a tour of the Jewish section of Prague.

In a word-Beautiful. Visited this place on my whirlwind tour of Prague Synagogues. Absolutely beautiful inside and out. The tiling on the ceiling and walls is gorgeous, and so is the chandelier. Later in the evening there was a concert, a violinist and piano player. It was ok, but nice to just sit in this gorgeous place and enjoy my surroundings.
Beautiful and interesting. On the 2nd floor there is a wealth of information on the Jewish population during the Holocaust. Be prepared to spend a lot of time if you want to read it all.
The most beautiful synagogue I have ever seen!. Amazing design all overWindows donated by many families inPrague before the Nazi regimeReally fills one with awe!A MUST!
Take a tour. We saw this synagogue with our Wittman Tour and I would suggest visiting the Jewish sites with them.

I loved it.. I went around this whole area on my last day > My feet were tired so I did not give it the time I should have. A place of beauty and sadness. The guetto in this area are highlighted. The building is splendid. I did the whole jewish tour around several of the synagogue (one ticket) get the hand held device for more information it is pricey but worth it for a fuller picture of the background to the buildings the people and the war.

Evening Concert at Synagogue. The building itself is truly beautiful. I visited at night for a concert so I was not able to see the upper part but I did enjoy the small museum cases on the lower floor. Even with the dim evening lighting the tiles and walls gleamed with a soft golden hue. This synagogue is lovingly cared for and it shows. The concert itself was excellent. The musicians and the female singer had great rapport and had just as much fun performing as we did watching.
Magnificent 19th C synagogue. Absolutely stunning synagogue with a must-see exhibition (on the second floor) of the history of Jews in Prague.

Beautiful building and decoration, interesting exhibition. We visited the synagogue while exploring Prague. It wasn't a planned visit, but those are often the best. The building is so beautifully decorated in Moorish style, with so much to see and admire, from the painted walls, arches and ceilings to the windows and lights. In addition there is a really interesting exhibition, which can be found on the ground floor and on the first floor, around the galleried area, dedicated to the history of the Jews in Bohemia and Moravia from emancipation to the present. The exhibition in the gallery is about the Jews in the Czechoslovak Republic between the two World Wars. It provides a good insight into how it was for Jews living there during those years and a good basis for our future visit to the Terezin concentration camp (outside Prague).
one of the synagogues but different. very different to the other synagogues, having an organ, and beautiful decoration. Small exhibition of jewish artists.

Beautiful, but sad. The beauty of this synagogue is quite unique. The shame is that too many tourists wander around taking too many pictures and one has trouble sensing how a religious place is misunderstood, by us. On the other hand, we also take part.The upper level has some showcases which include old documents and letters all related to the Holocaust, so one is able to feel the deep pain that came with those dreadful times, yet also appreciate that memories are held on to and that we should forgive, but not forget. A magnificent visit, very tops on my list of things to see when in Prague.

Ultra orniate and huge, one of Prague's many historic synagogues. Part of the multi-site State Jewish Museum complex, one of the most ornately decorated synagogues in the world. As with most of the synagogues, not currently in use, however they have concerts there many nites; we enjoyed a wonderful Gershwin/American music concert one evening (reasonable prices).

Perspectives on Jewish history. The building is interesting but everyone will say that. However, do go and look at the exhibition upstairs. Even if you are not Jewish you will find the history fascinating and, not a little, humbling. Just around the corner is the Robert Guttman Gallery which when I was there showed, simply and movingly, pictures and photos of all the synagogs that were destroyed by the Nazis and others.

Opulent. This is amazing sight. It shouldn't be missed. The Jewish sights in Prague are wonderful. But remember that Saturday is the Sabbath and they will be closed to visitors. The Jewish cemetery is truly moving. The history of this persecuted people is well displayed and recorded here.
Very beautiful synagogue. Very beautiful moorish interior and interesting museum of the holocaust. In the neighbourhood there also many more synagogues, if you are interested in the Jewish history.

Quite the best synagogue in Prague. I was surprised by how busy the Jewish quarter was on a drizzly weekday morning in early May. We trudged round the cemetery and the Ceremonial Hall and they were all okay, but the almost empty Spanish Synagogue was a revelation with its Moorish decor.

An architectural gem. This synagogue is a few blocks from the area where the other synagogues and the Jewish cemetery is located, yet it is also in the beautiful, and upscale area between Old Town and the river.As with the other synagogues nearby (buy a combination ticket and see everything) there is memorabilia and a retelling of the history of this community through religious objects and photos. But the star here is the Moorish architecture and decoration which should not be missed--it is definitely worth going inside. The Kafka statue next to the museum is also worth a look.

Great place for a concert. I went for the concert The best of Gershwin and must say that I enjoyed it. The main hall is very beautiful, very detailed painted and with lots of small details that would catch your eye. The acoustic was amazing as well. There were just 6 people playing but the sound was very clear and loud, without even a microphone. Last but not least, the artists are the masters of their work!!!

Beautiful and interesting. A beautiful building with a fascinating history. We went on a private tour organised by our hotel (the Intercontinental), which was well worth the money and was very informative about all the major Synagogues and the Jewish Quarter. Of them all, I think the Spanish is the best.

Amazing building. This Synagogue really has the wow factor. The outside of the building is a square box but inside of the building is decorated in the most amazing Islamic style decoration. Really worth seeing.

Beautiful.. This is a beautiful example of a Moorish 19th century building.While the synagogue is beautifully decorated inside, the guards enforce a 100% no photography policy, which is really a shame, as the interiors DO deserve to be remembered via photos.

Copy of Alhambra Palace that serves a synogogue. The 'Spanish' Synogogue in Prague is called Spanish because its interiors are designed on the template of the famous Granadian castle and palace Alhambra in Spain.It's worth visiting for the architecture and the records of Jewish people who suffered during the persecution by Nazi regime during the 1930s and 40s.

Stunning interior. The interior of this synagogue is stunning, like no synagogue I've seen, even in Israel. The exhibition of the history of the Jews in Prague was not only extremely interesting but left me very emotional. The only down side was the amount of youngsters, clearly on school trips, who, sadly, were not interested in all that history and blocked access to exhibits as they played games on their mobile phones

Beautiful. We did the Jewish museum and part of the places is the Spanish synagogue . Beautiful paintings of ceiling and walls makes this a must see. Cemetery and synagogue with names of all those who were persecuted are written and gives a huge appreciation for the devastation during this time . Not Jewish but interested in this Jewish quarter.
Just Go!. It's an odd sounding name. It is pretty simple on the outside, but the interior is magnificent. If you buy the package ticket for the cemetery and other sites it's deal you just can't beat.

Overcharged. Way to expensive for what it actually is.A beautiful Synagogue... And a cemetery ... The ticket is way too expensive for what it is (13€)... And they even charge if you wanna take pictures inside, or even go to the bathroom... It seems like they wanna squeeze every tiny little Euro coin out of the tourists...
Closed at lunch time - really??. Didn't get to see it as it was closed between 12 and 1pm! We were on a tight schedule so couldn't come back later.

Breathtaking!. This is one of the most beautiful buildings I have ever seen. I purchased a ticket for six sites in the Jewish Quarter, and all were worthwhile and moving. This was the last one I visited, and it was spectacular! The interior Moorish architecture and design is beautifully intricate. I could have stared up at the ceiling for hours. If you go on the Jewish Quarter tour, save the Spanish Synagogue for last. If you only have time for one site, this should be it.
So Beautiful I cried!. The detail in the synagogue are unlike anything else I've seen. An absolutely stunning building. Really magnificent. I highly highly recommend!
Nice synagogue. It was nice to see all the story of Czech Jews. Very self-explanatory.The problem is like in any other shul (synagogue), you can't take pictures/videos.

Very cool. I purchased the combo ticket so felt compelled to see all the synagogues. This one was the largest to me. Most ornate inside and out. If you only want to pay for one synagogue my choice would be this one.

Beautiful synagogue!. The Spanish Synagogue is a breathtakingly beautiful synagogue. I would have liked it if there were seats so that I could sit down and take in the beautiful building.This is part of the Jewish Museum, which includes the Jewish cemetery and the very moving Pinkas Synagogue. The ticket price seemed quite expensive (especially for a family of 5) but it was valid for two days. We were disappointed to find that the price we paid didn't include admission to the Old/New Synagogue. It would be nice if there was a flat rate for charges to attractions in Prague instead of a two tier type of ticket (we had the same experience when visiting Prague Castle)

Last, but not least!. This was the last of the Synagogues in the Jewish Quarter we visited. You enter the Spanish Synagogue through a non descript, contemporary looking structure, and I was concerned it would be the least impressive. Boy was I wrong!! It is absolutely beautiful inside. Turns out that entrance is just a side entrance for visitors. When you leave the Synagogue, make sure to walk around the side, which is actually the front. It's beautiful as well. A highlight of our tour of the Jewish Quarter!!

A thought provoking and moving experience. We saw this Synagogue as part of an outstanding and fascinating walking tour of the Jewish Quarter provided by Wittman Tours who we highly recommend. The Synagogue is beautiful and evocative

A Moving EXperience. The Jewish Museum is composed of this and several other buildings and synagogues. The exhibitions are so moving that I could not rid myself of thoughts of the Jewish experience for weeks after our visit. I would say that this is a must for visitors to Prague. This and the Kafka Museum. Together,they provide not only information about what happened, but also how people were affected psychologically and emotionally.

Disappointing site. Frankly, I was expecting something more interesting from what I found to present itself as just a fine synagogue. In combination with the Jewish Cemetery, IMHO not worth the cue at the ticket booth (and the steep, by Prague's standard, admission fee).
Wow!!. Do not miss this one. It is so lovely inside and the best synagogue of all the ones on the list in the Josephov quarter. Even the usual crowds did not dispel the beauty.

One of the best kept secrets of the Jewish quarter...a jewel off of the beaten path.. The Spanish Synagogue is really, really lovely inside in the Spanish, Moorish design. I didn't really like the fact that you couldn't take photos of anything, even without a flash. :(
a gem. not as busy as the other parts of the jewish quarter. great patterns and designs. would love to have been able to take pictures.

One-of-a-kind. The Spanish Synagogue was a one-of-a-kind place in downtown Prague. Though "Spanish," it is named that for the style, not for the worshipers. The interior was extremely ornate, with excellent exhibits on the second floor that chronicled the Jewish experience in Prague over time. This was our favorite of all of the synagogues in Prague and one you can't miss.

Beautiful Restored Synagogue. Be sure to take full advantage of the beautifully restored Synagogues across Prague, especially this one. No photos allowed, but it is worth the 30 minutes it will take you to get through it.

Interior is eye-candy!. While this synagogue has a well displayed history of the Jewish trials and tribulations in Prague, what made me drop my jaw to the floor was the interior decortation - the walls, the ceiling, the windows, even the organ. I understand why they don't allow pictures, but gosh, I wish I could use my camera in there!
Gorgeous religious site. This is a spectacularly beautiful syngague but it is disappointing that one is not supposed to take photos!
Most beautiful monument. Most beautiful monument in Prague with the Cathedral. The only bad thing is that it is not allowed to take pictures inside.

Well worth the extra effort. Decoratively stunning interior and the information about famous Czech Jews very interesting. A worthwhile addition to a visit to the Jewish cemetery and other synagogues and only five minutes walk away.
Classical Chamber Music - 5:30pm. Pay a bit to hear some chamber music in the synagogue - the music is outstanding and the inside of the synagogue outstanding...

Ravels Bolero. What a lovely way to start your evening,called here for the 5.30pm bolero concert was advised to arrive 15 minutes before hand as seating is first come first served,but dont worry there is room for everyone,plus you also get the chance to view the synagogue while waiting for the concert to begin.there was a quartet ,backing a lead violinist and all were at the top of there game,this was punctuated at intervals by a lady singing in soprano some well known songs and traditional jewish hymns.They all came back for an encore, which had the hairs on back of your neck tingling and still wanting to hear more,the whole experience was wonderful.

Gorgeous. Very beautiful and extravagant. It's a shame you can't take photos but to be honest they don't do it justice. I can't remember the cost (£4 or something like that) but it really is a must see. There is some interesting cabinets which tell the story of the synagogue especially through the second world war. Go have a little look.

If you only do one site in Josef Qtr, go here. You can buy a ticket to this building, or the general ticket that goes to the four synagogues and the cemetery. If you are short on time, this one building has a lot. Great building with Moorish revival mid-19th century decoration. Very fantastical with gilding and moorish designs and brightly colored wallpaper. There is an exhibition about Jews in Prague from medieval times to the present and the experience during WWII. There are photos and letters and small objects and drawings from the children etc. Don't miss the exhibit upstairs of the silver and treasures gathered from all of the synagogues by the Nazis. Fortunately it was not melted and it has remained as one group on display. Great shop as well with books and historical information as well as gifts etc.
Nice and special. Part of the Jewish Ghetto tour - liked it a lot.Entereance on the same ticket as other Jewish sights
Really interesting history.. Fascinating place to visit. We also attended a classical music concert here which was very good but wildly expensive.
Very nice place. The best part of old town of Prague is the orloj clock and the surrounding area. But once you are there, make sure you visit Spanish synagoga, a great place to see and visit.
Beautiful. This was a beautiful synagogue containing historical documents and religious items. Highly recommend a visit.

A must see. A very important reminder of the life and culture that were destroyed by the nazi beasts. The Alhambra-inspired decoration and architecture may not be to everyone's taste because they are somewhat too splendiferous if not over the top but they document the long history, sweet memories, dreams, aspirations of Sephardim Jews exiled from Spain after the Reconquista. The small museum is very interesting.
Magnificient Synagogue. The Moorish architecture is so lovely.! The colors were bright and vivid. There are few Synagogues as nice except for the Dohany in Budapest.

Breathtakingly beautiful. The Spanish Synagogue is a wonderful experience. The painted walls and ceilings, as well as the windows show exceptional craftsmanship and it's a real privilege to see it all.The synagogue also hosts an exhibition of Jewish history in Prague, definitely worth the hour or so to go through it.
Wonderful. We stopped here as part of a tour recommended by our hotel. It was a truly fascinating part of our trip and quite unlike any other synagogue I have seen before. Fascinating

Fantastic Concerts & Museum. This is a beautiful synagogue with a compelling museum exhibit. Their evening concert series is equally as entertaining. I attended "A Night of Gershwin" and was very impressed. The acoustics were outstanding.

Great artwork. Would have missed if it had not been for an recommendation by a friend. The interior is really nice, and far ahead of any of the other Synagogues in Prague. Definitely worth a visit. Quite annoying is that you can only visit the Synagogue with a Multiple-Site ticket (hence it will cost you around 12€ if I am not mistaken (this allows you to visit other sites, like the Jewish cemetry and two other synagogues but the spanish one is the highlight of the ticket). Also be aware the Synagogue is closed between 12:00-13:00 for lunch. As in the other locations you will get additional information on the Life of the Jewish population of prague in this case during the second world war.

Great interior. Went to hear a classical concert Bolero and enjoyed the experience greatly. The interior of the synagogue was amazing and brought back memories of the Alambra Palace in Granada. The music was great and the female singer had a wonderful voice. A very satisfying hour spent in wonderful surroundings.
Amazing. Amazing building shame you can't take photos inside. Lots of history regarding Jews in Prague and the Nazis. When reading the reports and seeing photos its pretty chilling.
Moving and spiritaul experience. Nice structure, the inner place is breath taking. Classical music concerts are taking place inside. The place is accessible with wheel chairs.

One of our best experiences in Prague. Had the pleasure of hearing a concert of primarily Gershwin (as well as other well known composers) in this stunning acoustically perfect setting. Absolutely memorable.
Spaniards in the works. The finest synagogue in Prague, in a tremendous Spanish-Moorish style of the late 19th century. Some good displays and photos of the Jewish community.

Definitely worth seeing. This was great - I would also recommend getting a tour of all the synagogues in the Jewish quarter. This is a must see including the Jewish cemetery and the Alt Neue Synagogue.
Amazing intricate moorish decor. This is definitely worth a look. Very unusual detailed decor and yet the overall impression is not 'over the top'

Visiting the jewish sites is a must do. As part of the jewish tour you need to visit this one. All sites together leave an imprint as the jewissh community got hit very hard in the 2nd WW but also in centuries before.

Stunning interior, and poignant exhibition.. Don't be fooled by the dull exterior of this synagogue, inside is a stunningly impressive and beautiful ceiling and wall decoration. The exhibition on the first floor is worth the visit and the WW2 section makes you contemplate the enormity of the Jewish suffering in Prague.Note entry into the Jewish Museum exhibits is only by cash, no cards accepted.

Saw this and other synagogues in the Jewish district. We had a good wonder around the jewish district but disappointed at the charges to go in and see everything. Having been to Krakow and toured their jewish district, this was quite expensive by comparison.

Historically interesting. If you are tight on time,you could skip this, but if you have the time, it's really a very interesting part of the city's history. We enjoyed walking around and reading the history.

Synagogue and Museum. It is one of 5 synagogues we visited. This one was the most beautiful, but don't let the title fool you. It is not a Sephardi synagogue- it is an Ashkenazi one built by Spanish architect/designer. On Friday night they house a conservative service, and during the week concerts are held in the sanctuary. It also houses an interesting museum of the history of the Prague Jewish community until the War when, sadly, virtually the entire Jewish population was destroyed.

Interesting stop. A different view of Prague than one gets from all of the Churches. There are seceral stops besides the Spanish synagog and one ticket covers them all. Make sure to see the cememtery.

stunning and awesome. It's amazing in Prague to turn a corner and find a gem from the past such as this amongst all the mansions and grand buildings! This is humbling in its sad history and reasons for still standing. Another astounding building in a city full of them.

Jaroslav Rona Sculpture "Kafka". Do not miss the very cool sculpture by famous sculptor and painter, Prof. Jaroslav Rona, one of the members of The Hard Heads, a group of revolutionary artists that helped stage a new years party at the Prague Castle in 1989-90, for President Vaclav Havel
Best of the Synagogues to visit in Prague. all the other synagogues are very minimalistic but this is very ornate. Moorish style interior, very unexpected.
Special place. Beautiful synagogue in Moorish style - we attended a Friday service there which was very moving. Ceilng is amazing

Great for a concert. This synagogue is a must in the Jewish quarter. Simply beautiful. We heard a concert here with musicians from the Prague Symphony Orchestra and it was fabulous, the acoustics were great.

you have to see it....... If you have any appreciation of history, this a stop you need to make. The interior of the building and the story that accompanies it is overwhelming. Plan on at least an hour or two to absorb the significance of this synagogue and the bizarre logic that prevented its destruction.

Place to learn about history of Jews in Czech lands. Unfortunately I did not have time to visit also other synagogues, but even visit of this only one taught me many details about the history of Jews. They have the exhibition explaining interesting details of their history - the most touching part for me: originals of letters and paintings made by children in Terezin ghetto, incl. photos of these, today no name, children that never survived the war. In the side room of the synagogue you can see the exhibition of silver objects used in church services. Worth for visit!

The most beautiful - and moving - synagogue.. We visited as part of the short tour of the Jewish quarter. The synagogue is absolutley stunning and contains artifacts from some of the children who were rounded up by Nazis in WWII. So moving!

Very special ceiling decoration. The exhibits are fascinating but the ceiling decorations are just superb. Well worth a visit even though the fees charged to go to the Jeiwsh Museum sites are not cheap.

Very beautiful!. Really worth a visit!Beautiful and rich architecture, and there is also an interesting exhibition in the second floor of the synagogue. It is highly recommended to purchase the tickets for all of the 5 Jewish sites.

Amazing - but no photos inside. It's called the Spanish synagogue because it resembles Spains Alhambra Palace. The interior is absolutely beautiful - but photos are forbidden which is a shame. I bought a ticket for a number of synagogues and the cemetery, which was valid for several days, but when I returned 2 days later they were all shut for a Jewish holiday. They could have warned me of this when I purchased the ticket.

A surprise. When visiting the old town, do visit the Spanish Synagogue, its name may be somewhat misleading, and do purchase the tickets for all of the Jewish museums in Prague..one ticket is good for 5 sites.

Spanelska Synagoga. A beautiful example of Sephardic architecture, history and Judaica. It was sad to see so many empty synagogues, where a once vibrant Jewish community of over 40,000 was decimated by the Germans during WWII, now there are only about 1,100 Jews remaining...sad.
prague sights. as soon as i arrived, i l, oved the old city square, especially since i had just come from Budapest, which was depressing
Josefov. The Josefov or Jewish quarter is peaceful and calm, besides the tourist noises. Interesting architecture and notable monuments, for example, the statue of F. Kafka.
Interesting. Part of the tour that includes the Jewish Cemetery and the other synagogues. The history is fascinating and the building stunningly decorated.

Well worth the visit. We visited the Spanish Synagogue on a ticket for all the sites managed by the Jewish Museum. It's a short visit, and they don't let you take pictures (although nobody really pay attentions) but it's well worth it to see the elaborately painted ceiling, altar, and the rest. Be sure to take some time to read the displays, particularly on the upper floor, as they have lots of interesting information about the Jewish community in Prague.
Wonderful place. We went there for a classical music concert.Music was good but lacking of emotion.Beautiful premises.

Concerts here are a treasure. We attended a Christmas Eve concert here and were so happy we did. The synogogue is simply beautiful, but not ostentatious like to many of the churches we visited. I would encourage you to attend any of the concerts here as the musicians and singers were excellent and the venue is very intimate. Buy your tickets in advance and show up at least 30 minutes early to get in line....seating is not assigned and people do push to get in the door!

My favorite of the synagogues. The Spanish Synagogue is beautiful inside. It's unique design inspired by the Moores stood out for me in comparison to the other synagogues in the Jewish quarter. If you are pressed for time and cannot visit all of the synagogues, make sure you visit this one.

Beautiful Building. We actually visited the Spanish Synagogue for an evening concert - it was at the end of a long and worthwhile day exploring the Jewish Quarter. By the end of the day, we had absorbed about as much history as we could manage, particularly one so fraught as it had been for the Jews of Prague, so ending with a concert in a beautiful synagogue allowed us to decompress a little, while still taking in some of the Jewish history of the city. Tip: bakeshop is nearby for a sandwich or a sweet treat.

We almost skipped this synagogue - glad we didn't. This synagogue had great displays about what happened to the Jews in Prague during World War II. It was inspiring to read the stories, horrible experiences but this is a part of history that we must never forget.

Beautiful!. Gorgeous place both from on the inside and outside. The only disappointment is that taking photos is forbidden (at least until the keeper lady steps out - that's when all the fun begins :))
Amazing building. Visited this building as part of a tour of the Jewish quarter. The inside of the building is really beautiful and well worth a visit.
Most beautiful of the 4. Magnificent synagogue, with wonderful decorations and interesting showcases: the most aesthetically beautiful of the four.

Christmas concert. An incredibly beautiful setting for a very special concert by five members of the Czech Symphony Orchestra and soloist Michaela Srumova. Highly recommended to anyone yet to visit Prague this Christmas.

A must see when in Prague Old Town. A magnificently decorated old building that is full of atmosphere and information relating to the old Jewish community in Prague up to and including the holocaust. Apart from the building itself take time to look at and read the touching and thoughtful exhibits throughout the synagogue all with English translations

History. A very interesting tour of the Jewish District,which visited the"Old/New" Synagogue and also the Spanish Synagogue and the Jewish Cemetery. We did this tour on our own and bought a ticket which gave us entry to the three sites

Wish we could take photos. The spanish synagogue is so beautiful. I enjoyed the decoration and all of the information they have on display. I just don't understand why they don't allow for pictures. It would be such a wonderful bonus to my trip to have great photos of these beautiful synagogues.

Beautiful decoration.. We had to respect the 'no photographs' policy, which is a shame, as the decoration inside is superb. The history of the holocaust is detailed in English and told a very powerful tale.

Spanish Synagogue. Value was the 5 site multi ticket to see the Jewish Cemetry and other Jewish sites. Allow 4 hours at least. The Spanish Synagogue was amazing inside ( for a synagogue ) and full of well explained history. All sites were no Photo, which was unusual, the rest of Prague no problem. Need change for the loos.

Important part of history. One of the few cities in the world who treat part of the Jewish heritage as top attractions in town.A kind of museum for a period starts at the 15th century up to World War II and the holocaust

Beautiful, Important Part of History. This is a gorgeous place and is very unique for a synagogue. It had a rather modest museum, but explained the relationship between Jews and Prague throughout history. Definitely shed a light on the quarter it is located in and on the inter-cultural relationship.
Nice. The Spanish Synagogue is stiuated very close to the old town square area and is always bustling with tourists looking to visit and appreciate the history.
very beautiful interior.. Lots to read and see in the way of artifacts and Jewish history, but for me the interesting part was seeing the very moving section on the war. Great cafe/bar opposite.

a must have experience. An experience that gave me the shivers. The synagogue is very beautiful and has a lot of decorations inside it which compensate the plain external of the building. I have learned more about The culture of my people, and how they dealt with all the difficulties in the second world war then all the the history lessons i have learned in high school.

concert. my friend and I saw this synagogue as part of a tour around all the synagogues ... which is a must do.... this synagogue is very beautiful... and also hosts concerts....we went to one ....magic!!!!! Go if you can. not cheap but worth the experience

Well worth the visit. Just loved the beauty of the inside of this synagogue. The history and information given throughout the building was very helpful in gaining some understanding of the religion and the Jewish area of Prague.
amazing. got the ticket to the Jewish cemetery and 4 other places and this was included. it was beautiful inside and well worth buying the entry ticket which was only £10

A must see!. The Spanish Synagogue has a very interesting exhibition on the life of the Jewish population – for years during the WW2, it served as a storage room for many items from the entire country. Now, some of these items are displayed there. If you are interested in the Jewish history of Prague and what is now Czech Republic, I suggest you buy the ticket that covers all the Jewish attractions in the Old Town. Start with the Spanish Synagogue and head to Pinkas where you can get an audio guide. The Spanish Synagogue is a masterpiece and I am positive you will be mesmerized with its interior. Pictures are not allowed (???) but can you blame myself for breaking the rules? It is such a beautiful place and I wanted to take some memories with me. Wanted to attend a concert there but time did not allow. Next time.

Concert at the Spanish Synagogue. The exterior of the building is very plain but once inside we marvelled at the beautiful ceiling and decorations. The concert was very good with a four piece orchestra and a opera singer. Worth the visit in every way

Wonderful tour of the Jewish Quarter of Prague. Opted for a guided tour in English and as we were the only two people who did we had a private guide. Our guide gave us a wonderful overview of the history of the Jewish people in Prague and answered all of our questions. I would recommend that you take the guided tour as their is some much to absorb.

Amazing!!!!. For me, tis is one of the most beautiful Synagogues in the word!!! But then, you will also feel the sad history of those who suffered with the Holocaust. It's a must see point, definitely!

WOW. I went here two times, the first time I was there for a concert, which I can recommend anyone to do when you're in Prague and the accoustics made it a concert that still visits me in my dreams. The second time I went to have a look at what it's got to offer and I can say it is probably one of the most beautiful synagogues I have ever seen. Well preserved and maintained, nicely decorated and the staff are also friendly and always willing to provide more help and explanations.

A monument charged with History. Breathtaking inside architecture and very impressive documents displayed all around, give this museum a very special appeal and flavor. Would suggest to buy the Jewish Museum comprehensive Tour ticket, which includes visit in all the highlights of the Old Jewish Ghetto.

The best of five. No doubt, this is the best of five synagogues that travelers can visit in the Jewish Quarter of Prague. Although the outside is not outstanding, the interior is magnificently decorated in moorish style. For those interested in the history of the jews in Prague, there are plenty glass boxes showing photographs, documents, books, and items related to jewish writers, musicians, scientists, as well as those that were killed by the nazis.

Jewish Quarter Package. The package to got to 4 synagogues and the cementry is worth getting as they are all different in style , but near enough to walk from one to another. Moving at times, with some well documented displays- another side to Prague and its history
Unique. This synagogue is beautiful, designed with a more Moorish look than traditional. Very modern for the times with an organ. It's a good location to begin a walking tour.

Very beautiful. Interesting display of Jewish historical memorabilia. The temple has very pretty woodworking. There is a charge for entry. We purchased the combined ticket for almost $25 per person and were told that it is good for 7 days with only one entry for each of the synagogues. Had I known this, I would have purchased the ticket my first day there and visited each facility at my leisure. Check to make sure that this is correct.

An elegant Jewel!. This delicious jewel of a synagogue gleams in blues and golds, its decor harking back to the days when Jews lived in harmony with the Moors of Spain, a true Golden Age of learning and interior decoration. A not to be missed beauty.
Stunning. What a beautiful synagogue. Really stunning with wonderful African/Moorish influenced decor. Very beautiful

Small, but beautiful. After seeing 20 or so of the over-the-top churches in Prague, it was a joy to see this small, but beautifully decorated synagogue in the old Jewish Quarter. No gold or statues, but intriguing middle eastern geometrics throughout the interior.
Spanish Synagogue. Exhibits were thought provoking, brought tears to my eyes, the building is beautiful. I am so gald we went there

Spanish Synagogue. This is a very interesting place and it is surrounded by even more interesting, though sad, things to see. it is the jewish Quarter and there are many buildings and museums right there together so all are easy to visit. One ticket can be bought at the sunagogue that gets you into several of the museums. This is both a wonderful and informative history of the jewish people in Prague and the upsetting history of the concentration camps of world war II. The whole visit including the synagogue is well worth a few hours. We hired a private guide through our hotel and she was most informative and had both history and little know stories to tell.
Intriguing building and history. This buidling has an intriguing history and lovely design inside. Definately worth a look if you have some spare time.
A must-see. A beautiful gem in the Jerusalem of Europe (i.e. Prague). The incredible culture wiped out by the Holocaust is memorably presented.
Interesting. Very interesting just expensive ticket :-( Recomend absolutely! There is big collection of historical things which come from Czech Republic.

Rich details in Spanelska Synagoga. Without doubt, one of the most beautiful synagogues in the Jewish quarter in Prague. Its interior, Moorish-style, reminds us of the Spanish palaces of the middle ages. There is also a touching exhibition of objects of the Bohemian Jews who perished in the Holocaust. and pay attention to the "Board of Ten Commandments" on the façade - beautiful.
A far-out impression. We went to five or six synagogues, and our 12-yo daughter was already complaining: Not another temple!, but the Spanish one really topped everything because it's so beautiful

OK, but other Synagogues more interesting.... Other Synagogues in the Jewish Quarter much more interesting. The Jerusalem Synagouge, small, but still in use, has a wonderful exhibit on the second floor.
Absolutely gorgeous synagogue. a must visit in the Jewish quarters of Prague. Beautiful intricate work all inside the ceilings and walls.
Spanish Synagogue. Again a very interesting area of Prague. It is in easy walking distance from Old Town were we were staying.

Unique and charming but not worth the money. 300cK ticket allows you to go to the Mainsel, Pinkas, Klausen and the Spanish synagogues.It also includes the cementery. The ceremonial hall is closed (when I was visiting in oct 2012. Need to pay extra money to visit the Old-New synagogue. You absolutely can no take any pictures not even without flash or use your iphone camera which is a bummer. I was not happy about that.

Stunning interior, lots of interesting historical information. We took the number 1 tour with an audioguide (3 synagogues, cementary, 2 locations were closed). Even though the audioguide is quite expensive (11 EUR), don't go on the tour without. The tour number 1 gave us a very good insight into the Jewish life and traditions in Prague before and during the Second world war. Traditional presentation but good coverage. The cementary was disappointing because of too little documentation. We spend three hours and wouldn't want to miss a minute.
Full of history. This is a stunning building and it has a very interesting and informative exhibition about the history of the Jewish population in Prague.

A little pricey but worth a look. Really pretty inside and they often hold concerts in there. There is war memorabilia in glass cases around the edges as the synagogue was used as storage for what the Nazis wanted to be a museum for Jewish culture. The Synagogue is also covered in the price of entry to the grave site so if you are going there anyway it is definitely worth a look.

Beautiful. We got into this Synagogue by going to a Gershwin concert here. It's a beautifully decorated Synagogue in the Moorish style. The acoustics were wonderful. They have concerts here with music by Jewish composers and it was fabulous. What an experience!

Amazing interior + interesting history. This is indeed an amazing building inside. The cabinets contain a very well laid out collection of background documents describing the history of the Jewish community in Prague over time. No photography allowed so a shame the range of materials available at the shop was limited.

More than just a synagogue. There are some religious artifacts and original documents. One postcard written in German to an aunt and uncle from a child send from Terezin reassuring all was well will haunt me forever.

A glimpse into a lost world. A view into the Jewish part of Prague that no longer exists and was snuffed out by the murderous Nazi regime. A reminder of the integral part the Jews played in Prague throughout the centuries. Thankfully, the buildings still exist.
MOORISH ART IN PRAGUE. I had never seen a synagouge in this style very decorated in a Moorish style. Very pretty. We didn´t go inside.

Fabulous - well worth a visit. The decor is extraordinary - don't miss it!! The silverware exhibit is wonderful too. The history of the czech Jewish community (especially under Nazi Germany) is very moving.
Spanish Synagogue was beautiful and historic.. Seeing the synagogues in the old Jewish Quarter, as well as the cemetery nearby.....fascinating and touching.
Beautiful Interior. The outside does not necessarily attract the visitor, but seeing the rich interior and its exhibits is a worthwhile experience.
Super concert venue.. We'd bought our tickets on line for the concert here.The venue was very beautiful and the accoustics were superb.Staff were welcoming and helpful.

A great intro to Jewish history in the region. I'm so glad I went. Not only is it exquisite, but it has so much information on Jewish life in Prague and the wider region including history and during the war then famous Jews from the Czech republic. I think there is a bit of something here for everyone.
very moving. This synagogue is the most infomatve of all the ones you can get access to. It explains the history in a good and fair way. Makes you realise what is important in life!

Stunningly Beautiful. This synagogue is stunningly beautiful and the cases with information about the history are very informative and enlightening. All the synagogues in the Jewish Quarter close for Shabbos and Jewish Holidays. Check before going.
Spanish Synagogue. The building itself was very impressive, very eastern, with lots of tile work. It contained an exhibition about Prague's Jewish History and the Ghetto. Very moving.

Interesting. We did a Jewish quarter tour for something different. The inside of the Spanish Synagogue was the highlight. I can't say it would be on the must see list. Be warned, no photography inside....you will be warned if you fail to see the signs.
Beautiful. We really enjoyed this well preserved synagogue, andwould be well worth the visit! We toured with a private guide who gave us a lot of interesting facts

Interesting interior and rich in history content. Did not think of going in to the synagogues, but bought the combined ticket and was very happy to have done so. The interior of the synagogue is unique, and the exhibition is full of interesting facts about life in Jewish Prague during the last centuries.
Very beautiful. This is the "prettiest" of the Synagogues that make up the Jewish Museum in Prague. The silver display upstairs is worth going up to see too.

Lovely and so interesting to visit. Me and my boyfriend had a wonderful afternoon visiting the synagogues. Get the see everything priced ticket. I love learning about other peoples religions and found it to be very enjoyable.

impressive. it was the first time for me visiting a Synagogue and i think this was the perfect one. i was impressed by everything. it's a beautiful temple and the details interesting. and also a lot of information about the jewish personalities . there is also an exhibition of silver Judaica. the temple looks like an ancient one. i recommend it. but in order to visit you have to buy all the tour on the jewish museum.
Overvalued. Too expensive, a bit boring. I would not do it again. The audio tour is a robery. Praga is too beautiful to spend the time in these Sinagoges

Quite interesting. The whole Jewish Quarter, including the cemetery are very interesting and gives a good emotional picture of how the jewish people have been treated during the 2nd world war. Even if you are not Jew! After all, we are all human beings!

Well maintained and really interesting. This synagogue is only one building of many that can be found in Prague. If you wanna visit it you have to pay (sorry but I don't remember how much) and you can choose if you wanna pay for visiting this synagogue alone or all the jewish buildings inside the Jewish area GET THE TICKET FOR ALL THE BUILDINGS! You can spend the hole day just visiting all these buildings, all of them are really interesting and well maintained and you can walk around all the jewish area since all the buildings are spread around the zone.

Why can't I take photos?. It really is a beautiful small synagogue (still actively used) in a style I've never seen before. Much smaller inside than I expected...but...why can't I take photos. The spectacular synagogue in Budapest has no such restriction.
Spectacular decor. Part of the Jewish museum and its associated synagogues, it is a spectacularly decorated building. An excellent exhibit about the Jews of Prague.

Truly magnificent!!!. We saw a musical concert in this synagogue. It is like a wall to wall feast for the eyes. Do not miss this. Preferably do the concert as well, as this is one of our best memories of Prague and the music compliments the grandeur.

The most lavish synagogue.. The synagogue is the most recent & the most lavish one built in Moorish style inspired by Spain's Alhambra Palace. The interior is in bright colors & exhibits the documents, photos, & religious objects.
Stunning. Beautiful historic building and very unusual architecture. We didn't go in but definitely worth a look from an open top car tour.

Prettiest synagogue in Prague!. This museum in a synagogue tells the story of the plight of the Jewish people in Prague. It is comparable to the Holocast Museum in Washington, DC. Especially sad for me was what happened to the innocent children. Don't miss this!

Worth a visit. Beautiful building with an excellent exhibit - particularly the upstairs part - on Jews in Prague and the Czech Republic in the years before and during WWII. Admission was a reasonable 70 czech crowns.

Most Beautiful Synagogue in Prague. If you bought a complete ticket for Jewish quarter you may feel a bit disappointed until you see the Spanish Synagogue (We had left it to last) but then Spanish Synagogue will indulge you with its fancy, oriental interior design. Both interior and exterior of the building is quite astonishing. Stained glasses are beautifuk
Marvellous. Very big synagogue in the end of the trip in the jewish quarter. at nights there are shows there Classsical music...the inside is very reach and remind me of a big church.

Beautiful!. The Spanish Synagogue was so, so beautiful. The decorated walls and beautiful detailing on the woodwork was a real site to behold. I visited all of the synagogues in the Jewish Quarter and would recommend buying the ticket which allows admittance to all of the synagogues as the history and the difference between them is something very special. One recommendation and one warning though! Recommendation:Classical music concerts are held each night at the Spanish Synagogue and the atmosphere is wonderful. The music was beautiful and it was well worth buying a ticket (this cost 700Kč). The concert lasted for an hour. Warning: You aren't allowed I take photos in any of the synagogues which can be disappointing especially as they are so beautiful. However, for some reason, if you go to the concert you can take photos so that's one way round it! A spiritually meaningful place with an interesting historical exhibition attached.
very interesting. gives you a full history of jewish community in Prague. an impressive display of the historic artifacts.
Wonderful historic interior. The outside looks much simpler so the interior is a surprise. Really great with a lot of historical information. Very inspiring.
Excellent record of the Jews in Czech Republic. loved the stories of various people and the photos of movements through time to show the struggle of Jews in Czech Republic and neighboring countries.

Sad monument of a community. Over my stay I visited all Jewish community monuments in Prague. This synagogue is lovely and well preserved, with beautiful vitrages in the windows and ceiling frescoes. Currently it serves as a moving museum for the Jewish community's history during WWII. It is very sad that it apparently no longer serves as a real synagogue.

Another Piece of history. Next to the prominent statue, this synagogue is one of the oldest, with a Jesus on the crucifix placed in a tree outside. I did not go inside but it was located on a nice street - easily accessed from my hotel and a lovely short walk.

Thought provoking. We spent a whole morning visiting the JOSEFOV area and went inside the various synogogues , , so thought provoking , beautiful exhibits toi see and very tastefully put together, my mind was opoened up to things that i didnt know very much about , buy a ticket for 300 czks and see everything

Jewish Quarter. A visit to the Jewish Quarter is a must, even if you are not Jewish. You can learn so much history and about the segregation of Jews. We met a lovely woman who gave us a personal tour of the Old New Synagogue and we learned so much from her. We saw another site where 80,000 names of victims of the Holocaust are inscribed. So much senseless death. The Spanish Synagogue also offers concerts since it is not a synagogue that offers services. Buy a ticket for the whole complex. You can use it more than one day so you can visit all the buildings. The cemetery is memorable as well: 100,000 people buried there because they were not allowed any other burial grounds.

Beautiful interior but overrated. Although the interior has a beautiful mosaic on the walls and ceiling I think the cost of admission to all of the Jewish quarter buildings are far too high for what is inside. Maybe seeing a concert here would make it worthwhile, I don't know.
Very impressive Synagogue in Prague. Be sure to visit this and the other 4 adjacent synagogues to get a sense of Jewish life in Prague before the holocaust and the impact it had.

great venue for a concert. we visited this venue to attend a concert (classical + gershwin - a different combination that works). the building is over-the-top impressive, specially for a synagogue. just like the concert, it is an eclectic collection of decorative motifs that radiates joy.
Impressive. Impressive, unbelievable until you see it. The architecture is very particular, and the exposition about jews history in the country interesting.
Nice. The Spanish Synagogue has beautiful interiors with elaborate styled interiors. It has a Moorish architectural style and is used as a museum...
Must see even if you are not Jewish. Part ou Europe's sad history, a good lesson for tolerance. The visit takes about 20 minutes. Go to see the old cimetery afterwards.

Amazing Place. What an amazing place! You have the feeling entering The Tales of the Arabian Nights'. The Synagogue is so beautiful. It is not used anymore for service but for concert and exhibit. A must-do when in Prague.

Beautiful. A little different in looks and design to the other synagogues, worth a visit. The one thing I did not like was you had to buy a ticket for all parts of the Jewish Area, not just individuals synagogues or sites.

Important part of the Jewish Quarter. The Spanish Synagogue is a very good interpretive site that gives a good idea about the Jewish community in Prague. The whole Jewish Museum, a complex of synagogues and sites within the Jewish quarter, is available through a museum pass. I started my tour there. I highly recommend the Spanish Synagogue in particular and the whole Jewish museum.
This was beautiful and unique!. I'm glad I had a chance to see this synagogue. It is different from most synagogues and very beautiful!

Classic Spanish Design. Fully restored and very old. It was mentioned in the book, "The Lost Wife", as a store house in WWII for Jewish citizens of Prague to shed their valuable belongings, by order of the occupying Germans.
Historical lesson. Impressive looking interior coupled with a very informative exhibition about the history of Prague, and the that of Jews in the city.

Beautiful building with moving collection. Beautiful Moorish style synagogue on the north side of old town. We got the combo ticket to see all of the Jewish sites. Upstairs is a wonderful display of artifacts and presentations. Recommend touring all of the Jewish sites to get the complete story.

Wonderful geometric interior. A welcome respite from the christian baroque and rococco opulence. It's easy to see the moorish influence in the geometry. The Jewish Quarter ticket includes all but the Old-New Synagogue and lets you avoid long lines at the cash ticket booths.Each synagogue details a different bit of jewish culture and history and gives a great english and czech descriptions of the items.

Worth a visit with a guide. This synagogne is in the Jewish Area of Prague which should be seen with a guide. The history is fasinating. The Spanish Synagogue is the most beautiful, unfortunately we visited on a Saturday so were unable to see inside. A visit to the cementry is a must

Jewish quarter and museums are run by non friendly people.. I am Jewish and brought my kids to see Jewish history of Prague. The tickets are super expensive, there is very little information or explanation as to the WWII history, and you must buy a second ticket to the Alt net synagogue, where the Golem remains in the attic. The ticket sellers and vendors are devoid of emotion, appearently not Jewish or even caring non Jews, and there is a small street that sells trinkets, made in China junk, and blares loud rap music right outside the synagogue. It seems that the Czechs should do more to honor what to Jews is a very poignant historical place and not let it turn into a purely commercial area. There was no soul or pathos left in the area, and I really resented the unfriendliness of all involved. I had done extensive research into the Prague Jewish quarter, and have to say that out of all the places I visited in German and Poland, Prague's Jewish area is the most crass, commercialized and disrespectul of all the Jewish sites in Central Europe. If you are Jewish and go there, please tell me if you think I am wrong about this.

Piece of History. Really well preserved synagogue which is now a musuem I believe. I went there for a concert and the acoustics and atmosphere were great. Once part of the thriving Jewish community in Prague which the Nazis put paid to.

Must see. It is amazing to follow the history of the Jewish people in Europe, especially in Prague, where so many Jewish places survived WW2. The Spanish Synagogue is one of the most beautiful sacred houses I've visited. Spend time looking at the detailed work on the walls and columns.
Stunning building. We listened to a concert in this beautiful building. The walls and ceiling are very detailed and the accoustics were good.
The Best. No pictures inside the synagogue but if you have a iphone you can give it a try, remember also to walk to the first floor, great silver work and beautiful view to the roof of the synagogue
Historical. My sons were a little stunned over the fact what happened in the church and with the jewish community during World War 2. I think it's good that they get to learn about our history!

Marvellous, with its "Andalousian" style. Don't miss it. Really. This synagogue is different, with its reminiscences of Andalousian synagogues (in Seville, Granada and Toledo), its guilded details.If you can attend any concert there, so much the better. I attended a sextet playing Gershwin and it was heaven (in spite of being a bit expensive).
very educational and special. Touching memorabilia, history and a lot to think about. Take your time reading documents and absorbing all the information.

Too expensive. Do not waste your money on the Prague Jewish museum, consists of this synagogue, 3 others and the cemetary. Way too expensive for what you see also you cannot even walk around the area: It is all walled in! Rather book a trip to Terezin and see the camp and prison. You will learn the whole story that way at also the same price.

Beautiful interior, it's a pity that photos are not allowed. I have never been to a synagogue before so the whole experience is quite interesting to me. The interior deco is lavish and the silver collection on the second floor is surely an eye opener. You can buy a ticket here that gives you access to almost all the attractions in the Jewish Quarter here rather than buying the same ticket at the Jewish cemetery, which you will face a long queue. No photos are allowed to be taken inside the synagogue, which is a pity, but it's still worth the visit.
Interesting Place. The decoration of the Synagogue is quite fascinating. You should definetly visit the Synagogue if you are around the area. It is a nice place with interesting art.

Tour the Whole Jewish Quarter. Don't just stop at the Spanish Synagogue although it's beautiful and not to be missed. But also see the Old/New Synagogue and some of the others and walk through the cemetery. You can purchase one ticket that gets you into almost all of these sites and it's worth the price of admission.
go for the spectacle of it. you have never seen anything like it....I have seen many synagogues but never anything as ornate as this one...wow!

Outstanding. Walking through the Synagogue is just as astonishing as walking through the various cathedrals and churches in Prague. There's so much history here and Prague was the key area for Jews in Central Europe at that time. It's absolutely beautiful. And, definitely visit the Jewish Cemetery as well. Also full of amazing history.
Spanish Synagogue. Probably, one of the most beautiful sinagogues in Europe. Not too large, but blindingly beautiful. Important part of European Jewish Heritage
The most interesting inside. Only go in if you bought the ticket for the Jewish museum and see the 6 sites. this synagogue and the cemetery were the best parts.
Spanish Synagogue. The most impressive and beautiful synagogue of the whole Jewish Museum in Prague and one of the most beautiful in Europe. Upstairs a display of silver jewish relics.

Synagogue tour. This synagogue is very ornate and worth a visit. There are four synagogues in the centre and we saw them all. We did a walking tour of the old jewish area and it was very educational and fascinating.
FANTASTIC!. What a beautiful synagogue. Buy a ticket that covers all the other attractions and see them all. You won't be disappointed.
Beautiful and moving. The old synagogue is lovely and the permanent display showing the history of the Jews of Prague is informative and very moving.
Very oriental and interesting. It is quite unusual to see such an "exotic" building and Prague and I am proud we have it here. :-) Recommend to visit it.

Synagogue as museum and concert hall. Moorish architecture, Islamic-style patterned walls. A sumptuous interior. We attended a concert at the synagogue one evening (Carmina Burana, Bolero, etc.) In a country where 90 percent of the people are non-religious, it's great that the old synagogues and cathedrals have become places for music, performance and gathering.

Impressive synagogue. Despite the name, this was always an Ashkenazi synagogue, built in the "Moorish" style. While it does not have the emotional history of some of the other nearby synagogues, it is pretty and is close to the other synagogues, and is worth a visit.
Remarkable. This synagogue resembles the Alhambra in Granada, Spain in its beauty. I would also recommend to visit all the other synagogues.
Cloosed saturdays ( sabbat). Paying, but no possibility to go back an take a look at something interesting or take pictures...

Part of History. The Jewish section of Prague is a must see, with the Jewish population of most of Eastern Europe being decimated due to the Nazis and WW II, the Jewish history and exhibits in Prague and other parts of Eastern Europe are important for both Jews and non-Jews to see and understand.
beautiful. beautiful , the most beautifull we saw. Worth a visite
Beautifull. We did the Synagogue tour and this was the last one. It is beautifully decorated in the Moorish style and has a very interesting Jewish exhibition

Beautiful and full of history. Don't be fooled and just buy the ticket to this synagogue. The rest are not worthwhile the package ticket of $25. Don't miss the second floor. It has a lot of history about Jews during World War II and it's aftermath

Beautiful and historical. Perhaps obscenely opulent, and the exhibits are a bit dry, but there's no questioning that this is a beautiful building. Rather pricey though... As are all of the synagogues in Prague's Jewish Quarter. Compared to other attractions, it is massively expensive.
The details of its unique architecture is amazing. Please visit this place and spend some time looking the details of its unique architecture. It is really beautiful.
Do not miss. Steeped in history and a fascinating visit. A must on your sightseeing list
A special building!. Went to a concert there one evening. They let you take photos then which they don't during the day. Absolutely beautiful!
Beautiful synagogue. The architecture of the Spanish Synagogue is striking. The scope of the building indicates the size of the congregation it served.
Do visit. Well maintained with a very interesting exhibition of the wartime experience

Old new Synagogue was wonderful to see. We went to the Jewish quarter and walked around but only paid for the Old New Synagogue. It was worth the price to see the old sanctuary and sit for a few minutes in contemplation.

What an amazing synagoge. We watched a classical concert in the evening in the Spanish Synagogue and all I can say is that I would thoroughly recommend it. It was simply wonderful and everyone gave them a standing ovation. We saw a string ensemble but they have different programmes each night.

Average attraction - overhyped. We went to the Jewish quarter with a lot of hope. It has a set of 7 museums of which the Spanish Synagogue is a big one. We felt it was over-hyped and the ticket too steep.

Great Historical Journey. The Spanish Synagogue is beautiful and provides a lot of historical information. It is included in a group of historical Jewish locations, including other temples and the Jewish Cemetery. All provide great insight into Prague's history during the Holocaust.

Not as big as you think..... After seeing many churches, I was surprised by how small the synagogue was. The details are beautiful though and the artistic value is worth seeing. I particularly liked the historical sites on the second floor as many of the artifacts were explained and I was able to understand more of the Jewish traditions. Worth walking around this area to see the Jewish Cemetery and the other synagogues too.

What Time are Services?. I think this could change, but if you want to attend a service in this beautiful structure, come on Friday at 6 p.m. in winter, 7 p.m. in summer. The congregation is called Bejt Praha, and the website is http://www.bejt-praha.cz/aj_o_nas.html. We were there in June and joined several locals and tourists for the Friday night service. Seating was mixed, and the style of service was close to U.S.Conservative. There's no "eruv" in Prague, but ladies had their purses (I think this used to be the European style of observing Shabbat). The crowd was friendly, and the atmosphere relaxed.We had visited the museum part and had admired the architecture before we attended the service, but if you're Jewish and want to greet some of the Jewish community in Prague, this is one place to go.Like many European synagogues, this one has security agents to quiz visitors who come for services, of course.
Loved the Colors. This synagogue's most interesting feature for me was the color.
Jewish Quarter. This is just one of the many fantastic places to visit during a tour of the Jewish Quarter. So much history and such beautiful architecture.
magnificent. Magnificent synagogue, a must see. Pay for all-included tour of Jewish quarter and see Old-New Synagogue, Jewish cemetery and this.
Old-New Synagogue. The oldest one in Europe I guess. Very close to the old town. A definite must-see.
Opulent. What a statement of wealth and a celebration of God. Very moving to see the collection of Jewish artefacts from all over Europe.

Spectacular and Sobering. The first thing you notice when you walk into the Synagogue is the grandeur of the decoration. It is definitely the prettiest of the Synagogues in the city.However, when reading all the descriptions and stories on the display cases dotted about the room, you are again brought down to earth with the details of the horrors that this Synagogue has lived through. The information about the Holocaust, like the other Synagogues in Prague, is both fascinating and heart-breaking. A must visit for fans of History, Art, and Architecture.

Very moving and beautiful. This was just gorgeous. And it's interesting to know their is three times more gold in there than in their national museum. Take the time to go to the first level and read the facts. It's very moving and very educational

Memorable experience. A visit to the Jewish Quarter is a must. The history of the Jews in Prague and in other parts of the country is incredible. Be prepared to shed a tear or many. One can't help but to be touched by this experience. We will never forget!

Amazingly decorated. Stunningly, intricate decoration with quite interesting exhibition including silver collection. The exhibition could be better, as could the rest of the Jewish Museum venues, but it was fine and the actual building is stunning.
Great setting. We attended a small concert with a string group and a wonderful soprana. The interior of this synagogue is amazing with every wall and ceilling intricately decorated.

Beautiful synagogue. We toured the Spanish Synagogue as part of the Jewish Quarter ticket package. We were able to tour five locations for 300 CZK for adults and 200 CZK for students. We were very disappointed not be able to take photos. It was built in 1868 in a Moorish style and was restored in 1998. The synagogue houses the second part of the "History of the Jews in Bohemia and Moravia". Upstairs is a large display of silver that the Nazis stockpiled.

A real gem. This synagogue is just... Beautiful. It differs from any other synagogue, or church, or mourish building you have ever seen. The combination of jewish tradition and spanish-mourish architecture is just mind-blowing! Too bad it is forbidden to take pictures inside. As with the other buildings in the Jewish Museum, this one also has a permanent exhibition and lots of texts to read about Jewish history.
in jewish quarter. is nice to see all the synagogues but theyre not mazing unless your jewish and understand it all
Very beautiful. Amazing interior but unfortunately you can't take pictures.

Part of Jewish Museum in Prague. This synogogue is part of the tour of the Jewish section of Prague. It is really an important thing to do in Prague. When you buy a ticket for the Jewish cemetary, you buy a ticket for all the synagogues except one (the old-new). This building is not as old as the others but really beautiful. It reminded me of the old synagogue in Toledo, Spain. It is a museum today and worth going to.
Memorable Site. The synagogue is a must-see, as it is so beautiful and tells such a story along with the other synagogues in the vicinity.

Interesting visit. The history of the Jews in Prague was very interesting. We bought a single ticket as we did not want to visit all the synagogues. Wwe would have like to visit the Jewish cemetery but unfortunately you couldn't buty a single ticket - only part of a packaget

A different style of synagogue with an important exhibition. As the details state this has been built in a Moorish style and differs markedly from the other synagogues and ex-synagogues that you can visit.This synagogue has an exhibition that covers the occupation of Prague during the 30s and 40s as it was used as a storage facility for many Jewish items, not a happy exhibition, but worth viewing.

Costly but worth it. We got the ticket at the Pinkus Synagogue so you had to pay for the five sights. The Spanish Synagogue was beautiful plus the information it has is extensive and most of which I have never seen before. Prague is a unique place and has a different Jewish history which was very interesting to read about. Pay the money and go!

Educational. We did the full visit to all the elements of the Jewish Museum and it was heartbreaking. The three rooms of names just reminded me of how lucky we are today. The information in the synagogues was excellent and a fascinating insight into the history not only of the war period but further back. An extremely educational place and worth every peny and minute we spent visiting.
Wow!. We went to a concert here, (the best of Gershwin)and were blown away with the musicians talent and the synagogue! Amazing!

Just Beautiful. The entire Jewish quarter is worth a visit but this synagogue with all of its beautiful tile work is a must see. We is also where we viewed all the beautiful silver peices which were religious in nature. They had some volunteers there that explained the uses of some of the peices for us. The Jewish cemetary is not too far and worth it!
Moving. We visited all the Synagogs and were very moved by the story they all told. It is a must to tour the Old Jewish Quarter and to see what the have had to put up with.

Jewish life in Prague. Most Czechoslovakian Jews perished in the Holocaust, but the synagogues have been brought back to life as museums dedicated to Jewish culture. The Spanish Synagogue is the most beautiful of all the synagogues. One ticket will get you into nearly every Prague synagogue (but ot into the Holocaust Museum which is in another part of the city and well worth a trip). Remember that the story of the Golem started in Prague!
must see. a bit of a walk from the Jewsih cemetery, but worth it. Wonderful displays, Moorish beauty
Beautiful building , book the concert , great location to enjoy some light classical music. Very unusually decorated synagogue. Lovely concert was a great way to spend the early evening in Prague.
Amazing architecture. The interior of this building is magnificent! It is worth doing a guided tour of the Jewish quarter to find out more about this whole area

Beautiful and interesting too. I'm a fan of all things moorish and the spanish synagogue is gorgeous. The exhibition on jews in Prague was excellent and despite the crowds milling all around the city, I felt I was able to take my time and appreciate the exhibits and artefacts.

Striking and unusual Synagouge. Most Synagogues place a much lower emphasis on beauty compared to churches, and are typically not very interesting visually. This one, however, is truly striking, with intricate detail everywhere, done in the Moorish style.Inside there's also a small exhibition with explanations of the history of the Jews in Bohemia, with documents and books from various periods - very interesting.

Fascinating history. Don't miss this. The interiors are spectacular and were an interesting contrast to the other synagogues in the Jewish Quarter we toured. The history display on the second floor is fascinating and tragic.

impressive. This is the most beautiful synagogue in Prague. Buy a combined ticket for the synagogues and the Jewish museum. If you have little time and have to choose between, visit Spanish Synagogue. It is a pity that they do not let to take photos in any of these places.
Beautiful experience!. Great atmosphere and luxurious interior. Very interesting history. We really injoyed the combination of classical music and opera withing the walls of this synagogue.
Tough walk up the stairs but well worth it. The view from the top alone is worth it. The history and beauty is amazing.
LA MAS BONITA. LA SINAGOGA MAS BONITA DE PRAGAThe most beautiful synagogue of Praga

amazing interior. Went in the evening to a hear a concert. Three violins, a cello, double base and trumpet, playing tunes from the best american musicals. The designs on the wall are beautiful, and like many building in Prague a lot older than many other "occupied" cities.
So beautiful. Amazing interior, so intricate and stunning! Colors are fantastic, too bad you can't take photos inside. Also lovely historical artifacts for viewing.

Can buy as part of Jewish museum ticket or separately. This synagogue is beautiful on the inside and the upstairs has an exhibit on the History of the Jewish community in the Czech Republic with English signs. There was also an exhibit of the silver items that were taken from synagogues by the Nazis.
