You can buy a ticket as part of the Jewish Museum ticket which allows entrance into several places or you can buy a Spanish synagogue ticket for 70czk. The No Photos policy was aggressively enforced.
The nicest synagogue in Prage. One of the most beautiful locations in Prague! Inside a museum of jews history is located with interesting exebition.

Incredible moorish interior. If you love moorish architecture, this has to be a stop on your itinerary. After visiting the many "traditional" churches and cathedrals in the area, this one is refreshing for how different it is. You do have to buy admission as part of the Jewish Museum ticket but it is worth it. The only negative is they don't let you take pictures, and their postcards just don't do it justice. Kafka's statue is right out front as well.
Great history. Go with a guide for the background info. Jewish quarter generally very interesting and partly sad.

Photos. Very photogenic, but lookout for ex communist block wardens manning the anti-photo patrols. You are expected to buy a photo permit, talk about rip off. There are quite a few Synagogues but just visit this one
Great concert venue. Went to an evening concert here. A beautiful structure excellently restored to its original glory. Rich heritage. Very good acoustics. worthwhile visit
Amazing. Don't want to spoil the surprise by saying too much but the interior is decorated in an amzing way. We also listed to a classical music concert there which was worth doing
Lots of history here. Worth it just to see the Moorish style painted walls and ceilings. But also a large collection of museum quality artifacts that reveal the long history of the Jews in Prague.
Moving experience. The story of a lost culture is always sad, the good news is that it is preserved in this place

Impressive design. Moorish design, like the Alhambra or churches in Spain that once were Moorish mosques. Suggest engaging a tour guide to take you through all the synagogues and the Jewish cemetery. There's really no way to understand the key aspects of this and the Jewish Quarter without a guide.

Unusual synagogue with moorish architecture and interesting history. I watched a classical performance of Gershwin favorites and although the stage is not meant for doing a classical performance, the synagogue had v good acoustics and it is very beautiful inside. Definitely an experience not to be missed.
Very touching visit. Prepare to be touched right threw the heart...It's a must to visit.
Step into a world we could hardly imagine. It is a time warp that gives you an opportunity to see what was an absloutely glorious period. Followed by one of humanity's darkest hours...
went on Shabbat (Saturday). there were services and a minyan. People were quite friendly. Security was appropriate and well done.

a wow. A lovely design with impressive wall decoration -- geometric, as they couldn't represent people or animals for religious reasons. Side displays with historical notes and pictures about the Josefov ghetto and the fate of the Jews during and after WWII

Nice balance of history and architecture. As part of the synagogue tour, we were impressed with the beauty of the interior as well as the exhibits describing the history of Jews in Prague. Not as somber as other attractions, but it gives a enough information for a visitor to appreciate the plight of Czech Jews.
Spanish Synagogue. A beautiful interior but the charge for visiting all of the Jewish buildings was very high.
Beautiful. Fascination history, well worth seeing all the synagogues in the tour.
Wonderful Synagogue. This may be our favorite building in Prague. The building is built in th "spanish style" of the day for non-spanish Jews. Beautiful workman ship, very worth seeing.
Great!. Was there in the evening, I was stunned by its outlook, it is big and very very pretty. Although you have to pay to go inside, yes, it is worth.

Moorish interior. The synagogue, from the XIX century, has a particular Moorish design, that give to it a special ambient. It has an access fee, you can not take photos inside, and it is included on the Jewish Quartier Tour. The Josef Kafka statue it is close to the entrance.
synagogue. steeped in history. Lovely old feel about the place.
ornate beauty. Interesting artifacts most intact synagogue in group to make up Jewish museum. Silver artfacts and exhibits on WW Ii activities in area. Go early fills up with school children by 11am.
Quiet and relaxing.-. A good programme for families and individuals. Use the FUNICULAR to go up and just walk to go till the Castle or Charles Bridge. Amazing programme.

beautiful. This is a beautiful synagoge in the style of the Muslims from spain (like Alhambra). Nice decorated, beautiful coulours. Really a pity that you are not allowed tot take pictures, also not without flash. The guards are really keen on that!
Trip to Andalucia in Czech Republic. Once inside the synagogue, the first thing that impresses is its rich architecture. And the second thing that impresses are the testimonies of Holocaust
Beautiful. Great as part of the Jewish quarter tour. Lovely ceiling and ornamentation
Breathtaking. An incredible experience. The synagogue was so beautiful and the information as walked through was sobering

Amazing Jewish Cemetery. This was a fascinating location that should not be missed. The synagogue itself is devoted to the memory of those lost in WW2. However, the ancient cemetery is the legendary site of where the Golem is buried. Don't miss it!

Beautiful, but pricey. The Jewish Quarter venues were fine but expensive and too crowded compared to other venues in Prague.. Even the toilet prices were double everywhere else. They even charged for picture taking in some areas. I would suggest many other sites before these if you are limited for time. They tell you that you have 48 hours to see all the sites, but then they close on Saturday. Also they do NOT take credit cards.
named because of the decor-not the people. the building is beautiful. the area is overwhelming and well worth the visit!
Beautiful. The synagogue is stunningly beautiful. A real highlight of my trip.

Must do.... Please do Roman Billy's tour of the Jewish Quarter. You will be humbled and intrigued. The synagogue is special, being the oldest synagogue in Europe, built in a Spanish style of architecture.
Only saw the outside. Didn't go in as I am neither Spanish nor Jewish, the outside was unremarkable but cannot comment on the interior obviously.

avoid the tourist groups. this is an amazing building although small so it can get too crowded to see all the exhibits when there are more than 2 groups of tourists. Ornate and well worth the walk into the quarter where other synagogues are also worth a look - most not so ornate.
spanish synogogue. out of all the synogogues this was definitely the best one to visit, stunning to look at and interesting information inside.fee payable
Jewish tour. Jewish walking tour worth going on. Beautiful building and interesting displays of local Jewish history.
well worth it. We saw all of the synagogues in the Jewish quarter but the design it the Spanish Synagogue was quite unique. Also - make time for the Old Jewish Cemetary.
Christmas Concert. Beautiful and if you can catch a concert there, its worth the money!

Very fine.. I cannot really speak about the Synagogue itself because I only attended a concert there which was held in a part of it. The concert was excellent and my wife and I really enjoyed it and the hall where it was held beautifully decorated.

Most beautiful of Synagogues. We visited with our Jewish Museum combo ticket, and I can honestly say this was the most worthwhile site in my opinion. Visually it has a very stunning interior, despite it's off-putting and somewhat modern appearing exterior. I would have been left extremely disappointed with my whole Jewish Museum experience had I not seen this Synagogue. In retrospect, I wish I had ONLY purchased a ticket for this site alone.
A burst of colour. Not only the interiors are splendid, but the exhibition on the balcony is very moving
Gorgeous architecture, moving history. It's a great place to visit for Jewish heritage. Both the historical and architectural aspects are impressive.
interesting. this is something to see, i would have liked to have attended a concert there, it could be cleaner, felt quite grubby, feels like it needs the attention it deserves!

A unique and different piece of history. Revives the lost world of rich Jewish life in Prague. It is not likely to come across a synagogue that resembles a church and so rich with decorations. The story is very important and make sure you don't miss it.

A concert at the spanish synogogue. we attended a concert at the beautiful spanish Synonogue last week. the Synoogue is well-kept and is magnificently designed. we enjoyed the music and the chance to see one of the most beautiful synogogues in the world.

Don't forget to go upstairs.. OK, the synagogue, itself, is beautiful, but what really stands out is what's upstairs in the balcony. They've set up a wonderful exhibit of the history of the Jewish people in Prague that far exceeds most of the other historical exhibits around town. You could spend several hours or you could spend just 30 minutes. All the artifacts are nicely interpreted and with excellent English translations, too. Elsewhere around Prague, much seems to be lost in those translations, but not here. Check it out.

Breathtaking. It cost us 100 for 2 to get in I thought it was a bit cheap for what it is! The place is run by the jewish population. The synagogue looks plain from outside but inside its all golden. There is a museum upstairs which shows the holocaust and history of the synagogue and the precious items. Only downpoint is you can not take pictures and as we got there near closing time the gift shop was shut.
guides need to speak quieter to their groups. a very interesting place but difficult to read or see some things in cases has people standby them listening to guides,the guides were FAR to loud
AWESOME. I've been visiting many Synagogues, but this is for far the most beautiful i've ever seen... don't let go the chance to see it for 15 minutes. You will decide to stay for an hour for sure!

Educational and stunning architecture......... We bought a ticket which enabled us to see all the synagogues and the jewish quarter.Stunning place to visit fantastic architecture well worth the price to get in. I would recommend for adults only as small kids would get a bit bored of it i think. This place is NOT open on a saturday so bear this in mind when you plan your trip.
Stunning!. This has to be seen to be believed. The effect of the decoration is dazzling. We went to an excellent concert with a wonderful soprano. Thoroughly recommended
Beautiful architecture.. Take your time to see the whole synagog, from up top as well as the room filled with the silver collection.

Well Worth Entrance Fee. The inside decorations should perhaps remind the mebbers of this jewish society of their origin but it feels today a bit dark and gloomy. More interesting is to read about all remarkable personalities who lived there and whose lives under the 20th century mostly ended in a tragic way. Unfortunately you are not allowed to take photos inside, but the visit is well worth czk 70.

a must see. this synagogue inside is totally covered w/ colors and was totally beautiful. the history about the items was well noted in english. this is part of the jewish museum and includes 6 other sites including the cemetary and the pinkas museum.
What an interior. This Synagogue has an interesting history, but for me the most interesting thing was the gorgeous interior. Absolutely mind blowing.

A lovely synagogue. Gorgeous ornate synagogue with sumptious decoration. The Jewish museum covers the synagogues which are a great visit for anyone with an interest in Prague history or Judaism generally
Different. Duffernet to the other Synagogues, but quaint and interesting all the same.
Must see. You must see the Jewish streets and Jewish museum and old cemetary

Stunning!. If you want to see only one of the synagogues, do pick this one. Built in a beautiful and exotic moorish style, it makes you feel like you were just miraculously transferred to Andalusia. Do not miss the tiny but precious silver exposition on the second floor.

A different kind of synagogue. the inside of this synagogue is unlike any of the others in Prague, as well as any other i have seen. The Moorish (?) designs on the walls was unusual. Even more attention worthy were the displays and descriptions of successful Czech Jews and their demise by the Nazis. You might think you know about the holocaust, then you hear a little more and and gain a deeper understanding of what was lost.

Amazing Architecture. An amazing site, no photos allowed and strictly policed. Worth the price of admission. Would have liked to have seen other sites in the Jewish Quarter, however, you have to buy a block of tickets, due to time constraints and some not being our pick. Decided against.

A wonder to see. I must say that of all the Jewish Quarter, my favorite place and Synagogue is the Spanish Synagogue. With it rich interior, fascinating 2 view facade and the exhibition inside of Prague's Jewish community, this is a must see when in Old Town.

Breath Taking. We bought the entrance fee for all Jewish sites for CZK 480 per person & you need to buy a photo license CZK 50 to take pictures in the cemetry. This allows you to go into the following: The Maisel Synagogue, The Spanish Synagogue, The Pinkas Synagogue, The Old Jewish Cemetery, The Klausen Synagogue & The Ceremonial Hall. You can't take any pictures in any of the Synagogues. We most beautiful Synagogue of all were the Spanish Synagogue. The interior is just breath taking, you need to google the inside to see. There is also a small exhibition worth going through. We spend over 2 hours here.
Beautiful. An incredible building with TONS of information to read and absorb. Spent ages in there reading and contemplating.

Interesting place - interior and exterior. We passed the Spanish Synagogue on our free walking tour and our tour guide explained how the exterior desing was an homage to the Moorish design from Southern Spain where the Jews had had a better standard of living than in Northern Spain with the catholics - very interesting design.We visited the interior the next day and it is a wonderfully decorated interior with several interesting displays with information in both Czech and English to explain their context. Highly recommended to visit.

Nice building – bit pricey. While the Synagogue building was pretty cool, the entry fee was not. I passed on the ticket, but found the building to be worth a look. The western facing is the most interesting. Also the bizarre statue at the front of the building is not to be missed – weird!
All for interior. Outside its not so spesial, but when you step in - its just breathtaking. Nice collection of silver.

Music evening a delight. We had a lovely evening here with a quintet playing pieces from Carmina Burana, Bolero and many others. The soprano Michaela Srumova had a most beautiful voice and the acoustics were brilliant.The synagogue is beautifully decorated in a Moorish style with some Islamic influence. If you arent doing the Jewish museum tour this gets you into the synagogue!

A night of music. This small, but opulent synagogue was the highlight of this trip. You can purchase tickets for a variety of performances held here throughout the year. I enjoyed the night of Czech music with 6 local musicians performing the classics.

Breathtaking. The exterior of this synagogue is lovely, but once you step in, it's stunning. The walls and ceiling are really, really beautiful. I was crushed that we couldn't take pictures, because I would have covered my walls in them. The displays are interesting, but it's really the decoration worth seeing here.

Amazing. The synagogue is not very large but incredibly ornate. The concert we saw was very intimate. A beautiful venue and beautiful music made for an incredible experience. If I had a complaint it would be about the other people in attendance - it amazes me how many grown adults are incapable of shutting up for one hour. If you see the concert, don't talk. You don't have to share every thought that enters your head and whatever you're thinking can wait. Don't be surprised it you get shushed and catch dirty looks if you talk.Having said that, the noise wasn't so bad and we enjoyed the show.

The Spanish Synagogue - A real gem!. We went on the Jewish ghetto tour led by Roman and the Spanish Synagogue was part of it. It's definitely the most beautiful building we've seen in the whole Prague! Apart from its religious and historical value, it is a cultural gem which should not be missed if visiting Prague! We also attended an evening concert here and were thus able to take a few photos - attached, but as the light was rather low-key, I feel they aren't really showing the real beauty of this place. So DO pay a visit, it's worth it!

Stunning. Beautiful exterior but by far the most amazing interior of any building in Prague. It is built in the Moorish style which is quiet unlike any other building in Prague or eastern Europe and it is just incredible. The beauty and detail is unlike anything I had seen before and worth a visit. It costs 70 CZK to get in but you can buy a package for 450 CZK which will let you into all the major sights of the Jewish quarter if you have interest in that. A must see to say the least. The only downfall is that you can’t take pictures.

Gorgeous interior, fabulous concert. The Spanish Synagogue was easily the most beautiful interior I've seen in Prague. I visited it as part of my admission ticket to the Jewish Museum, and then came back in the evening for a classical music concert that was lovely. The concert was about an hour long and was not cheap (about $35 US per person) but the combination of beautiful music in such dramatic surroundings was a memorable experience. I would reccomend it to travelers who want to experience the musical side of the Golden City.Be aware, however, that there are only about eight wooden benches so space is extremely limited, and the seats are far from luxurious. A few people ended up trying to find chairs to pull up because they were unable to sit on the wooden pews comfortably. I did not find it that uncomfortable, but it is not like sitting in a theatre.

Average attraction in the Jewish Museum. This synagogue is out of the way from the other sites in the Museum. The interior is large elaborately decorated, and there are some artifacts. These are mostly documents, pamphlets, news stories, etc. The history here doesn't go back as far as some of the other synagogues, but it is a pretty building. There are free bathrooms with admission. Crowds were small in March. Due to its location, this will probably be the last site visited in Josefov. If short of time, it can be missed. 1/2 hour is more than enough time here.
